Children are naturally good at speaking, but writing is a skill that must be learned. We need to understand how writing works and how to teach it to children.

I have never started a novel with more doubt. I call it a novel because I don't know what else to call it. I have little story to tell, and I don't end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave my reader wondering. This book is about my memories of a man I met only a few times, and I don't know much about what happened to him in between. I could make up details to fill the gaps and make the story clearer, but I don't want to do that. I only want to write what I know. To avoid embarrassing people who are still alive, I have given the characters in this story made-up names, and I have tried to make sure no one can recognize them. The man I am writing about is not famous. He might never be. When he dies, he might leave no more trace than a stone thrown into a river. Then my book, if read at all, will be read only for its own interest. But maybe his way of life and his strong and kind character will influence others, and people will realize that he was a remarkable person. Then it will be clear who I am writing about, and those who want to know about his early life might find something useful in my book. I think my book, with its limits, will be a useful source of information for my friend's biographers. I don't claim that the conversations I have written are exact. I never took notes, but I have a good memory for what matters to me, and though I have put these conversations in my own words, they represent what was said. I mentioned earlier that I have invented nothing, but I have taken the freedom that historians take to put words in the mouths of people in my story that I did not hear myself. I have done this to make the scenes more lively and realistic. I want to be read, and I think I am right to make my book interesting. The smart reader will see where I have used this trick, and he can choose to ignore it. Another reason I am worried about this work is that the people I write about are from another culture. It is hard to know people, and I don't think you can really know anyone but your own countrymen. People are not only themselves; they are also the place they were born, the home they grew up in, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they went to, the sports they played, and the poets they read. These things make them who they are, and you can't know them just by hearing about them; you have to live them. You can only know if you are them. Because you can't know people from another country except by watching them, it is hard to make them believable in a book. I have never tried to write about anyone but my own countrymen, and if I have done so in short stories, it is because you can describe characters briefly. You give the reader a general idea and let him imagine the details. In this book, I don't pretend that my characters see themselves as I see them; they are seen through my eyes.

**POETRY RECITALS**
At any time in history, the world of literature can seem confusing to those living in it. It is only later that people can see the patterns and importance of different writers. Today, there are many different styles of poetry, ways of presenting it, and ideas about the poet's role in society. Generally, there is a debate between two groups: 'literary' poets, who write poems to be read on the page, and 'popular' poets, who prefer to perform their poems in front of an audience. This division is not strict, and public poetry readings have become more common in the last twenty years. These readings happen in many places, like small towns, schools, colleges, and arts festivals.
For 'pop' poets, who write their poems to be performed, public readings are beneficial. Their poems are often simple and easy to understand when heard. However, on the page, their weaknesses in thought and technique can be seen. On the other hand, poets who focus on the craft of poetry, trying to include deep passion, thought, and rhythm, may not be appreciated by an audience hearing their work for the first time. The risk is that they might choose to read only their simpler work to connect quickly with the audience.
Listening to poetry readings cannot replace reading poetry on the page, but it can be a fun and educational experience. Hearing poets read their work can help listeners understand the emphasis and rhythm of the poems. It is helpful if the audience can follow along with the text or know the poems beforehand.
The main reason for popular poetry recitals, sometimes mixed with music, is to make people associate poetry with enjoyment, not just something for a select few.

**Oral History**
Historians are using more oral evidence, but it has challenges. It's not simple to think that someone's story is a perfect picture of the past. In an interview, both the historian and the person telling the story affect each other. The historian chooses who to talk to and what to talk about. Even if the historian just listens, their presence changes how the person remembers and talks about the past. The final story is influenced by the historian's position and how they understand history. Historians help create new evidence, so they must be careful. Also, the person telling the story is not directly connected to the past. Their memories can be mixed with other information, like from the media, or changed by feelings like nostalgia or later life experiences. These feelings can make the story seem convincing, but they might not be from the time being discussed.
**Animal Science**
There are two main ways to study animal science: physiological and whole animal. Physiologists focus on how the body works, like nerves and muscles. The whole animal approach looks at the behavior of the entire animal and what affects it. Within this approach, psychologists and ethologists are different. Psychologists usually study learning in animals like rats and pigeons in labs. Ethologists study natural behavior in wild animals. Although these fields are different, they are now working together more. Physiologists believe their methods are more basic, but understanding behavior also needs studying it as a whole. Describing a bird's nest-building by looking at nerve cells is like trying to read a book with a microscope.
**The Social Sciences**
Students studying social science for the first time face a challenge. They need to learn both the content and the methods of the subject. This means understanding the knowledge in textbooks and how this knowledge is gathered and organized. Social sciences might seem like common sense because we all live in society, but they go beyond that. Each social science focuses on a specific part of social life, uses special methods, and has its own concepts. These concepts are the basic ideas that help social scientists go beyond common sense and make each discipline unique.
**Classical Architecture**
In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building. The Roman architect Vitruvius said architecture is about order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. He used Greek words for some of these ideas, showing they came from earlier Greek sources. Utility and function were not part of his main definition, though he did talk about the best designs for different uses. The focus was on architecture as an art. Classical architecture has complex origins. Before it, there were simple huts in Greece and Italy that didn't meet Vitruvius' artistic standards. These simple forms still influenced later architecture. Despite its appearance, a classical temple is basically a simple, single-roomed hut.

The two sisters, Lily and Mui, kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily would drive around the allotments, railway line, and gasworks. She once made a mistake by jumping a small bridge, but Chen found it amusing when he found out. He was happy about Lily's new skill and planned a trip with her. They chose a Monday at the start of next month, a quiet day, to leave early and return by midday, so they wouldn't lose customers. Lily practiced driving around the allotments in the meantime.
Mui, despite her worries, bought a road map and got a discount, which impressed Chen. Lily felt a bit insulted by Mui's lack of trust in her navigation skills. An hour after leaving home, they reached the English Channel. Lily drove very well, even overtaking some slow cars. Chen applauded her. They drove through a seaside town and parked near the sea. Lily was unsure about the road markings, so she paid for parking to avoid trouble.
Lily locked the van doors carefully. Chen joked that no one would steal the van, which upset the sisters. Chen then took their son, Man Kee, to see the sea. He decided to give Man Kee a good education and hoped he would own many restaurants one day. The sea made Chen feel thoughtful as he planned Man Kee's future.
Chen saw a ship through a telescope and showed it to Man Kee, saying it was special and would take them home one day. Lily and Mui joined them, and Lily tried to see the ship through the telescope, but it was gone by then. She only saw seagulls in the distance.

**The Well**
I had read that if you look from a deep hole, you can see stars during the day. I convinced you to help me try this. You watched as I pulled up the well bucket, steadied it, and climbed in. I asked you to lower me down. I didn't think about how heavy the bucket would be or that you might not be strong enough. You held the handle, but when I pushed the bucket off the well's edge, I fell. You screamed and tried to stop the handle, but then let go. I fell into the well and hit my head. I saw strange lights, like stars in cartoons when characters get hit. At first, I was dazed, then scared, then relieved, and finally angry at you for letting me fall. I was also worried about what Mother would say. You called down to ask if I was okay. I was about to shout back, but you called again, sounding scared, and I stayed quiet. I watched you through my eyelashes. You ran to get help. I quickly climbed out of the well and hid in the shadows near the moat bridge. I heard voices from the castle. Mother and Father came with you and Arthur. Mother was upset, and Father told Arthur to use the winch. You looked pale and shocked. I felt a mix of excitement and fear. Then I saw the wet trail I left from the well to where I hid. I was scared they would see it. Father shone a flashlight into the well. I couldn't believe no one noticed the water drops. Mother was screaming, and I felt guilty. I realized my prank had gone too far and could lead to serious trouble. I regretted not thinking it through. I decided to act like I had just escaped. I came out of hiding, pretending to be weak and tired. I told them I found a secret tunnel from the well to the moat and crawled out. I thought they believed me until Father asked me to repeat the story. I added that the tunnel collapsed after me, so no one could check. Father looked at me with disbelief. He told me not to be ridiculous and walked away. Arthur looked at me with pity, seeing through my lie. His look made me feel ashamed, realizing the seriousness of my actions.

**MOVING DAY**
Susan, a widow, is moving out of her family home now that her children are grown up. The moving van had "Removers of Distinction" written on it. Fred, the removal man, and his team were packing everything from the house into boxes. Fred was careful with the fragile items, but his helpers were not as gentle. Susan was leaving a beautiful four-storey house that overlooked a small harbour. She remembered the years spent there with her children growing up.
When they first bought the house, her son Robert, who was five at the time, asked, "Mum, when you buy a house, how do you get it home?" Now, Robert was an adult and was helping with the move. He was making sure Susan didn't mention the piano. Francesca, her daughter, was also helping. She was very particular about the Steinway piano, insisting that only she could handle it properly.
Fred noticed that Susan wasn't crying. He said many people cry when they see their house being emptied. Susan could understand why. She remembered when they first moved in, and the piano got stuck on the stairs. It took a long time to get it inside. Her late husband, Peter, had solved the problem by hiring a builder to remove a window and using a crane to lift the piano into the house.
Now, Susan was worried about the piano again. The banister rails were still not perfect from the last move. She thought she should have warned the movers, but it was too late. Fred reassured her that they just had the piano left to move. Susan was nervous, but Robert and Francesca were there to support her.
As the piano was moved down the stairs, Susan felt emotional. She realized how much the things in the house meant to her now that they were being moved. But when the piano was safely outside, Robert started laughing, and soon all three of them were laughing together. They walked down the path arm in arm, and the only tears Susan shed were tears of laughter.

**Online Book Reviews: Fun for Everyone?**
When the Internet started, the idea was that anyone could share their thoughts online. In the beginning, you needed some technical skills to do this. But one area that became open to everyone was book reviews. Amazon.com, the first big online bookstore, allowed anyone to write a review for a book. People could rate books from one to five stars and share their opinions. This was great because it let buyers see what other readers thought, not just what publishers or professional critics said.
Amazon was the biggest online bookstore, with over 80% of the market. It had many reviews, but this also led to some problems. Many reviews were submitted every day, so it was hard to check them all. Amazon had rules: no single-word reviews, no personal attacks, no spoilers, and no bad language. But since reviewers were anonymous, some people broke the rules. For example, some authors wrote fake positive reviews for their own books. One author, Lev Grossman, did this until he admitted it in an article, and then Amazon removed his fake reviews.
Authors could also comment on their own books through a special link. Most authors used this to encourage people to buy their books. However, Amazon did not always check if the comments really came from the authors, except for famous writers. For example, a fake comment pretending to be from the famous author John Updike was removed.
Sometimes, readers used reviews to express their anger. When James McElroy's book about a cheerleading team was published, some people in the book felt upset and wrote negative reviews on Amazon. These reviews disappeared after a few days.
Despite these issues, Amazon liked that people spent time writing reviews because it was good for business. They watched popular books closely to make sure reviews followed the rules. Funny reviews were more common on less popular books. For example, a children's book called "The Story about Ping" inspired a funny review that compared the book to Internet technology.
Most reviews on Amazon were serious and gave a good idea of whether a book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once said that reviewing too many books could be boring. But with everyone able to write reviews, it made the process more interesting and fair.

**Art in Modern Times**
In the last two hundred years, people often think that every artist must be different from others. Art is admired for being unique, new, or even shocking. We like to praise artists whose work was not appreciated a hundred years ago. But when it comes to today's art, we sometimes feel unsure and say an artist has gone too far, that it is not art anymore. The media often say this for us, and we agree because we expect art to be new and different. We forget that today's art also has old themes and methods. We think artists should be special and different from us, with talents that cannot be controlled by rules. In the past, people asked artists to create art for specific reasons, and it was part of everyday life. Today, we let artists do what they want and get upset if they try to be more like us.
**Picture This**
I will describe a situation and ask an important question. An artist picks a piece of text from an art book. The text talks about different kinds of pictures and says, "There is no end to the number of different kinds of pictures." The artist asks someone to make a canvas and take it to a sign painter. The sign painter writes the text on the canvas in simple black letters. My question is: Is this a painting?
**Underground Encounters**
At the Mercury Gallery, London until 26th June
Usually, when a painter finds success in one style, they stick to it. Collectors expect this, and trying something new can upset people. Gallery owners like safe choices, and the public likes things to stay the same. Some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, change styles and succeed. Eric Rimmington is another artist trying something new. He is known for still life paintings but now paints the London Underground. He has always liked railways and started drawing them in the 1980s. His new show, "Underground Encounters," has 40 paintings and drawings showing the magic of the underground world.
**Extract from a Novel**
I have come to this island with a few books. The villagers joke that only a sick person would come to such a remote place to heal. I am here to heal myself. Apart from an old woman who comes to clean the house, I am alone. I am neither happy nor unhappy; I feel like I am floating in memories. I talked about how art seems useless but did not mention its comforts. The comfort of my work is that in the quiet of painting or writing, reality can be changed and shown in a new way. Our everyday actions hide the true meaning of life. For artists, art is a way to deal with what hurts us in life, not to avoid it, but to fulfill it with imagination. Otherwise, why do we hurt each other?

**Family Business**
"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were driving back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice, had just picked me up from the fancy girls' school I attended. He had also been to Parent's Day, where I received the Latin prize and the prize for doing best in my exams. He talked with my headteacher, and now we were going home for the holidays.
"What isn't?" I asked, though I guessed what he was thinking because he was unusually quiet. He usually talked a lot. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I was told you will get a scholarship to Oxford."
"So?" I said, trying to be brave. "Mightn't that be useful?"
"I also heard," he continued, and I knew a confrontation was coming, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister of all things!" My father knew a lot about barristers and the law.
"I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"
"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality - you can understand a lot of information quickly, you talk well, and you enjoy performing."
"I don't know about that," I said. "I only know what I see in TV dramas."
"Be that as it may," he continued, "I feel your heart's never going to be in the business now. Obviously, you'll go to Oxford University, and after that, I can't see you wanting it."
The problem was that, like many children in family businesses, I felt trapped by family expectations. I saw other careers open to me, and I wanted to explore them. At the same time, I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was the favorite - but I found him intimidating.
"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.
"I tell you you're not going to want to join us," said my father, who was usually right about these things, "and it's a pity because you've got the gifts - the brains, the nerves, the vision."
"There's still Maurice," I said, sulking. My father snorted. We both knew Maurice hated the business.
"Anyway," I continued, "you could always use me as a sort of consultant."
My mother wasn't around to help - she died when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger, and because he was motherless, I got used to taking care of him. It wasn't hard. I loved Maurice. Because the business was successful, we lived in luxury - a big house in London, fancy schools, nice clothes, parties, theatres, operas. My father knew many people - politicians, actors, businessmen - and our house was full of interesting conversations.
"I tell you what," my father said. "You can help us during holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you decide to leave us, you can. It will give you some pocket money and be a real help to me."
"OK," I said, relieved to avoid immediate decisions and my father's sulks if I opposed him. This was how he controlled us.
So it happened. In my last term at school, and then during university vacations, I helped out, never more than twice a year, and always on safer tasks. I became one of the smarter students, with a little house, a small but powerful white car, designer clothes, and a black dress with a Paris label for my final exams.
In my last term, my father visited me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left. My tutor predicted I would get a First Class degree in Law, and I knew that if I stayed focused, he might be right. I felt confident and concentrated.
This was not to be. My father told me that, in about a week, he needed me for one last assignment, the most important business the family firm had ever attempted, and that it would be worth my while.
"But Dad," I protested, "I've got my final exams coming up, and I need to concentrate on that. It's really important that I do well, and I don't want to think about anything else right now."
I could tell that such pressures were beyond my father's imagination (or maybe he was jealous of my life away from him?) and that he would see a refusal as a betrayal in his time of need.
That was not all. As he described the procedures, I saw more clearly than ever before the single-mindedness of my father - the clarity and resourcefulness with which he worked, the dynamic energy, the perfect self-control. In his way, he was a sort of genius, and I respected that. It made my own plans and hopes seem less important.
"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with his wife, Lois. They could only afford it by being very careful with money, which was not ideal. At first, it seemed like a good decision because Simon had many successful cases, and Lois had returned to her job at the advertising agency with a higher salary of thirty-five thousand. Lois wanted to move because their flat was too small for a family, and they needed more space, a garden, and a place for an au pair. They could have found these things in a less expensive area, but Lois wanted a better address for their social status. 
To save money, Lois decided one of them should use public transport. Since her job was far away, Simon had to take the crowded tube, which made him unhappy. He often thought about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where his grandmother took care of everything so his grandfather could relax after work. But times had changed, and Lois made it clear that her career was as important as Simon's. They needed both salaries to maintain their lifestyle.
Now, their situation was at risk because of Venetia. She came to their office very upset, accusing Simon of knowing that a client, Brian Cartwright, had bribed jurors in a past case. She also said Cartwright gave shares to Simon's fiancée before the trial. Simon denied everything, but his denial seemed weak even to himself. He felt guilty and remembered being punished as a child. He wished he had been prepared and said something different. Venetia's anger and disgust confused him. He wondered why she was so upset and if she had the right to ruin his career. If the rumors spread, he knew his career would be over.

I chose this place to live because I thought I could be anonymous here. I believed people wouldn't care if the houses were old and the gardens were messy. But I was wrong. People in the shops soon start to recognize you. The roses next door remind me that the gardens were once loved. Usually, I stay inside, trying to forget about summer, but tonight, I am watching the birds fly between the trees and roofs. I have cleared some space in the garden for a chair, and my arms are scratched from the plants. It is a small London garden where plants must grow tall to survive. 
My upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leans out of the window. She writes books that haven't been published, and sometimes I have to pretend to like them because I am an English teacher. I have her latest book now. 'How's the work going, Jaz?' I ask. 'In no other job do people ask you about your work all the time,' she replies. Then she says, 'I'll bring something to drink.' I don't want Jaz in the garden, and I see now that it looks messy. The only way to the garden is through my flat, and Jaz is knocking on my door. 'You're on holiday now,' she says, sitting in a chair. 'Cheers,' she adds, 'I should've been a teacher - writers don't get holidays. They say, those who can, do, those who can't, teach.' And some can't do either. 'What plans for the holidays?' she asks. 
I feel worried about the school year ending. Empty days. Hot pavements. The walk to the shops and back. The little park with its fountain, and feeling lonely on the bench. 'Actually, I'm going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed the cats?' I ask, feeling nervous. 'Of course,' Jaz says. 'If I'm around,' knowing she will be. 'Where will you stay?' she asks. 'With my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun. We've known each other since we were eight.' It's not true, but I often deal with fiction. 'Going back to your roots. What do you think of my book?' Jaz asks about her manuscript, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which I haven't finished reading. I like the title and tell her so. I can see how red vans could be cruel, always bringing gifts to other houses and returning her manuscripts. I decide to be honest. 'Let me give you a tip,' I say. 'What?' she asks, upset. 'Try writing about nice people for a change, people who want to be good: less about yourself, more fiction...' 'Teachers!' Jaz says, like a student unhappy with a grade. 'I keep a journal,' I say, 'where I write something good about each day.' My words sound old-fashioned. 'Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann.' 
Oh, I have a life. I have my work, and I go out sometimes and come home, reading on the tube. When we go inside, my calm kitchen reassures me. Then I suddenly remember my school geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age now, winking as she said, 'I've had my moments.' We almost died laughing.

**Heritage**
Heritage is important because it connects people and communities to the past. We often feel connected to our personal heritage, like knowing about our grandparents and their stories. But there is also a need to learn about our wider past to understand our future. Heritage gives us a sense of continuity, helping us feel part of history. Just like we inherit genes, we also inherit culture from past generations. Even if there are parts of our national heritage we don't like, it is still ours, and it feels good to belong to something. Heritage teaches us a lot and is important for our well-being. It influences everything from customs to material culture. In the past, we learned about our heritage through stories from our ancestors. But now, because of changes in society, many of these stories are lost. Instead, places and buildings help us remember the past. It is important to protect these links to honor our ancestors.
**The Fens**
I started writing a novel called "Waterland," where the landscape of the Fens in England became important. People often ask why I, a Londoner, wrote about a place I have no personal connection with. I chose the Fens because they seemed simple and empty, a good setting for my story. But I learned that the Fens are not really flat or empty. They are as English as any other place but also very unique and mysterious. It is interesting that in the middle of England, there is a place that feels foreign to many English people. The Fens are both empty and full, cultivated and wild, open and mysterious. While writing, I did not visit many places in the Fens. As a fiction writer, I prefer to imagine places rather than rely on facts. The Fens are not just a landscape but also a state of mind.
**Museums**
Museums should make their collections easy to access. In the past, this meant putting items in display cases with long labels. Now, displays should be lively and interesting, using techniques to capture visitors' attention. Museums should also reach out to the community. For example, they can provide boxes of objects for teachers to use in class or for helping elderly people with memory loss. Museums focus on real items, not replicas. They show things that existed and had meaning in history. This is what makes them different from heritage centers and theme parks. Museums that create exciting displays and programs will find that virtual history can actually help them by making people want to see the real things.
**Architecture and Environment**
The desire to preserve things is not new, but now changes in our towns happen quickly and affect many people. This makes some people want to preserve everything, while others think more about the future of towns. People who have lived through big events like world wars may care more about preserving things because they value stability. If there is a need to preserve, planners should consider it. Change is not bad if we learn to manage it. Changes in our towns reflect changes in society, like our population, welfare, and needs.

**Einstein**
If you ask someone on the street to name a scientist, they will probably say Albert Einstein. His face is often used to sell smart products, like computers and encyclopedias. Most people don't know much about what Einstein did, except that he created some theories called 'relativity'. These theories are famous for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions that seem different from everyday life. Einstein was part of a big change in science, which started modern science in the 20th century. Scientists were trying to describe the universe better by studying matter and natural forces. Einstein made important contributions by rethinking the basics: time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, people believed in Isaac Newton's idea that stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein changed this idea, saying that time and space are not fixed but relative.
**Young Readers**
When we were children, Lydia and I didn't like prize-winning books because we thought they would be boring. Our mother didn't like this attitude, but our father would give us small amounts of money to encourage us to read these books. He would also give us better books as gifts, marking them with 'This Book is NOT Literature'. We often thought these were 'boys' books', but sometimes we found some good short stories and once, a famous book of poems.
**Language**
In 1851, Jacob Grimm wrote that the origin of human language is a wonderful mystery. This mystery has led to many strange ideas. In 1928, Charles Caller said that early humans might have made sounds like "meuh" when they were in danger. This sound is sad, and people in dangerous places made desperate noises. Some words today, like malaria (meaning "fever") or the Latin mors (meaning "death"), might come from these sounds. Because of these strange ideas, many people avoided the topic, thinking it was for odd thinkers. But now, the origin and evolution of language are important research areas. Language probably started in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. It was mainly used for friendly communication and was important in power struggles. Sharing information was probably not its original purpose, even though philosopher John Locke said language was a 'great conduit' for sharing knowledge.

'Writing Reviews Frank Kermode talks about how to write reviews from a writer's point of view. Most reviews are written quickly and don't last long. They have deadlines and are usually short. Once published, they are only read for a short time, like a day or a week. People often think that writing reviews is not important work. Many writers do it because they need money or because they can't work on their big projects all the time. However, writing reviews is a skilled job. It's different to write a short review for a newspaper than a long one for an international journal. Reviewers also need to think about who will read their reviews, from casual readers to those very interested in the topic. A good reviewer knows a lot about many things and can write clearly and enjoyably. Reviewers often write other things too. For example, the American novelist John Updike writes reviews between writing his novels. He collects his reviews into books, even if they are short. Some people think only famous writers should keep their reviews, but others believe anyone can if they think their reviews are good. I feel this way about my own work. I am mainly an academic, and my serious books are academic. In the English-speaking world, it's common for people to both review and study literature. In the past, some academics didn't like professors writing reviews, but now it's more accepted. There is more reviewing work now, so many people can do it. I think this is good for readers because they know the reviewer understands the topic. It's also good for professors because it helps them communicate better with non-professors. In the end, reviewing is a secondary job. You can only do it well if you are also doing something else well.'

Ralph unlocked the door to his apartment and entered the dark, quiet hallway. Even after three years, he sometimes felt a little unsure about owning the place when he came home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the flat, he would come home excited and curious, often as early as possible, wondering what the flat had been like while he was away. It felt like a welcoming place to him, where he was in control. He thought he should worry about things like intruders or leaks, but the flat always seemed to be waiting for him, either tidy or messy, depending on how he left it. Over time, he started to see it as just another part of himself, a space filled with his thoughts and feelings. He became frustrated that it couldn't change. Sometimes, there would be a small pile of letters by the door or a blinking light on the answering machine when he returned. He was glad the windows hadn't been broken or the flat damaged, but he wondered what it would look like if that happened. From his dull office on Holloway Road, Ralph often looked forward to his evenings alone at home. Once he left the office and started his bus ride home, he felt more like himself and didn't need to be alone anymore, though he often forgot this when planning his social life. At his desk, he longed for time alone with his things, but once home, he felt empty and waited for a sense of self to return. Instead, he felt a deep emptiness, making him think that working in a job he didn't like had changed him, moving him away from who he thought he was. He would read or listen to music at night, but now he wondered why he did these things. His thoughts and feelings seemed unclear and disconnected. There was a time, he thought, when he didn't feel so powerless, when he might have escaped if he had realized his own worth. But he had been eager to settle into something and followed the first path that seemed right. After university, he tried to make a plan for his future, but he only wanted to survive quietly. He applied for jobs he heard about from friends and followed their paths, not imagining he could find a job that would make him happy. He went to one interview and didn't think much about the job itself, which was an editorial role at a free local newspaper. He was just happy to have a nice conversation with Neil, his boss, and didn't think about the long meetings he would have later. Neil offered him the job right away, saying Ralph was the only graduate who applied, which Ralph took as a compliment at the time.

**Goat Racing**
I was about to see goat racing. It was Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. I moved through ice-cream vans, many people, food stalls, and loud music. Everyone was going to the racecourse, and I tried to find a good spot. A part of the area was marked off for the race. It was not like big racecourses, but people stood on both sides of the track to watch the goats. It was hard to keep the goats in order because they like to eat almost anything.
**Canoe Trip**
As the day ended, I thought about the night ahead and felt scared. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, and there was nowhere to stop. We hadn't seen any villages or huts since morning. In the dim moonlight, we used our torch to see the cliffs, but the batteries were low. We put in new ones, but they didn't work. We couldn't find a place to camp. A few miles later, Lesley said she saw a light, and we felt hopeful. But it was just moonlight on the waves. Soon, we heard the loud noise of fast water, but we couldn't see it. Time seemed to stop, and we kept moving.
**How to be Presentation Perfect - we answer your questions**
I am not good at making presentations, but as a managing director, I have to present to my colleagues and shareholders. How can I get better at presentations and feel more confident?
You are not alone. Making a presentation is different from running a company, but many senior executives need to be good at it. If you want to convince your audience, you must believe in what you are saying. Show your belief with passion and enthusiasm. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas before the presentation. Ask colleagues to think of difficult questions the audience might ask. Also, start with something everyone agrees on and slowly build to your main point.

Some activities cannot be rushed. They need their own time. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you add oil too quickly to mayonnaise, it will curdle. If you pull hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot will get tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some things it does very fast, while others take longer. We can get faster at solving puzzles or doing math in our heads. But some things cannot be rushed. If we try, they will fail, like the mayonnaise, or get tangled, like the fishing line. Sometimes, trying to think fast is not helpful, like trying to sleep in half the time. We learn and think in different ways, and these ways work at different speeds. "He who hesitates is lost," says one proverb. "Look before you leap," says another. Both are true. The mind has three different speeds. The first is faster than thought. Some situations need a quick reaction. When my motorbike skidded on a wet road, my brain and body reacted quickly to keep me safe. A concert pianist or an Olympic fencer also reacts quickly. This fast intelligence is called our "wits." Then there is thought itself, which involves figuring things out and solving problems. A mechanic fixing an engine or a student working on an assignment uses this kind of intelligence, called "intellect." Someone good at this is called "bright" or "clever." Below this is a slower way of thinking. It is less clear and more relaxed. When we are lost in thought by the sea or just waking up, we are in this mode. This slow way of thinking is just as important as the faster ones. Thinking slowly is important, especially when life is busy. We need the slow mind as much as the fast one. Some problems are better solved with a slow mind. Recent studies show that slow thinking is good for complex situations. Fast thinking works well when the problem is clear. But when we don't know what to consider, we need the slow mind. If the problem is managing a difficult group at work or changing careers, it is better to think slowly. This type of intelligence is linked to creativity and wisdom. Poets and philosophers have long known the limits of fast thinking. Scientists are now studying slow thinking. Cognitive science shows that the unconscious mind can do many important tasks if given time. It can learn patterns, understand complex situations, and solve difficult problems better than fast thinking.

**Surviving in a Foreign Land**
I have been welcomed warmly. It's a friendly and well-supplied base camp in a very isolated place. At any time, there are about forty people - scientists, students, weathermen, satellite trackers - in a close community where everyone helps each other. My school-level French is just enough to communicate, but not to have casual conversations. I miss the small details, and my phrasebook is not helpful at breakfast. This is not a practical problem for me, but at first, it affected my self-confidence. I was a bit nervous about mealtimes. I would hesitate, unsure about which table to choose, worried about the silence when I spoke, anxious like I was in the first weeks of school. I still smile awkwardly or panic when people talk to me. I think this occasional sadness is not because of missing company or communication, but because I have lost the social advantage that my ability to talk has always given me.
**Elliot**
When I first met Elliot, I was just a young author like any other, and he didn't pay much attention to me. He never forgot a face though, and when I saw him again, he shook hands with me warmly, but didn't try to become friends. If I saw him at the opera with someone important, he often pretended not to see me. But then I had a big success as a playwright, and I noticed that Elliot was more interested in me. One day, he invited me to lunch, and I thought he was testing me. After my success brought me many new friends, I started to see him more often.
**Alfred Hitchcock**
The film director Alfred Hitchcock always said he didn't care about the story of his films or the acting, but he did care about the photography and the soundtrack and all the technical parts. For Hitchcock, it wasn't a message or a great performance that moved the audience. He believed that people are excited by pure film, no matter their cultural background. So, if a film is made correctly, people from different countries should react the same way. Hitchcock's view of himself was always clear and logical. He was a man of reason and a talented craftsman who liked to hear an audience scream. He didn't deal with guesses or abstract ideas, and he didn't explore his screen characters deeply. He focused on film, pure film, and the precise beauty of what a strip of film can do to an audience.

**Amateur Astronomy**
Many things have changed in astronomy over the last 50 years. About 30 years ago, there were not many charts and catalogues. Telescopes were basic, and there were few books on practical astronomy. Today, you can buy many types of telescopes and equipment. Electronic calculators and computers have changed how we make charts and analyze observations. This might be the best time for amateur astronomy. However, some things have been lost. Now, you might need to travel 80 km to find a sky as clear as it was in cities 50 years ago. During the day, airplane trails can stay in the sky for hours and turn into clouds, making it hard to observe the sun and stars.
**Too Much Choice**
Today, there are too many choices. There are too many things to do and too many options. In the new economy, people always want the newest product or service. Technology makes changes happen faster. New products come out quickly, and it can be overwhelming. More choices can mean more stress, less time, and more complexity. People are now looking for 'simplexity' - simple things that give meaning in a complex world. But simplifying life is hard when there are so many products and services. There are more types of detergent and breakfast cereals than we need, and more software updates and phone plans than we can follow.
**McAndrews Hotel**
Every summer, we spend two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. It is a family tradition started by my grandmother, and now it is very important to us. Nothing can change this ritual. The people who stay at McAndrews are similar: old-fashioned and maybe a bit snobbish. I do not like the bad manners of shop assistants today, and I do not like waiters who try to be too friendly. I know most of the other guests' names because they have been coming here since they were children, like me. But I can be sure that when I see them in the hotel, we will only exchange polite greetings. Such respect for privacy is rare in hotels today.

**Othello**
A special version of Shakespeare's play "Othello" has moved from Stratford to London. This gives me a chance to correct a review I wrote when the show first started last spring. I said Ray Fearon was too young for the main role and criticized his acting. I still think it's not right to ignore the age difference between Othello and Desdemona, but I was wrong about Mr. Fearon's amazing performance. The whole cast is excellent. Memorable scenes include Cassio's games with other officers that become dangerous, and the moment when Iago starts to lose control. The scene where Emilia helps Desdemona get ready for bed is very emotional. The pace and tension are great throughout. Don't miss this show.
**Lake Vostok**
In the middle of Antarctica, there is no movement. On the edges of the continent, there are many penguins, seals, and birds. But on the large white plateau inside, there is no life. Except in a huge hidden lake called Lake Vostok, which is under almost 4 kilometers of ice, at the coldest place on earth. The water has been without air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Biologists are eager to explore its mysterious depths and find out what strange creatures live there. Geologists and glaciologists are also interested. For two years, researchers from around the world have been planning how to uncover the lake's secrets. If they succeed, the next few years will be known as the decade of Lake Vostok.
**Scientists**
There was an interesting topic on the radio last week. It seems that some scientists are very excited about what makes them want to be scientists. The phrase "because it's there" comes to mind. We all know it's the old search for knowledge, the wish to understand everything from atoms to black holes. But these scientists want to know why we want to know all of this in the first place and why science can't explain our curiosity. Surely, it's more important to know if what scientists are doing is right, rather than getting stuck in debates about the purpose of it all. I think the important thing is not why we do science, but to understand that science is a tool, and we should decide how, where, when, and why to use it.

**Food**
Our relationship with food is very important and satisfying. Many people think cooking is only worth it for special occasions or complicated dishes. But that's not true. You can make a delicious soup by just putting some chopped carrots, a leek, celery, and herbs into water. This is much better than buying a packet or opening a can. Instead of buying a chocolate mousse with preservatives, you can make a tasty dessert in five minutes that everyone will love. Cooking is also a way to show care and love. Sharing food is important in our lives, which is why we celebrate birthdays, anniversaries, and other events around tables. No one would have a takeaway for a wedding or anniversary party! And not many people would discuss a business deal over canned soup.
**In the Elevator**
This morning, Alistair tried to clean his office, but papers were still everywhere. Tax forms were stuffed in drawers and boxes, waiting for a day when he felt like filing them. He also had extra paperwork from owning an apartment building. Books and journals were near the new bookshelves. As the elevator took him to his floor, he knew Mallory would be on time for their meeting. She was always punctual and neat. How would she react to the mess? She might think someone had vandalized the office. He could pretend to be shocked. Mrs. Wilson, his cleaning lady, arrived while he was trying to clear some space on the carpet. He smiled at her with hope, but she wasn't interested in cleaning his office. She only took care of his apartment, which was her responsibility. Mrs. Wilson thought of him as someone from another world, not from her familiar Brooklyn streets.
**KAREN**
Karen wanted to be different from her mother, so she created her own story of strength. A key moment was when she was twelve, and her brother accidentally hit her in the eye with a golf club. She thought she was blind, but the doctor said the bone protected her eye. She only needed a few stitches. When she opened her eyes in the doctor's office and saw her mother talking about miracles, she felt she was saved for a reason.
**Miss Fogerty**
Miss Fogerty was walking across the village green, feeling both excited and sad. She had just learned something important, which was exciting in her quiet life. But she was also very sad about Dr. Bailey's condition. He had been her doctor for many years and helped her with her yearly throat problems. She appreciated how he always made time for his patients and listened to their worries. This made him very loved in the village. He always gave his time, knowledge, and humor, and in return, he received loyalty and affection.

Joanna's Lessons
Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. But she also writes books for young children learning the piano. Joanna is known for her amazing piano skills. She plays many styles of music, like classical, jazz, and blues. At a concert for kids, a boy asked her to play "Match of the Day." Joanna found it funny and played it, making the boy happy.
Joanna is different from many top pianists because she cares about how children learn the piano. She has written a piano book for children called "Joanna MacGregor's Piano World." She did this even though she has a very busy schedule. She is involved in many music festivals and runs her own recording label, Sound Circus. She also likes to work with other artists.
Joanna believes the first piano lessons are very important. She thinks music should be for everyone, not just for those who want to be great musicians. She grew up with many children learning different types of music at her home, where her mother taught piano. She believes everyone should have the chance to learn the piano, just like learning to swim or speak a little French.
Some children learn piano quickly, but Joanna is interested in those who take their time. Many children stop learning because they feel they can't meet their parents' expectations. Joanna wants music to be fun and enjoyable, not just about achieving goals.
Joanna's books are colorful and have stories to make learning fun. They come with CDs that have music for children to play along with. She believes learning should be fun and encourages children to improvise and explore the piano.
As children progress, they need to learn to read music, not just play by ear. Joanna understands this because she also relied on her ear when she was young. She believes practice is very important. She didn't practice much until she went to the Royal Academy of Music, where she learned difficult music that required practice. Now, she practices eight hours a day and finds it very important.
Joanna says the key to practice is knowing what you want to achieve. She suggests playing the whole piece, even with mistakes, and mixing hard and easy pieces.

**Writing by Hand and on Screen**
Dr. Johnson once said, "What is written without effort is in general read without pleasure." This means that good writing is often difficult to create. When I look back at my handwritten school essays, I notice there are not many mistakes. Today, I would rewrite them many times. I think this is because writing by hand is hard work. Writing slowly helps the brain to think carefully. When it is hard to change or erase something, we write with more care. Using a computer can make us careless. Many writers find that they spend as much time fixing their computer drafts as they did writing by hand. Also, emails are not as personal as handwritten letters. Some people say emails have brought back the art of love letters. Many love emails are sent now, where before there was only small talk. This is good because at least these emails are written in some form of English. But words on a screen can feel boring. People who write on computers often do not understand the power of words and can exaggerate. Words written quickly on a computer lack the care and character of handwriting.
**The CD**
I put down my cup and looked at the CD. The case was not special, but the shiny disc inside was interesting. "Wonderful little things, aren't they?" Mr. Warriston said, coming back into the room. I agreed and gave the disc to him carefully. "It's amazing they can hold seventy minutes of music," he said, turning on the hi-fi. He pressed a button, and a small drawer came out. He put the disc in and pressed the button again, and the drawer went back in. "Some people say they sound too clean, but I think they..." "Do you have to turn them over, like records?" I asked. "What? No," Mr. Warriston said. "You only play one side." "Why?" I asked. He looked confused, then thoughtful. "I don't know. You could have two lasers or just turn it over by hand... hmm." He smiled at me. "Yes, good point." He nodded at my chair. "Come on, let's get you sitting in the best place for the stereo effect, eh?" I smiled, happy to have asked a question Mr. Warriston couldn't answer.
**Books versus Electronic Text**
When comparing books and electronic text, author Malcolm Bradbury was right when he said that if matches were invented after lighters, we would think they were better. Many people say electronic text is as important as the invention of printing and that it is almost complete. They forget that changes in how we think take a long time. For example, a book from 1979 said that books would start to disappear in the 1980s. This was not true. Reading long texts on a screen is not enjoyable, so most people don't do it. Computers make it easy to read small parts of text. Some people say this leads to new ways of storytelling. But reading parts of a text is not new. Many books, like religious texts and dictionaries, are not read from start to finish. What is new is that computers do not encourage reading a whole text.
**The Office**
Charles walked into the office and saw everything in perfect order. The carpet was clear, and the desk was dark wood, just like he remembered from the auction five weeks ago. Neat file-holders were in their drawers. Twelve years of trade journals filled the shelves. Kathleen tried to close the filing cabinet and then spoke to him. "You have to use computers, Charles. This is too much." "Hello, Kathleen. Oh, this is amazing." He admired the room and its antique furniture. He did not think about computers or any other machines, not even a pencil sharpener. "Simply amazing," he said, avoiding the topic of computers. Over the two years he knew her, they had this conversation many times. She could not understand why he resisted technology when he was so good with computers and had even written an important paper on computer skills. She had inspired that paper. She could use a keyboard to change any software into something new.

"You don't take sugar, do you?" shouted his secretary. She wasn't really asking because she had been making Lancelot coffee for many months. She usually forgot because he wasn't supposed to be there. But now, he was there all the time. He realized that if he stayed away, things would go wrong. He thought about how he went from being a valued advisor, meeting authors and playwrights over lunch, to someone always trying to prevent problems, with no parking space at work. "This came," she yelled, waving a folder before putting it in front of him. "From that guy in Los Angeles. You said you wanted to see it." The label said: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert." It also said "An Expanded Synopsis." Lancelot did not want to see another synopsis. He wanted to see a "First Draft." Ian Cuthbert had been given a large advance for this book when Lancelot bought the company. Ian was an old friend, and Lancelot had made the mistake of commissioning books from friends. Ian was proof that friends can be unreliable. Lancelot skipped the introduction and read the synopsis. He recognized almost every phrase. He closed the folder and put it aside. It seemed Ian's manuscript would never come. The synopsis lacked the brilliance Ian was known for and felt like it had no real conviction. Lancelot remembered stories of a famous author whose last book was published incomplete after his death. The author was paid chapter by chapter. But Ian had already received a large advance. Lancelot, who studied modern languages at Oxford, remembered when Ian was the most promising talent at Cambridge. Ian's friends took over British theatre quickly, but Ian seemed even more talented. He wore his coat like a cape and talked about famous writers as if he knew them. But Ian's talent stayed hidden. While others succeeded, Ian became more difficult. He was chosen to edit an arts magazine but never published it. His contract with a fashion magazine produced little except stories about his high salary. At meetings, Ian criticized others' ideas. Ten years later, he was unreliable. Lancelot was starting to admit that "A World History of the Short" was a mistake from the beginning.

'England's breakfast change The importance of a good breakfast is clear according to health experts. However, breakfast is quite new in England's history. In medieval times, breakfast was not common. There are some mentions of travelers eating at dawn before long journeys, and sick people having breakfast for health reasons. But most people did not eat breakfast unless they were kings or nobles. In the sixteenth century, breakfast slowly became normal for everyone. Some say this was because there was more food available. But they might not have thought about other big social changes. For example, new work patterns might explain why breakfast became more important. People started working for set hours, often very early. So, eating in the morning became necessary and was not just for the rich.'

**Photography**
When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to show based on their skills, personal views, and cultural norms. In this book, we will see how these factors affect the style and meaning of a photo, and how people react to it. For example, when we look at a photo in a newspaper, we might think about whether it shows the scene as it really was or if it shows the photographer's opinion. Is the exact moment important, or is the photo a symbol of something bigger in the world?
**More than a Game**
For me, sport is more than just a game. The best people in sport believe in themselves completely. You need to focus if you want to succeed. There is only one way to be the best, and you have to ignore everything else. Sport is tough, and no one will do it for you. It's all or nothing. Sport has taught me discipline and determination, but also how to work as part of a team. My sport lets you shine individually, but it's also a team game, and you need to balance both. It's like life - you can succeed alone, but you must remember others around you. Sport has given me a lot, not just money. It has opened doors and shown me things around the world that others may never see. But you also have to give up a lot for these benefits.
**Tuning In**
Some experiences stay very clear in our memory. For me, one such moment happened one night in California many years ago. I was awake, listening to a mockingbird singing beautifully from a tree in the neighborhood. I don't usually have trouble sleeping, but the bird's song kept me awake. As I listened to its complex melodies, I felt like I was in a new artistic world. To understand the bird's song, I thought about my knowledge of jazz and Indian classical music. The bird's performance was like an amazing improvisation. I reacted with surprise and joy as each new musical variation came through the window, until I finally fell asleep.

People have always had strong feelings about birds. But what do these feelings say about us? Paul Evans explores this idea. 
In a greenhouse, a small brown bird, a wren, is hitting the glass. Wrens are seen as special birds in British culture. In the past, people believed that the way wrens flew could tell them about their future luck. Today, wrens are still popular in British art and homes. Even if old beliefs are forgotten, wrens are still loved. A forest without wrens feels empty. 
This connection with birds comes from old stories and beliefs. For example, in the 1500s, red kites were common in London and were seen as helpful birds. Later, they were seen as pests and almost disappeared, except in Wales. Now, they are protected and are a symbol of conservation in Britain.
Our connection with birds is deep and goes back to early human history. Early humans watched birds to learn about danger, weather, and food. Birds also connected them to their dreams. Birds represent flight, song, and freedom, which are important to us. Some people think these feelings are old and not needed now, but they are still part of us. 
Birds are now seen as indicators of environmental health. In Britain, 30 bird species are endangered, which is sad because it means losing cultural symbols too. Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing have special meanings in literature and folklore. Their loss is felt deeply. 
Folklore is important because it keeps stories and feelings about birds alive. These stories connect us to the past and help us understand our feelings about birds. Whether we watch birds on TV or in our gardens, the excitement we feel is hard to explain with science. Birds are fascinating, and the stories we tell about them help us understand their messages. The wren in the greenhouse is a mystery that connects the past, present, and future.

'Maps The purpose of a map is to show how places and features on the earth relate to each other. This is done using distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance by time, like 'a day's walk' or 'a few hours by river'. This told more about how easy it was to travel through the area than the actual distance. Direction was also important, but for most travelers, the main questions were 'Where do I go from here?' and 'How far is it?'. Because of this, written directions were often used instead of maps. Even today, some maps, like train maps, do not show true directions. Early maps used signs to show important landmarks, and these signs varied in size to show their importance. The way maps were made depended on their purpose and where they were made. To understand old maps, it is important to know the conventions used at that time. The history of map-making is about improving the accuracy of distance and direction and adding more details to maps. Map-making has used other sciences to help. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, people used the magnetic compass. Instruments were created to measure angles accurately. As people explored more, they tried to map the world. Astronomers found that the earth is not a perfect sphere, but slightly flat at the poles, which changed how large areas were mapped. Over time, different people needed maps for different reasons. Soldiers needed accurate maps for planning battles, especially with the use of artillery. Archaeologists, historians, and geographers also had their own needs. Modern map-makers have developed ways to map things like geological layers, climate, and land use. Today, maps are important for understanding many scientific phenomena, leading to a modern revival in map-making. However, the progress in map-making has not always been smooth. There have been times of slow progress and times of rapid development. Sometimes old ideas stayed alongside new ones. Map-makers often knew how to improve maps but had to wait for better tools. Since it was easy to copy old maps, publishers were sometimes slow to accept new ideas. Therefore, maps should not always be seen as accurate evidence of what people knew at the time. The many maps we have today show a lot of human effort and thought. They are a valuable record for studying human history. This makes the study of historical maps both interesting and educational.'

I was invited into a young man's living room. It was a nice and organized space, unlike the messy rooms around it. Moving from the kitchen to his room felt like going from economy to business class on a plane. He had the largest collection of records I had ever seen, and the first stereo record player and tuner I had come across. It was surprising to see a teenager who spent money on Georgian wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months before starting. During this time, he wanted to become England's answer to the composer Richard Rodgers. 
My own dreams were just as crazy. I wanted to be a pop star for reasons like women, money, and fame. The difference between Andrew and me was that my dreams were not as serious to me. But when Andrew suggested I try to become a famous lyricist like Oscar Hammerstein, I decided to give it a try. This was because, within ten minutes of meeting, he played me three tunes he had composed. I could tell he was very good. He played more music from shows he had written at school, reminding me of the best show albums from my parents' collection. He needed a new lyricist for the outside world. I didn't have much to impress him with, except for praising his music and a single song I had written that an unknown pop group had recorded. We promised to meet again and write something together. 
I was still more interested in pop music than in theater, but I knew I had met someone with rare talent and determination. I thought it would be a mistake not to work with him. Even if we didn't succeed in musical theater, we could try to compete with the Beatles and Rolling Stones later. The next day, back at my desk where I was training to become a lawyer, my excitement about a life in show business with Andrew had faded a bit. I would still look for groups needing a vocalist and write simple songs, but it seemed likely I would become a lawyer by the time I was twenty-five. My father predicted I would grow out of pop music by the time I was twenty-one, which worried me. But I felt I had nothing to lose by seeing Andrew again. It would be fun to write musical lyrics instead of pop songs. Andrew was interesting and talked about good food and Victorian architecture, and he supported Leyton Orient football team. 
I wasn't convinced by the musical idea he had been working on for a year, but in 1965, I was rarely convinced about anything. His talent was clear, and he said he had all the contacts. I soon returned to his living room. The idea was about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, a nineteenth-century philanthropist who founded orphanages. His story was worthy, but it didn't excite me. The hero was too perfect, and the project was not original, similar to Lionel Bart's hit show, Oliver. However, Andrew's belief in his music's brilliance was contagious and somewhat justified. What did I know about musicals? As David Land, who later became my agent, said, if there's a demand for one hamburger bar, there's room for two. We could be the second one. I started working with great enthusiasm, especially on the funny songs. Andrew explained the plot, played the tunes, and often gave me the titles, which his previous lyricist had thought of. I skipped a day at the law office, pretending to be sick, to write my first theatrical lyrics. I didn't know it then, but I had changed careers.

**Language**
Humans have a special ability: we can communicate with each other using language. Language is so important in our lives that it is hard to imagine living without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they will probably start talking. Even when alone, people often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as an 'instinct'. This means that people know how to talk naturally, just like spiders know how to spin webs. Spiders did not learn web-spinning from a teacher, and they do not need special skills to do it.
**Climate and Weather**
Climate and weather, created by the air around us, greatly affect where animals and plants live. Climate can change the look of landscapes. For example, warm and wet weather all year helps tropical jungles grow, which have many different species. On the other hand, cold and windy places have fewer living things. Weather patterns, which make up the climate over time, happen because large masses of air rise and mix. The atmosphere is always moving. Some of this movement is because the earth spins, and the air does not move as fast as the earth. The sun is another important reason for air movement.
**Coffee**
As a bar-person, I had to serve drinks and make coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I spent several days learning how to make coffee and how to clean the espresso machine. I also learned how to make a perfect cappuccino. By the end of the first week, I realized making good coffee was not easy, and I thought I might be given simpler tasks. Fortunately, my boss was patient. He said, 'Making coffee is both an art and a science, and you need time to learn it.'

**Art on TV**
Why does television often fail with programs about visual arts? Painting and sculpture should be easy for the camera to show. The camera can show a whole artwork and then zoom in to see details. But there are few TV series that show both the joy and complexity of looking at art. A good example of this problem is Robert Hughes's series, "American Visions." Hughes is a trustworthy critic with a strong personality. He had almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which British galleries often ignore. I thought the series would focus on great artworks. Instead, it was about how American history and culture are shown in its art and buildings.
**Dealing in Metals**
For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and became known as a risk-taker. Metals are less regulated than other markets. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, you can make a lot of money. Risk-taking is a big part of the industry. This adventurous culture fits well with a free-market global economy. But now, free-trade economists who said the market would keep metal prices high have found the opposite. More minerals are being extracted, and raw material costs are going down. Considering inflation, most metal prices are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a multinational company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its off-shore cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas. These islands stretch from Florida past the Tropic of Cancer to Cuba. Each island has its own personality and offers something special. To get around the islands and cays of Abaco, you need a boat. If your room doesn't include a boat, don't worry. There are many ferries and water-taxis. You can also rent a boat if you want to travel on your own. Sailing is the most popular way to travel here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for a good reason. The calm, protected waters are perfect for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The cays and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

'Build Your Own Bamboo Bike in the UK
The Bamboo Bike Club, started by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan, offers a course where you can build your own bamboo bike. Located in Hackney Wick, east London, this is the UK's only bamboo bike-building workshop. The course includes a custom-designed bike frame and a fun weekend of building.
Bamboo is becoming popular in bike construction. Companies like Calfee Design in California and Bamboo Bikes in Yorkshire have brought back this method, first used in 1894. However, their bikes are expensive, with frames costing around $2,995 or £1,868. James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes affordable for everyone. They spent years developing their idea in a shed in Wales. They realized they wanted to share the joy of making something unique and sustainable, not just sell frames.
The Bamboo Bike Club is more like a community project. James works with wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer, so they run the club alongside their full-time jobs. Their courses are popular and affordable, offering a custom bike frame and a weekend of building.
On the first day, participants learn to choose bamboo for strength and make strong joints. The frame starts with the front triangle, then the seat and chain assembly. Metal tubes are used for parts needing extra strength, like handlebars and wheel forks. James and Ian help with every step, ensuring quality.
Building the bike is part of the fun, especially for engineers. Mistakes are okay; you can try again with a new piece of bamboo. Each piece is checked for quality, and you can choose the look of your frame.
On Sunday, participants build the lugs using hemp bindings and epoxy resin for strong joints. A final coating makes the bike waterproof. The finished bike is ready for wheels, brakes, and other parts. It's as strong as metal bikes. Ian has used his for a year on a long commute, and James has tested one off-road for three months.
Bamboo bikes may look a bit rough compared to professional frames, but they are unique. They are great for a relaxed ride. I chose a 'Classic English' frame for a smooth, easy ride. Bamboo bikes are light and absorb vibrations well, making them fun to ride. The price? Less than £500.'

**Self-help Books**
Dione Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York when she found a manuscript by an unknown psychologist, Dr. John Gray. She thought the title would make it a bestseller, and she was right. Dr. Gray is now very successful, and Dione Reverend has her own company. Dr. Gray's book on communication between men and women is very popular in the self-help industry. This industry is growing and helps people who want to improve their lives. It also supports the publishing world in New York. In Britain, the self-help genre is also becoming popular, but many books are not published because they are too similar to others. Editors look for books that can sell well. Dione Reverend says that a catchy title is very important for a book's success.
**Autobiographies**
When someone writes an autobiography, there is an agreement with the reader that the truth is being told. However, writers often do not tell the whole truth. They might leave out things that are too embarrassing or not important. Sometimes, writers change the truth to make their story more interesting or to show a deeper truth. Some writers might even call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is not. This is not always done to deceive readers.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**
Detective stories became popular in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. They often show the conflicts in society. In these stories, a crime represents human desires like greed, and solving the crime shows how society can work well again. In Hammett's stories, society is shown as corrupt. The detective and the criminal understand each other. The detective is both a part of the law and a bit of a criminal. He sometimes feels connected to the criminals, and this affects his work.
**Science Writing**
Stephen Jay Gould is a well-known science writer. He believes that to write well about science, you need to understand the culture of science. Only scientists can explain science well because they know the rules. Gould advises not to simplify the argument too much when writing. You can make the language easier, but you should not treat the reader as if they are not smart. If readers feel they are being talked down to, they will lose interest.

**Air-conditioning**
At Cannons Gym in the City of London, the air feels very cold. This gym is popular with workers during lunch. To handle the very hot summer, the gym has used a lot of air-conditioning. Sometimes, it feels as cold as the Arctic inside. This is an example of how people often use too much air-conditioning. It is now a big part of work and leisure, showing how humans can control or change the climate. However, many buildings with air-conditioning could use other ways to stay cool. They could use natural light and air, and have thicker walls that keep out heat during the day and release it at night. These ideas might seem simple, but they can work well and reduce the need for air-conditioning.
**Sundials**
It is interesting that as we start a new millennium, people are again interested in sundials. Sundials are tools that tell time by the sun's position. A hundred years ago, they were important for keeping time accurately. But as clocks and watches improved, sundials became just garden decorations. Now, people are taking them seriously again. David Harber, who makes sundials, thinks they are special because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a magical moment when a sundial starts working. They are calm and romantic objects that remind us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**
I used to think china-painting was for serious, older women who painted flowers on teacups perfectly. I saw this at an arts and crafts show long ago. Their hands were steady, and the paint never smudged. I wondered who would be brave enough to take a china-painting class. Would beginners also be so talented? But the class was not scary at all. The students were there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint flowers on teacups quickly like I remembered.

**The Wrong Country**
Uncle chose a package holiday for Keith and Dawne at a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice, staying at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to the travel agency to book, the clerk said the other people in their package were a school group learning Italian. But something went wrong. Either at the travel agency, the check-in desk, or in a computer, a mistake happened. Keith and Dawne ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, in Switzerland.
At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. On the plane, they were surprised to hear people speaking with North of England accents. Keith thought maybe the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks and relaxed.
