When they arrived, a woman with glasses said, "The coach will take us on." There was no mention of an overnight stop in the brochure, but Keith thought it was part of the plan. It was almost midnight when they reached the hotel, and they were too tired to ask questions. The next morning, they realized they were staying there for the whole holiday. The receptionist said they could enjoy the lake and take a steamer to Interlaken.
Keith calmly told the receptionist there was a mistake. "We were meant to be in Venice, at the Pensione Concordia." The receptionist said he didn't know about a mistake. Dawne described the travel agency clerk who made the booking. A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they saw at Gatwick, came over. Dawne explained they were in the wrong hotel. Mrs. Franks said there are many holidays with similar tickets and labels, and sometimes people follow the wrong group.
Keith insisted they were not supposed to be in Switzerland. Mrs. Franks said she would check and left them standing there. The receptionist was gone, and they heard typing. Dawne whispered that Mrs. Franks seemed kind, but Keith was lost in thought, remembering everything that happened at the airport.
An elderly couple, Mr. and Mrs. Nottage, spoke to them. They said they had a great night's sleep because of the lakeside air. Keith and Dawne left the reception area. They didn't mention the irony of their situation: on their first holiday since their honeymoon, they ended up with a group of elderly people, when they wanted to escape the demands of the elderly. Uncle had said this when they tried to convince him to join them.

'HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON American business leaders are looking at the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a model for good management. Eluned Price reports. Many people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and have a general idea of his achievements. In America, however, he is only now becoming well-known. The Wall Street Journal called Shackleton 'an Antarctic explorer whose feats went unnoticed for most of the 20th century,' which might be an exaggeration. But now, Americans are showing great interest. Books about Shackleton's journey on the Endurance are being written and are expected to sell quickly. The American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition, and Columbia Tristar is making a film about Shackleton's life. Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They admire his actions and learn lessons in leadership and communication from his story. They even use the term 'speaking Shackleton' among themselves. Shackleton, with his reindeer sleeping bag and blubber-stove, has become an example for modern management consultants. Jim MacGregor, a managing partner at Abernathy MacGregor Frank in New York, has used Shackleton as a role model for years. His company deals with communication during mergers, acquisitions, and corporate crises. For example, when a company's plant explodes or when half the workforce must be let go. MacGregor says, 'Even if a company handles its crises well, it can still cause problems by communicating poorly.' Shackleton is a model for management because he was a great leader and communicator. He had strong values and was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, like their lives. One of Shackleton's most interesting decisions was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. This decision showed his credibility for future expeditions: the lives of his men were most important. This refers to Shackleton's 1908 expedition to the South Pole when, 97 miles short of their goal, with delays using up their supplies and limited time to return to their ship, Shackleton made the brave decision to turn back. In a crisis, MacGregor says, people want to know someone is in charge. Today, managers often avoid responsibility, but Shackleton was ready to take charge. His 1914 expedition became legendary. His ship, the Endurance, was stuck in ice for nine months and was eventually crushed. When it sank, Shackleton told his men, 'We will all reach safety if you continue to do your best and trust me.' From the diaries and accounts kept by his men, it is clear that Shackleton was always in control. 'Shackleton thought everything through, planned for every situation, kept his men informed, and asked for their opinions,' says MacGregor. 'He was adaptable, willing to start over when something was lost. We've created a set of principles here that Shackleton demonstrates. Clients can relate to his story without feeling criticized.' Shackleton believed an explorer needs optimism, physical endurance, and patience. 'One of the hardest things to do in difficult situations is to do nothing, especially in America, where people want quick solutions,' says MacGregor. 'If you buy bonds and the interest rates change, you should wait, and eventually, you'll get your money back. To "fix it" and sell would mean a big loss. Also, don't be afraid to change your plans if they're not working. If a new product is bad, don't keep selling it.' Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he saw Hurley, the expedition photographer, without gloves. He gave Hurley his own gloves, saying if he didn't wear them, he would throw them overboard. Someone else remembered him doing the same with a biscuit when they were starving on the 1905 expedition: 'He said he'd leave it in the snow. Millions of pounds couldn't have bought that biscuit.' As Caroline Alexander, author of Endurance, says: 'The public's interest in heroic efforts is growing. Shackleton shows that there is little heroism today. Everything else fades away, and he remains the true example of the ideals we long for now.'

'Finding Food in Madagascar's Forests In the forests of Madagascar, there is a primate called the aye-aye that lives like a woodpecker. Both the woodpecker and the aye-aye search for insect larvae in wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its teeth to gnaw into the wood and its long, thin third finger to scoop out the insects. Scientists have known about the aye-aye's feeding habits for over a hundred years, but only recently discovered how it finds insects inside the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied the hunting skills of two male aye-ayes, Nosferatu and Poe, a female named Samantha, and her baby, Annabelle. He tested if they found insects by looking for signs on the wood, like holes where insects might have entered. Dr. Erickson gave the aye-ayes logs with several holes. Some holes led to mealworms, while others were empty. The aye-ayes went straight to the holes with food, without needing to see the surface holes. They didn't use smell or sound to find the insects either. They could find mealworms even when the smell was blocked and when the mealworms were dead and silent. Dr. Erickson found that aye-ayes could sense empty spaces in the wood. They tap the wood with their middle finger and listen with their large ears. Dr. Erickson thinks they use echo-location, like bats, to find hollow spaces. They might also hear insects move when disturbed by the tapping. The idea that aye-ayes take the place of woodpeckers in Madagascar is interesting. However, there are birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that also look for insects in wood, so the woodpecker role might not be empty. The aye-aye is like a woodpecker and an echo-locating bat combined. It also acts like a squirrel because its teeth grow continuously, and it can gnaw through nut shells to get the nut inside.'

**Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives**
Most of us have photos of our grandparents, but do we know what their lives were like when they were young? Diaries and family stories often don't tell us everything. And what will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write things down but never do. We might leave videos instead of photos, but they still don't tell the whole story.
Hannah Renier has a solution: she writes autobiographies for other people. She creates a book of at least 20,000 words, with pictures if wanted, about ordinary people, not famous ones. The idea came to her when she talked to her family and realized how much of the past was being forgotten. "When I started, I didn't take it as seriously as I do now," she says. "People say they do it for their children or for the future, but they also enjoy it themselves."
The promise of privacy helps people be honest. A 62-year-old man who made and lost a fortune said, "I was surprised at what came out. There were painful things, like my divorce." He did it for his family, but hasn't let his children read it yet. He thinks they might learn something, but he prefers they read it after he is gone.
Ms. Renier notices that many people repeat patterns from their childhood. "It's amazing how parents influence their children," she says. "People often marry someone their parents would like, or the opposite as a rebellion." Many people still feel disappointed about things with their parents, even 60 years later.
Ms. Renier is more of a recorder than an investigator. "It's not for the public, and I'm not there to be nosy," she says. People sometimes share things and then wonder if it should be included. She includes it, but they can remove it later. Most people want to be honest.
"It's not about showing off," she says. "Things are changing fast, and we are losing touch with the past. This is a way to connect with our ancestors." Each book takes about 30 hours of interviews, which Ms. Renier uses to write the life story. Modern technology helps her produce everything except the book cover. The books are not cheap, costing nearly £3,000, with extra copies at £25 each. She gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the cost stops many people. "I thought it would be more affordable," she says. "But the people I've worked with are often wealthy, the kind who would have had portraits painted for their descendants."

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has one of the few collections of Greek and Roman sculpture casts in the world, with over six hundred pieces. Remember, nothing here is original. All sculptures are accurate copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is in a special gallery with great natural light. Plaster casts have many benefits: sculptures that were originally together but are now in different museums across Europe can be seen together here. You can see almost all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in one afternoon.
**B. Cambridge Darkroom**
Cambridge Darkroom is a photography center with community darkrooms and a gallery showing different photography exhibitions. We often run courses and workshops for all ages and skill levels, including a Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that allows members to use our darkrooms. We also help young photographers (aged 12 to 16) improve their skills with our Young Members program, led by our resident photographer. We sell photographic books, magazines, and materials.
**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**
The Sedgwick Museum has a great collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all over the world and from all geological ages. It also has Britain's oldest complete geological collection, made by Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728). It includes nearly 10,000 rare and interesting items in their original early 18th-century cabinets. Adam Sedgwick, a Professor of Geology, added a lot to the collections, creating an outstanding museum. The collection is organized by geological age, showing major changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays beautiful minerals and gems, with labels explaining their nature and modern use.
**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**
There are over 400,000 air photographs in the collection, taken by university staff over the past 45 years. The University has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and takes photos throughout Great Britain. The photos are interesting as they show the landscape and human activity from prehistoric times to now. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the library staff can help with questions. The photos cannot be borrowed, but copies can be bought. These are made to order and usually take about a month.
**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running center of its kind in the world. It is a unique tourist attraction. You can enjoy making wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The center has made resin copies, called facsimiles, to preserve the originals and make brass rubbing accessible to everyone. Brass plates, used as memorials instead of statues, spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many were destroyed in revolutions, but most of the remaining brasses are in Britain, and the widest range can be seen at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Fatherhood**
**A. The Theatre Director**
I have had 35 years of small children because of my unusual personal life, and I have loved every minute. I fed the baby this morning, and for me, that is what being a father is all about. I am very lucky with my children. We all love the same things: opera, theatre, books, music. This creates a strong bond, especially now that they are mostly grown up, and I have become more of a friend than a father. I don't believe in physical violence. I have slapped my children in anger, but I don't support it. I may not have been a very attentive father, but I have always tried to be available. I am here if they need me, but I let them call me. If you start chasing them to ask why they haven't been in touch, you make them feel guilty. My parents did that to me, and I would never do it to my children.
**B. The Advertising Executive**
I was young when my children were born, only about 25, and I found the responsibilities difficult. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I value. As they became teenagers, they introduced me to things I might have forgotten: music, youth culture, clothes. This has been very helpful for running the agency. I have never felt out of touch. When they were young, I was busy with my business, so I missed some things like their first concerts and sports days. I am sad about that, but now I can take them on holidays to the south of France. They get along well with our friends and come to parties and advertising awards with us without feeling shy. I think it helps that I do something they find glamorous and interesting.
**C. The Politician**
My first child was born just as I was about to be elected to the Greater London Council, and the others came soon after. My wife and I promised to make time for them, but as I became more politically active, time became a problem. I only accept weekend meetings and public events where my kids can come with me. This way, they know what I do when I am not with them, and there is no feeling of Daddy disappearing. I have noticed more MPs bringing their kids to the House. Maybe we are all realizing the need to involve our children in our lives.
**D. The Writer**
My first marriage ended when Kate and Bonnie were young, so I had to think a lot about being a father. I tried hard to stay in touch with them. My ex-wife and I even lived next door to each other for a while, so the kids could come and go as they wanted, but I think they found that confusing. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I am not sure I was a very good father. I was around a lot, but like many parents in the Seventies, I treated the kids as adults too soon. Kate recently said we were too liberal. I think I could have been more organized. Instead, I was very relaxed. I regret that now. I still worry about my older daughters as much as I do about my youngest. In that way, your kids never leave you.
**E. The TV Presenter**
I was ready for kids. I was 30, met my wife, and we had a lovely house, so we thought, "Why keep buying new sofas when we could have a kid instead?" Having my daughter Betty has made me understand who I am. You feel special when you have a child, and you are. But you also become just one more parent in a long line of parents. It's a great equalizer. I sometimes feel annoyed, but one look at her takes that away. A baby's smile is the best way to make a grown man feel better.

**THEATRE GUIDE**
**A. Tamburlaine the Great**  
This is a play by Marlowe about a powerful warrior. It is very long, but in Terry Hands' version, it is exciting and fast. Antony Sher plays the main role and is very energetic, doing stunts like somersaulting and sliding down a rope. He captures the audience's attention with his performance.  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
**B. Women Laughing**  
This play by Michael Wall was first shown in Manchester. It starts with two married couples talking in a garden, creating a tense feeling. Later, it becomes a touching story about illness. Michael Wall was a talented writer who died young.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*
**C. Amphibians**  
Billy Roche, an Irish playwright, tells a story about the decline of the fishing industry in Wexford. The play has strong characters, deep emotions, and funny moments. It can be a bit slow but ends powerfully.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
**D. Murder by Misadventure**  
This is a classic thriller about 'the perfect murder'. Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play writers who want to kill each other. The story is familiar but has clever twists.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*
**E. The Alchemist**  
Director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's comedy about tricksters. The play was first shown in Stratford and is now at the Barbican. The actors give great performances as the con-artists.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
**F. The Madras House**  
Peter James directs this comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society. It was successful in Edinburgh and is now in London. The play is stylish and well-acted.  
*Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)*
**G. Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn is a modern version of Beauty and the Beast set in London. It has beautiful music and celebrates romantic love. It is a charming show.  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*
**H. The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's version of Shakespeare's comedy is not very good, but it has excellent comic performances by Ron Cook and Anton Lesser. Most of the other actors seem uncomfortable.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
**I. The Voysey Inheritance**  
This play by Granville Barker is about a lawyer who leaves a corrupt financial legacy to his son. It is a great play and is now touring.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Hide and Seek** by Yvonne Coppard  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game. They are watching a strange bookshop. Emma sees her Uncle Jim there. He tricks her into a world of lies and crime, using her love for him. He tries to turn her against her friends. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes very exciting. She is trapped in the basement of an old house. This book shows family life, childhood friendship, and warns that adults are not always protectors. A must-read.
**Backtrack** by Peter Hunt  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, discover that their relatives were involved in a mysterious train accident in 1915, where eight people died. They work together to find out what happened. The story uses different viewpoints and documents like maps and first-hand accounts. It is a clever and complex novel that needs careful reading.
**Pigeon Summer** by Ann Turnbull  
Mary Dyer does not fit into her family or her male-dominated culture. She loves her father's racing pigeons. When he leaves to find work, Mary takes care of the pigeons and wins prizes, even though she argues with her stressed mother. Set in 1930, this story shows that there are different kinds of cleverness. Thoughtful readers will enjoy it.
**Yaxley's Cat** by Robert Westall  
Robert Westall tells a chilling story through the eyes of a mature woman. Rose rents Sepp Yaxley's cottage to escape her materialistic life. She finds a fierce cat and strange items in the house, which reveal why Yaxley disappeared. The locals become hostile, and Rose's family is in danger. The violence is controlled, but Rose is upset by her son's ruthlessness. A gripping read.
**Someone's Mother is Missing** by Harry Mazer  
Sam is from the poor side of the family and is impressed by his rich cousin, Lisa. When Lisa's world falls apart, Sam helps her find balance. They both learn about reality and the value of family. The story is slow in parts but has gentle humor. The growing friendship between Sam and Lisa is well done. It is interesting for both boys and girls.
**Stanley's Aquarium** by Barry Faville  
Barry Faville writes with humor and sets the story in New Zealand. Robbie works as a gardener for Stanley. At first, Robbie finds Stanley interesting, but later he is repelled. When Robbie discovers what Stanley keeps in his aquarium, the story becomes a thriller. It is unusual and compelling.
**Dodger** by Libby Gleeson  
This is a sad story about Mick's troubled relationships and school life. The story is told through flashbacks, a teacher's letters, Mick's notes, and a narrative. Mick learns to deal with others' low expectations and his own self-worth through a school play and a caring teacher. Highly recommended, though it is a tough read, especially at the end.

**Science Defying Gravity**
Journalist Tom Mumford joins students testing their ideas in weightlessness. From the outside, it looked like a normal aircraft. The pilot told the young passengers it was a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, built in 1964, similar to a Boeing 707. But inside, it was different. The 13 students from Europe and America were about to have an amazing flight. Inside, it was a long white tunnel with few windows, lit by lights along the padded walls. Most seats were removed, except a few at the back, where the nervous students sat. For a year, they competed with other students to join this flight. The European Space Agency challenged them to suggest creative experiments in weightless conditions. The best ideas won a place on this special flight, like a wild roller-coaster ride. For two hours, the Boeing would fly like a giant bird, going up and down. At the top of each curve, the pilot cut the engines at 3,000 meters. The plane went higher by its own momentum before gravity pulled it down again. In those few seconds, everything inside became weightless, and the students felt closer to the moon than Earth.
The aircraft took off smoothly, but soon the pilot made it climb at a 45-degree angle for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, blood rushed from our heads, and bodies floated in the cabin. Then the engines stopped, and we were weightless almost instantly. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence. The floor felt like a trampoline, and one step sent us towards the ceiling. We floated aimlessly; directions like left or right, up or down, no longer made sense. Gravity helps us understand where we are. After ten seconds of freefall, the pilot pulled the plane out of its dive. Gravity returned suddenly, and some students landed with a bump. After the first curve, some students felt sick thinking about the 29 more to come. Thirty curves gave ten minutes of 'space time' for experiments. Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats always land on their feet. They used a device to turn it belly-down with radio control. During another curve, a student accidentally landed on it. Nearby, a German team from the University of Aachen studied how metal joins are affected by no gravity, thinking about future space stations. Students from Utah State University tested making solar sails from thin liquid films in microgravity. They believe these sails could use the sun's radiation like a yacht uses the wind.
After two hours of flying between heaven and Earth, breakfast felt unstable, but the main feeling was excitement, not sickness. This feeling would last a long time. "It was an unforgettable experience," said one student. "I wanted to become an astronaut before, but now I want to even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**
Jonathon Porritt is the author of "Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology." He talks to Danny Danziger about his experiences in New Zealand.
I had a unique time in my life when I didn't experience any summers. I traveled to New Zealand every summer from here, which is winter in New Zealand. So, I had nine winters in a row. I enjoyed it because I like winter. My parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, "If you plant trees on it, you can have it." This way, we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which was nice since my father grew up there. They found land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land wasn't very good, but it was suitable for planting trees.
I have always been interested in land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing different farming jobs. So, the idea of planting trees sounded nice, and I was excited. My family became enthusiastic as we continued. We started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, we had planted the whole 70 acres.
In 1968, it rained a lot in New Zealand. It was a very happy time, even though it rained almost every day we were planting. I don't think I've ever been wetter or colder for so long. Every morning, we had to prepare for planting. We would get out of the Land Rover, warm and dry, but the rain would start, and our clothes were still wet from the day before. Our boots were soaked, and our hands struggled with slippery laces.
In the first year, I worked with an experienced tree-planter, which was helpful since I had never planted trees seriously before. You carry a planting bag around your neck filled with as many trees as possible. When the bag is full, it's difficult, but it gets easier as it gets lighter. The hardest part was getting the lines straight. You decide the spacing for the trees, line up three poles, and plant along the line. I enjoy hard physical work, and it made me fit. After a while, you plant trees almost automatically, finding a rhythm and using the fewest spade strokes needed to dig a hole. This rhythm is common in many farming jobs. You develop a regular process: take the tree from the bag, dig a hole, plant it, stamp it in, and move on.
Mentally, it was interesting. My mind started thinking about life and the natural world. Many ideas that have influenced my life began during those days. I've returned to New Zealand four times since then to see the trees grow, which is satisfying. I feel a connection to what happens to them. I worry when I read about storms or droughts in New Zealand. But the trees are now 20 years old and doing well.
In 1984, I took a break from teaching and went back to New Zealand alone for three months. I wrote my first book, "Seeing Green," there. I stayed in a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, table, and chair. I wrote in the mornings, pruned trees in the afternoons, and did research in the evenings. The connection between me and that area is still very strong. It's the place where I feel most connected to the earth.

**Bringing Up Badgers**
"What now?" I thought when a helper handed me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I have an open farm in Somerset, where we care for orphaned animals. The noise from the box was strange, like a mix between a laugh and a bark. Inside, I found three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their fur was soft like velvet, and they had milky eyes. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between January and March and stay underground. If they lose their mother, they often die from hunger. These cubs were found by builders who accidentally destroyed their home. The mother was dead, and the cubs were still with her. They were healthy but cold and crying. After cleaning them, I placed them by the stove for warmth. There were two females, Primrose and Bluebell, and a male, Willow. I fed them with a syringe and used a warm cloth to mimic their mother licking them, which helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, they ate every four hours. Soon, they drank from a bottle and moved around a bit. They seemed happy with each other and a heated pad as a substitute for their mother.
Three weeks later, Willow seemed tired but still ate normally. I didn't realize it was a warning sign, and the next morning, he was dead. The vet said he died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding, it's important not to let the animal drink too fast, or liquid can go into the lungs. This caused Willow's infection, which was hard to treat. I was sad but continued caring for the others. Six days later, a local farmer brought me another male cub, abandoned by its mother. He was cold and hungry, so we named him Willow II. He was about two weeks younger than the females and difficult to feed. I had to move the bottle around in his mouth to get him to drink. After a while, he would finally drink as if he hadn't all day.
By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and other foods. Willow II was different. He gave up the bottle but struggled to eat without making a mess. Eventually, I gave him a sausage, which he slowly ate. After a week of sausages, he was ready for other foods. At nearly five months old, they all ate cereals for breakfast, meat and vegetables for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, eggs, and seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat earthworms, beetles, bugs, and small animals. My badgers were lucky because the summer was very hot, making it hard to find earthworms.
By August, the cubs became more active at night. We often walked through the orchard, where they played and chased each other. Derek joined us sometimes but didn't learn to avoid their playful bites. During these walks, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely looking for food, as badgers are territorial and can be aggressive. We were warned they might attack our cubs, so we made their pen more secure. The local press took pictures of me with the badgers, and we started a project to build a home for them on the farm. With help, we designed a sett with tunnels and a viewing area. As it took shape, the badgers explored it and eventually moved in. The cost was high, but a local bus company and other businesses helped. Everyone wanted the badgers to have a home.
One evening, they moved into their new home. I checked on them later and saw them sleeping peacefully. Now, I don't walk with them as often because they are active late at night. We see Primrose sometimes, as she joined another group, but Bluebell and Willow II still greet us before heading out. This is their territory now, a place they know well and have accepted as home.

**In search of true north - and the man behind Halley's comet**
Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow Sir Edmund Halley's journey to study compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.
Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his important achievements was to map the 'variations of the compass' during his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. These variations, now called 'declination', are the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without knowing this, sailors could not correct their compasses, making it hard to find longitude and navigate the oceans.
Halley, one of the few people paid to do scientific research at that time, sailed to the Cape Verde Islands to map declination in the North and South Atlantic. The trip was stopped early because of problems with the crew, but Halley tried again. This time, he traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From these travels, Halley published a map in 1701 showing compass variations in the Western and Southern Oceans. This map was very useful to sailors for over a century until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made it less accurate.
Dr. Clark, who loves sailing, plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by following the Paramore's route. He needs to raise £70,000 for the trip, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, known for leading the first cross-Antarctica expedition, is supporting him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about the scientist's life. Halley was not only an astronomer but also did research in geophysics and led expeditions. He even helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica.
Dr. Clark believes recreating the voyage will give Halley the recognition he deserves. The new expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. It will involve taking measurements like Halley did, but with more accurate tools. These measurements are important because the Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The data will help improve the international geomagnetic reference field, a model of Earth's magnetic field.
Dr. Clark explains that measuring the direction of the magnetic field requires knowing true north, which they can find using global positioning satellites. The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments for the expedition. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his data will fill any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean.
Halley's Atlantic journey was the first scientific sea expedition, and he was the first civilian naval captain focused on declination. Dr. Clark has the experience needed for this journey, having spent two years in Antarctica and worked in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey. He has also sailed from Rio de Janeiro to England. The expedition will have four stages with different crews.
Dr. Clark is willing to dedicate eight months to this project, showing his passion for Halley's work. He says, "Halley, and his fascinating life, have given me a real sense of purpose."

**Power Dressing Every Summer**
Every summer, peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tails to the female peahens. This display is a mystery that puzzled Charles Darwin. In a world where animals compete to survive, how did peacocks evolve such extravagant tails? Darwin thought that animals evolved through natural selection, meaning the strongest and smartest survive. But the peacock's tail seemed to be a problem, not a help. So, Darwin suggested another idea called 'sexual selection.' He believed females chose males for their beauty.
Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different idea. He thought that if peahens chose the most beautiful males, there must be a good reason. Maybe these males had other qualities that helped them survive. Today, scientists like Marion Petrie are studying peacocks at Whipsnade to find answers. They want to know if peahens really choose the males with the best tails and if these males have other advantages.
Observations show that peahens do prefer males with more eye-spots on their tails. But it's still unclear if these males are better in other ways. Some scientists think that showy males might be healthier and have fewer parasites. Dr. Petrie is comparing the offspring of attractive and less attractive males to see if the attractive ones have healthier children.
There is another idea called 'Fisher's Runaway,' proposed by R.A. Fisher. It suggests that if females start choosing males with slightly better tails, over time, this preference will grow. This could lead to peacocks having such long tails, supporting Darwin's idea of 'beauty for beauty's sake.'

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**
Tom Cunliffe believes the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He did this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of modern yachts with new technology. Most of these yachts are based on a design change from 25 years ago. My boat, however, is different. It sits quietly on a tidal creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it could be 100 years old. Some might think I am a romantic dreamer, but I don't think so. My boat uses old boat design ideas, but modern technology made it easier to build.
Modern technology is important in boat design and building, but it can also make sailing too easy. Many people go to sea to experience the challenges of sailing. I don't think sailors should suffer, but I like my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable beds. If every sail works automatically, why go sailing? Sometimes, dealing with the sails is part of the fun. Also, why move the steering from the back to the middle of the boat? This change makes more room inside, but I think a boat should feel like a boat, not a house.
I once had a boat called Hirta, which I used to sail around Britain for a TV race. The previous owner said it had comfort but no luxury. Hirta had heavy sails, no electric water pump, no fridge, no central heating, and no electronics, but it was the nicest boat I ever sailed. However, old boats need a lot of care. After I hurt my back, I had to sell Hirta. I couldn't find a new boat I liked, so I decided to build one.
The Westerman has been great. Nigel Irens, the designer, and Ed Burnett, his assistant, used computers to help design it, but Nigel first drew it on a napkin. He then made a model, like in the old days. We looked at the model and made changes on the computer. The final design was perfect. The Westerman has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of six races. It looks timeless, sails well, and feels peaceful inside. It was designed as a sailing boat, not a floating house. This shows that you don't need to follow trends to be happy. Built with treated wood, it is waterproof like a fiberglass boat but feels like a traditional one.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**
Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.
**A. HENLOW GRANGE**
I was happy to visit Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big 18th-century house was very comfortable. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined many classes like yoga and body conditioning. The instructors are very good, and I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments like aromatherapy, seaweed baths, and facials. The staff are friendly and professional. Henlow is planning to add a new swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles or walk in the garden. During my stay, I felt better and more energetic. I want to visit again. This is a great break for a stressed working woman. Save Room 5 for me! - Marcella D'Argy Smith
**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**
The calm atmosphere of this stately home was clear from the moment I arrived. The Hall has a beautiful library and conservatory. On arrival, everyone gets a medical check-up. We were called patients, which was strange because I am healthy. They found a shoulder problem during my check-up, and we worked on it in fitness classes. Each person gets a special diet. I lost weight but felt hungry and had a headache on the second day. My meals included grapefruit, salads, and fruit with yoghurt. If you are not on a diet, you eat in the main dining hall where the food is tasty. You get a massage or water therapy every other day. Extra treatments are well-priced. - Liz Gregory
**C. CAREYS MANOR**
Careys is not a health farm. It is a lovely old manor with log fires and a big lounge. If you are watching your weight, you might skip the gourmet food. The French chef makes rich sauces and desserts. The hotel has a gym and pool to help burn calories. There is also a spa bath, steam room, and treatment rooms. A big attraction is the sports injury clinic. I got advice on my shoulder injury. Careys is comfortable and luxurious. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside around. - Beverly D'Silva
**D. CLIVEDEN**
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, swimming pool, tennis, and horse riding. There are beautiful walks and gardens. Waldo's restaurant has amazing food. The dinner menu is long, and the meal was wonderful. I enjoyed a facial and an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden has fitness assessments and beauty treatments if you want them. - Kay Letch
**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is delicious but high in calories. The aromatherapy massage is also great. I chose relaxing oils and had a good night's sleep. The place is modern with many facilities and luxurious rooms. There are many therapists, so it is easy to get appointments. They offer treatments like manicures and facials. Guests include football teams, families, and friends. I would like to visit once a month. - Eve Cameron

**NATURAL TALENTS**
In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we haven't changed much genetically. We are still more than 98% the same as chimps. On a big evolutionary scale, what makes humans different from animals is a recent change. Our ability to make art and do other human things must come from a small part of our genes. This is a lot to expect from just a few genes. 
Studies of animal behavior show that many things we thought were only human are not. For example, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools. Chimpanzees use sticks as tools, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have simple language with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. These findings show that there are few absolute differences between us and animals, except for art.
If human art comes from a special genetic gift, it's strange that our ancestors didn't use it for most of the 7 million years since they split from chimps. The first art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but we can't know because those materials don't last. Clear evidence of human art, like cave paintings and statues, only appears around 35,000 years ago with the Cro-Magnons.
If we say our recent creativity sets us apart, how is our art different from animal art? Three differences are often mentioned: human art is not useful, it's made for beauty, and it's learned, not instinctive.
First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." Human art doesn't help us survive or pass on genes, unlike most animal behaviors. For example, birdsong helps defend territory or attract mates, which helps pass on genes. By this measure, human art is different.
Second, human art is said to be motivated by aesthetic pleasure. We can't ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during breeding season, so they probably don't sing just for pleasure. Again, human art seems unique.
Third, human art is learned, not instinctive. Each human group has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are different, but people can learn each other's songs. Some birds, however, inherit their songs and would sing them even if they never heard them. It's like a French baby raised in Japan singing the French national anthem without learning it.
The role of learning in human art is clear in how quickly styles change. Geese honked 2,000 years ago as they do today, but human art changes fast. Even a casual museum visitor can tell a 20th-century painting from the Mona Lisa. Experts can often identify when and who painted a work. However, they might mistake the works of two mid-20th-century artists, Congo and Betsy, who were actually chimpanzees. Congo made up to 33 paintings in one day and got upset when his pencil was taken away. Their paintings were shown in 1957 at London's Institute of Contemporary Art, and most were sold, which many human artists can't claim.
These paintings by chimps blur the lines between human art and animal activities. Like human art, the ape paintings had no practical use and were made for the painter's satisfaction. You might say human art is different because it's meant to communicate, but some famous human art was also made for personal satisfaction.

**A Big Adventure**
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on earth. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and survived to tell his story. There are not many big adventures left and not many heroes. Children's stories used to be about brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes looking far into the distance on their journeys into the unknown. Today, you don't find such people in stories or real life. Or so I thought until I met Charles Blackmore.
Blackmore's great adventure was leading a team across the Taklamakan Desert in western China. Its name means 'once entered you never come out', but local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that amazing journey at his family home. The team he led included four Britons (one was the medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts on the area, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have been very dangerous and could have ruined the expedition.
This group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the world's least friendly desert, and Charles Blackmore wrote an interesting account of their journey. At the time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, to prove something. 'I always thought I'd spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to see who Charles Blackmore really was, outside all that. It was a big risk. Tina, my wife, was very worried that I wouldn't come back because nobody had ever done that route; we went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very kind to us.'
Anyone reading his story of that crossing will wonder why he used the word 'kind'. The team suffered many hardships: dysentery, extreme temperatures, severe thirst and dehydration, and the loss of part of their precious water supply. 'But', Blackmore explains, 'when we were at the limits of our endurance and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we managed to find some. We didn't experience the Taklamakan's legendary sandstorms. And we never faced the raw, biting desert cold that would have stopped us completely. That's not to say that we weren't fighting against challenges the whole time. The fine sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. The high dunes were very hard to climb, for us and for the heavily loaded camels, which often rolled over onto us.
'What drove me on more than anything else was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Neither our budget nor time allowed one. No aircraft ever flew over us. Once we got into the sandhills, we were completely on our own. 'I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared of my physical ability to do it. I remember day one -- we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that you couldn't breathe. I thought, "We've got to do it now!" At that moment, I was a very scared man.'
If it was like that at the beginning, how did they feel towards the end? 'When you've walked for 1,000 kilometers, you're not going to give up. You've endured so much; you've got so much behind you. We were very thin, but very muscular and strong despite our physical exhaustion. My body was well-toned, and my legs were like pistons. I could walk over anything.'
Midway through the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon, thinking of his family. How aware was he of the ordeal it must have been for them? 'Inside me, there's someone trying to find peace with himself. When I have doubts about myself now, I go back to the image of the desert and think, well, we managed to pull that together. As a personal achievement, I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I've done. Yet in terms of a lifetime's achievement, I think of my family and the happiness we share -- against that measure, the desert does not compare.'
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? 'I yearn for the challenge -- for the open spaces -- the resolve of it all. We were lifted by the sense of purpose. I find it difficult now to be part of the sameness of modern life.'

Susan Harr decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us gadgets that make life easier and save time. But Susan thinks we might be too dependent on technology. She had a bad experience with her broken word processor, which was expensive to fix. This made her question if gadgets are worth the trouble and cost. 
Susan started letting her household gadgets go when they stopped working. She wonders if technology really gives us more time or just makes us buy more gadgets. When her sewing machine broke, she decided to sew by hand. She found it relaxing and enjoyable. She can sew while listening to the radio or talking with family and friends. 
Susan also returned her rented color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. This change made her family spend more time walking the dog, reading, and talking. She realized that doing things by hand, like sewing, can be satisfying and calming. It slows down life and gives her time to think. 
Now, Susan looks around her house and wonders if she really needs things like the freezer, microwave oven, or electric lights. She thinks she could save money by living with fewer gadgets.

'The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst makes a living from making beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. Charles Hurst seems like a man who is always busy. When I arrive at his workshop in East London, he greets me quickly and says, 'Well, fire away then!' It's not clear if he is really in a hurry or just a bit shy. But when you look around his workshop, you can see he is very busy. The workshop is full of half-made furniture and pieces of wood in many natural colors. Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has a great reputation. His schedule is always full for months, even though he doesn't advertise. People know that if you want a good cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen units, Hurst is the person to go to. Finding a furniture-maker is not hard, but finding one who makes beautiful, simple furniture is not easy. 'There are few real cabinet-makers now. People call themselves furniture-makers,' Hurst says. He is disappointed by some modern furniture. 'I am amazed by what some furniture-makers get away with, and saddened by what people will put up with.' He doesn't like cheap, mass-produced furniture and craftsmen who make poor-quality pieces. Hurst's search for perfection and his talent are keys to his success. He is confident about his skills. 'I have a huge natural ability,' he says. 'I have always been good at making things.' Hurst is self-taught. How did he learn? 'I asked the right questions and picked it all up,' he says. Most of his work comes from private clients. Some clients come back many times. 'You end up doing the whole of their house. That is very satisfying.' But he admits that working with clients is not always easy. 'The most annoying clients are those who don't know what they want, and then decide they do when it's too late ... my favorite clients are the exacting ones.' Hurst is happy with his work but also praises others when they deserve it. 'There are people far better than me. I can admire other people. After all, I wasn't trained at Parnham' (a top furniture design school). He is critical of craftsmen who 'are trying to be artists and take a year to make one piece.' He also doesn't like degree shows where students try to make fashion statements. 'A piece of furniture is not about making a statement. It has to be something that people really can use.' Hurst is confident but not pretentious. As I leave, he says, 'After all, I am only making furniture.'

'Three ideas about why we sleep People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This shows that sleep is very important. But, why do we sleep? Scientists do not fully agree on the reason. There are three main ideas. The first and most popular idea is that sleep is mainly for our body. It says we sleep to keep our body healthy. While we sleep, our body fixes any damage from the day and makes us ready for the next day. The second idea focuses on learning. It says sleep helps us process information we learn during the day. Without sleep, we would not learn well. The third idea is about energy. It says we need sleep to recharge our energy, like recharging a battery, so we have enough energy for the next day.'

**Eccentrics**
An eccentric is someone whose behavior is different from what is normal. They do not follow the usual rules of society. This makes us ask, "What is normal?" Many of us have our own little habits. It could be entering newspaper competitions, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to the press about many topics. Eccentricity is about being unique. Inside us, there is a struggle between wanting to be different and wanting to fit in. It's like having two trains pushing against each other on the same track. One train is called individualism, and the other is conformity. For most people, conformity is stronger. We want to be accepted, loved, and feel like we belong. This is stronger than wanting to stand out and be different.
People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often find others like them. They form clubs and have meetings to share their interests. They want to find others who understand them. Even a small group can make them feel better. We all feel a pull between being unique and fitting in. We might say we are different, like when someone at a bar says, "I say what I think," or when a new person says, "You must take me as you find me."
Anyone can choose to be more individual. Many successful people have done this. For example, Bob Dylan, an American singer, said, "When you feel in your gut what you are doing and then pursue it, don't back down and don't give up." But being different on purpose is not the same as being eccentric. If a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention or a hostess says shocking things to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. If they keep doing these things until they can't go back to normal behavior, then they might be eccentric.
The key to being eccentric is being natural. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they just are. They do not care about what others think. They do what they do because of who they are. This makes them different from enthusiasts, practical jokers, criminals, exhibitionists, and recluses. These people are aware of the world and react to it. Some want to impress society, and some want to escape it, but they are aware of it. Eccentrics, however, continue on their own path without concern for society.

**Natural Books**
We asked four naturalists to tell us about the wildlife book that influenced them the most.
**A. Geoffrey Lean**
Choosing the author was easy. As an environmental journalist, I have met many important people in the field. None impressed me more than Barbara Ward, a small, frail woman who was central to environmental issues in post-war Europe. She combined her experiences into a strong philosophy. As a young journalist, she helped me understand the field. Choosing the book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But "The Home of Man" is, to me, her most important book. It talks about the rapid growth of cities and the big themes she cared about. It is a powerful call for what we now call 'sustainable human development.' I have not found another book like it.
**B. Linda Bennett**
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can imagine the sounds and smells of a herring gull colony. This book explains animal communication with words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony changes from chaos to an organized social structure. You can see which birds are partners and recognize families. Niko Tinbergen was a great behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. He worked with Eric Ennion, a talented wildlife artist, to create this book. Ennion's paintings, with simple lines and colors, show how one gull is aggressive and another is peaceful. This is the work of a true field naturalist.
**C. Lee Durrell**
"My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell is the book that influenced me the most. It led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation. This book defined my love for the natural world. I was researching animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. I was facing many challenges, but reading this book made my world brighter. It shows animals, people, joy, and beauty all connected. Many say humans are the worst because of the harm we cause, but I remember Gerald as a boy, seeing the world as a family. This is a concept we all need to understand.
**D. Bruce Pearson**
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library after it was published in 1966. I was drawn to the 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion. I already had other bird books and spent holidays learning to identify birds. They encouraged me to sketch birds to help with identification. But "The Shell Bird Book" offered more. It had chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and birds in music, literature, and art. This wide range of information and exciting images made me appreciate birds and nature more broadly. The book showed me that my emotional and creative response to nature was as valid as a scientific one. Since art was my strong subject, I saw new opportunities for myself.

'DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS? We asked five top British publishers about how book reviews affect sales. Here is what they said. Publisher A Reviews are very important for publishers. The Book Marketing Council found that more people buy books because of reviews than for other reasons like ads or word of mouth. Authors and publishers both dislike getting no reviews, but publishers are usually calmer about bad reviews. They think that any review, good or bad, can help sales because readers want to decide for themselves. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own opinion of the book. Publisher B Publishers and the press both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books reviewed positively. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but paperbacks are often ignored. Publishers need reviews because they help make a book and author known. A good review by a trusted person can increase sales, especially if there are many reviews. Fame helps sell books. Publisher C Reviews are very important for literary publishing. We publish books by authors who are not famous, so we rely on reviews. Good reviews are more valuable than ads because they are seen as honest. Reviews can help sell books, but they need to work with other things like word of mouth and good marketing. Publisher D In Britain, the link between publishing and reviews is unclear. In the US, a review in the New York Times can greatly affect a book's success. In Britain, bookshops often don't pay much attention to reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years of good reviews for a writer to become popular. Some poorly reviewed books sell very well. Non-fiction reviews often focus more on the reviewer's knowledge than the book itself. Publisher E All publishers and writers want long, positive reviews. But do they sell books? I once published a biography with great reviews, but it didn't sell well because people felt they didn't need to buy it after reading the reviews. The reviewer's name used to matter more, but now it's the surprise choice of reviewer or the quality of the review that attracts buyers.'

'WEATHERVANE MAKER Making weathervanes is a very old skill, starting in ancient Egypt. Today, this craft is still alive in Graham Smith's workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who make weathervanes by hand. Graham creates special designs for each customer. 'This way, I can make a unique and personal item,' he says. 'Many of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want a special gift that shows the man's work or hobbies.' This is different from the usual cockerel design, which is the most common for weathervanes. Graham's first weathervane was not a cockerel but a witch on a broomstick. He made it as a surprise gift for his wife. Friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. 'I saw that there are endless ideas for weathervanes,' he says. Graham decided to focus on a weathervane business. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, decided to switch roles. She went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to care for the children and grow the business. That was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. 'My old job was not artistic, but this is exciting and creative,' he says. 'I really enjoy designing.' Graham has now made over 100 original designs. He works with great detail and always gets the customer's approval before cutting the design by hand. Graham also keeps many traditional designs in stock because they are as popular as the custom ones. 'People like hand-made things,' Graham says. 'They like to have something a bit different.' Graham does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a small craft. 'I have found my place in the market. People love the unique items, and I enjoy turning a simple shape into something almost lifelike,' he says. 'For centuries, weathervanes have helped people understand the weather by showing wind direction changes,' he explains. 'Now, more people are moving to the countryside, and they want a special touch for their homes. This has helped crafts like mine.' Graham is now very busy, sending flat-packed weathervanes to clients around the world. American and Danish buyers are especially interested. 'The price,' he explains, 'depends on how detailed the design is.' His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can create a unique gift.'

**Beginner Takes All**
Before it was published, *The Horse Whisperer* was already a very popular book. It is the first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans, and it has made him a lot of money. Here, he talks about his inspiration and success.
At the start of the year, things were not going well for Nicholas Evans. He is a screenwriter, producer, and wants to be a director. His year started badly when a film project called *Life and Limb*, which he had worked on for months, suddenly failed. He was worried because he hadn't earned any money for two years, and this film was his only hope to pay the bank. 
Instead of finding a job, Evans made a surprising decision. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel for three months. The idea for the story came from a farrier he met on Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became wild. Its owners were desperate until they found a gypsy who calmed the horse just by talking to it. These men were called 'horse whisperers'. Evans was fascinated and started researching to write a screenplay. But after *Life and Limb* failed, he decided to write a book instead.
In the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. He felt alone and worried about his future. By August, he had written half of the book and showed it to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent thought it was "fine" and said Evans might get $30,000 for it. Evans needed more money to pay his debts and support his family. He was advised to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book.
In October, the first 200 pages and the summary were sent to seven UK publishers before the Frankfurt Book Fair. Soon, his agent called to say he had turned down an offer of $75,000. The book was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for $550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. Evans was shocked by the success. 
Hollywood studios also wanted the book. Evans' UK agent worked with an agent in the US, and they received an offer of $3 million for the film rights. Four famous filmmakers called Evans to ask for the chance to make the movie.
Evans shared this story while we drank coffee at his home. He said he turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. He didn't want to spoil the fairy tale by becoming an employee. He wanted to stay involved but not too closely. The success of his novel also brought new interest in *Life and Limb*, but he wasn't sure he wanted to make it anymore. He thought it would be wise to write another novel.

'Young Masters Bobby Fischer is trying to make a comeback in chess, but age is not on his side. Chess is now a game for younger people. After 20 years away, Mr. Fischer is playing against Boris Spassky again. Mr. Fischer won the first game with a great move, but he is not the same as he was in 1972. He is now 49 years old, out of practice, and not in good shape. Mr. Spassky is even older. Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Mr. Fischer helped make chess popular, and now it is more professional. Winning is the main goal for modern players. In international chess, a player's nerves and stamina are as important as their intelligence. The game is very intense: players must make a certain number of moves in a set time, or they lose. Now, games last longer and are played without breaks, which benefits younger players. In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the one before. Of the top ten players in the world, eight are under 30. The way chess is played has also changed. Much of the game happens off the board. Players must prepare well before matches, especially because computers have changed chess. A small computer can store one million chess games and help players study their opponents. In one match, players used teams to find weaknesses in each other's games. The start of a chess game is now studied very carefully. Being well-prepared can decide the game. Today, there are more top players than ever before. Many grandmasters compete for small prizes around the world. Success needs both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours. Players must stay focused, as a mistake can be costly. The chess clock adds pressure. The end of a game can be a fast 'time scramble', where players have only seconds to make moves. This is not for thinkers; it is a battle of nerves and willpower. Losing is very painful at this level, while winning brings great satisfaction. But one win is not enough to win a tournament. Players must be ready to compete the next day. Most tournaments last 9-11 days, with games every day. World championship matches are even tougher. In 1984, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow was stopped because both players were too tired. Mr. Karpov lost about 10kg. Can Mr. Fischer succeed? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This made his leaving chess in 1972 surprising. But it also made him a legend. If he returned for money, he will earn a lot. No matter what happens in his match with Mr. Spassky, both will become much richer. But if Mr. Fischer came back to prove he is still the best, the result might be disappointing.'

**Fame and Fortune**
Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.
**A** Nick Grosso is in his early 30s and has written three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, "Peaches," into a movie script. "It's low budget, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be over £30 million, but it could be as low as £30." Before writing "Peaches," Nick had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote it, I never thought it would be performed," he says. "It's set in a car. I wouldn't do that now because I know the problems it causes. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing school, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of the rhythm and rhyme," he says. "It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational environment. It was very exciting."
**B** Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has progressed a lot since studying drama at Bristol University. He is writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even at Bristol, he was performing in comedy clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon remembers. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor and that I was more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it isn't. If you have courage and good material, making people laugh is wonderful." He has performed with the comic group Funny Business, but his work with Steve Coogan has been the most successful. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably saw me copying him," Simon admits.
**C** Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became famous when he starred in the series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." The show was very well-received, and his career has taken off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says. "I can now choose what I want to do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare position, especially since he just graduated. Looking at Ciaran's early career, it's clear he was always going to be successful. Encouraged by his mother, he went from school plays to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he stayed for four years. "I used acting as an excuse not to do homework," Ciaran laughs. "But then I decided to take it seriously because I was good at it and loved it." Now he is waiting for more success, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you act. It's about getting respect for doing good work."
**D** Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single "Chimera" is released. "The record company talks about a big hit, but I have no idea. If two people buy it, I'll be happy," he says. Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music business ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I was doing student gigs for eight years and was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have happened at a better time. I've been in some terrible bands, but hopefully, it will all be worth it."
**E** Poet and author Stephen Richards, 27, has won many prizes and awards. He is well-known in the poetry world and has been touring and giving readings for six years. His first novel, "Hidden," will be published in March. "It's a story of obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express in a poem." Stephen loved creative writing at school but became unhappy with education later. "I decided not to go to university, but when I got bored with stuffing envelopes at a theatre, I decided to go." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "My parents didn't expect me to be a writer. They thought I'd be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry being praised, moving to novels is brave. "There's a structure in my poetry, so there's less chance of making big mistakes," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more chances for mistakes. My main goal is not to just produce work without caring about the quality."

A. Isabel, the main character in this funny novel, thinks she looks good in jeans but rarely wears them because she doesn't want to be seen with the wrong people. She is a 31-year-old art student who loves historical romance books and is looking for Mr. Right. She worries that her knees might stop her from finding love. However, she remains hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes with great energy, using a fast-paced style like an old silent movie. B. This story is about the start and near end of a local radio station in America. It is told from the view of a smart child, Francis With, who works for WLT Radio. The station was created by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station broadcasts a mix of singers, preachers, and soap-opera stars. The small-town setting allows the author to use dry humor and simple writing. The story takes the reader back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of old cars and radios. C. In this story, it is normal for a second husband to talk with his wife's first husband. Professor Richard Vaisey falls in love with a Russian poetess and talks to his wife's ex about it. The poetess writes bad poetry, which bothers Richard, and she wants his help for her brother in prison. The author makes these problems interesting and funny, and the story is enjoyable and clever. D. Two pairs of best friends, two women and two men, meet in London in the 1960s and stay connected for 25 years. One of them, James Hudson, is starting a newspaper with his friend Richard Blake. The newspaper launch is important, but so is the fact that the woman they both loved was killed years ago. The story includes murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, and the writing is good. The book is long, allowing readers to really get to know the characters. E. This story, by a great American writer, is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty for a mistake and becomes a father to his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is becoming an unusual bachelor. The story shows many emotions and focuses on Ian's sweet relationship with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm book with a good mix of sadness and laughter.

**Volunteer Tourism: A Discussion**
**A.** Volunteer tourism is when people travel to help build homes or schools. They often pay a lot of money to do this work. This money could be more useful if given directly to the local community. Many volunteers are young people on gap years who do not have special skills. Some studies question if these volunteers really want to help or if they are more interested in improving their own careers. However, volunteering can help people become more ethical and caring in their future lives.
**B.** Volunteering can help people from different countries understand each other better. It can also help solve conflicts and create international friendships. This can be good for both volunteers and the communities they visit. But if only rich people can afford to volunteer, it mainly benefits them and not the communities. These volunteers might use the experience to advance their own careers.
**C.** Sometimes, international volunteering can seem like charity from rich countries or a way for people to improve their own lives. But it can also be a way to share skills and learn from each other. Volunteering can make people aware of global problems like poverty and injustice, and encourage them to help solve these issues.
**D.** Volunteer tourism is popular because it seems like a simple way to help others. It avoids big government and business, focusing on personal acts of charity. However, it often does not change the real problems in poor communities. Some people think volunteer tourism is just a way to feel good about helping, without really understanding global poverty.

**Sound the Alarm: Stuart Harris Reports**
Many people listen to the radio in the morning and need something to help them wake up. That's why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? Our team, including me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five models.
The first model has a 'dual alarm function.' I thought it meant you could snooze and then wake up again, but it actually lets you set two different wake-up times, like one for weekdays and one for weekends. This model also has a cassette player, which is a good deal since it costs about the same as the second model. You can fall asleep to your own tapes and wake up without news. We liked the radio quality, but it's as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also books a wake-up call just in case.
The second model was the best-looking and overall winner. Paul Bridges loved it, although the clock sometimes got stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with grey numbers on a green background. The snooze bar is wide, so you can tap it with your eyes closed. It has a self-power back-up, so you don't have to reset it if the plug is pulled out. We found it hard to set up, but once we learned, we felt 'cool' and sophisticated.
Tom Granger thought the third model, with its built-in lamp, was 'tacky.' You have to pull the light out of its socket to use it, which made him question its quality. He had to read the instructions twice to make it work. The light only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges liked the lamp idea but agreed the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer was loud and annoying, but this model is the third most popular on the market.
The fourth model is aimed at young people with its bright colors and strap. Tom Granger and I liked it because it stands out. It was the only one we could set up without reading the instructions. However, the alarm can be 10 minutes early or late. Paul Bridges found it 'fiddly' and 'useless.'
The last model is the simplest and cheapest. Tom Granger liked it because it was standard and took up little space. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which he found intuitive. He admitted that button-tuning has improved radio quality. I thought the tuning was basic, but the radio quality was fine. The buzzer worked well, getting me out of bed in just two beeps!

'Hedgehogs A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines covering its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not native to America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are attacked, so their spines stick out. This helps protect them. The number of spines a hedgehog has can make this defense more or less effective. Some desert hedgehogs have fewer spines because they need to be lighter. These hedgehogs might try to run away from danger first and use their ball rolling as a last option.
