Acupuncture involves inserting fine needles into the skin to help Qi flow better. Sometimes, warmth or pressure is also used.
**Acupuncture Points**
The points used in acupuncture are related to meridians and may not be near the pain area. People often feel a dull ache or tingling when the needle is used. This shows the needle has reached the Qi. There are over 300 main points on the meridians.
**Scientific Views**
Western doctors have found scientific reasons for acupuncture's pain relief. They suggest it might block pain signals to the brain or release natural pain-relieving substances called endorphins.
**Types of Pain Treated**
Acupuncture is often used for long-term pain like back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and post-surgery pain. It is also used for menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.
**Modern Use**
Acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years, but using it instead of anesthesia in surgery began in the 1950s. This convinced some Western doctors of its effectiveness. In China, acupuncture is used in many surgeries, sometimes with electrical stimulation or drugs. It is said to reduce pain without the side effects of regular anesthesia.
**Effectiveness**
Clinical trials for acupuncture are hard to conduct, but some show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists agree it doesn't work for everyone, and results vary. Relief usually takes six to seven visits, but some improvement can be felt after two or three visits.
**Different Views on Pain**
Western and Chinese medicine view pain differently. Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just symptoms. They consider external factors like weather and the type of pain to decide on treatment. This approach is different from that of most Western doctors.
**Choosing an Acupuncturist**
Some medical professionals have traditional acupuncture training, while others use scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe their method leads to longer-lasting cures. It's important to choose a qualified acupuncturist who can refer you to a doctor if needed.

P.D. James is a famous crime writer. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She seems very confident, like a headmistress, but she is actually shy. Her detective character, Adam Dalgliesh, is a bit like her. He likes to solve crimes alone, and she likes to write alone too. She needs privacy to write. P.D. James is very humble and does not agree that she is Britain's most famous crime writer, even though her 12 detective novels are loved by many people worldwide. She enjoys reading books by her friend Ruth Rendell, who writes as Barbara Vine, and other women writers like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner. She also likes male authors like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh.
P.D. James became successful later in life. She was 42 when her first crime novel, "Cover Her Face," was published. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband, Connor Bantry White, there. He was a student, and she loved Cambridge, which is why she set her book "An Unsuitable Job For A Woman" there. Her life was difficult at times. Her husband returned from World War II very sick, and she had to work hard to support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Her husband's parents helped a lot by taking care of the children.
She worked full-time for the National Health Service and later at the Home Office. She was involved in forensic science and juvenile crime. She got used to seeing dead bodies but was more interested in writing crime novels. She liked the structure of crime stories and always wanted to be a writer. She didn't want to use her own life's sad events in her books. Writing detective stories was a way to bring order to chaos. Solving a crime in a story shows that life is important, even if the person is not nice. She believes nobody really likes violence.

'The pen is mightier than the psychoanalyst The study of handwriting to reveal a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you might be asked for a sample of your handwriting. Your handwriting could help decide if you are right for the job. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is seen as a real science in many places. Researchers say it can help show certain illnesses, like heart disease and cancer, and can reveal psychological states and emotional problems. Handwriting analysis is being used more for career guidance and in job interviews. Many big companies now hire graphologists to look at the handwriting of people applying for important jobs. But most doctors and psychiatrists are not sure about the value of graphology. Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist for over 20 years, thinks they should take it more seriously. She believes handwriting can show psychological traits and some medical conditions. She says: 'Handwriting shows social class and intelligence. It can also assess mental ability and potential, whether a person should focus on arts or sciences, and if they have a devious or open character.' According to Ms. Marne, graphology can be useful in assessing possible criminal tendencies: 'Criminals often have disturbed handwriting, mostly poorly-shaped. Many criminals come from difficult backgrounds and have stopped emotional development. This often shows in childish handwriting and going over letters several times. I can tell if people are honest, manipulators, or reliable employees.' 'Young male offenders often have very high ascenders, showing they live in a world of fantasy and dream of success. Graphologists can tell if violence is about to happen, if the writer is under a lot of pressure, and if there are psychopathic tendencies. Handwriting can predict possible suicides.' Heart and lung problems can also show up, she says. 'You can't make a diagnosis from one sample, unless the writing is clearly shaky or disturbed. But if it changes over time or becomes disjointed, if there's a break in the signature that wasn't there before, that could mean something serious has happened.' A big emotional upset can also show in a temporarily changed signature, she says. Ms. Marne says handwriting can show other psychological traits. People with writing where letters form 'threads' instead of being separate are, apparently, devious and clever. Those who write mainly in capitals are trying to hide their true selves. Very light pressure shows sensitivity and lack of energy. Originality in handwriting - how much the writer has changed from standard script - shows confidence and artistic ability. Disconnected writing is a sign of a loner. Very small signatures show inhibition and an inferiority complex; circles over the 'i' are a bid for attention, and crossing the 't' heavily over the whole word shows intolerance and a patronising attitude. Ms. Marne says it takes six years of study and experience to analyse handwriting accurately, and this needs empathy and intuition. She thinks more research is needed to make graphology a proper science. This will happen soon, she believes. 'It's more accurate than psychoanalysis, as you can tell the whole history of the person, including all their emotional crises, without asking them questions they might answer wrongly.' Although this sounds interesting, there is little strong evidence to support these claims. Some psychiatrists are very critical. They say handwriting is a product of education, artistic ability, and the type of writing taught - and has no other meaning.'

'Is your office working well? Fresh air and good chairs are important for a happy, healthy team, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they were. Our expert panel included a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies people's working conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.
Office A: Advertising Agency
Building Health Consultant: This office is very simple; no central heating, no mechanical ventilation, and windows open to the street. The team of seven people seems happy and adapts to the seasons by opening doors and using electric heaters, like at home. They have created a friendly work environment without much outside control.
Ergonomist: The furniture is mismatched and often causes bad posture. Chairs are old, not adjustable, and many are broken. However, the team has a varied work schedule, which helps prevent tiredness and boredom.
Occupational Psychologist: Staff enjoy the variety of work and the flexible office space. The office is the right size for knowing what others are doing but also having personal space. It is both efficient and creative.
Office B: News Service
Building Health Consultant: The office is comfortable and the air quality is good, helped by a No Smoking policy.
Ergonomist: The company has used an ergonomist before. Chairs, lighting, and computer equipment are good, but the layout could be better. The office is impersonal with grey walls.
Occupational Psychologist: Walls are bare except for planners and a maternity rights poster. Staff relationships are okay, but desk positions could be improved for better information sharing.
Office C: Bank
Building Health Consultant: The office feels like a glass case. Despite smokers, the air is not stale. You can't smell smoke even close to a smoker.
Ergonomist: The office is standard and uninspiring. Desks are just adequate, and not all chairs meet requirements. Computer setups are outdated.
Occupational Psychologist: Staff support each other and have good technology. The office is busy, but the wood paneling and brown carpet make it look dull.
Office D: Newspaper
Building Health Consultant: The building has poor air-conditioning and is cluttered and dusty. The roof collects dust, which falls on people below.
Ergonomist: The furniture is more suited for a workshop. Chairs are not good for keyboard users, especially shorter people. Many chairs are old and not adjustable.
Occupational Psychologist: The office is dirty with old chairs and carpets. It needs cleaning and better air conditioning. Few conversations were happening; everyone seemed stressed. The company should encourage teamwork.'

**Chewing Gum Culture**
Chewing gum is popular and people in America chew 12 million pieces every day. It started as an old custom and is now a big business. Each piece of gum has less than ten calories, but it is considered a food. This means it must meet the rules of the American Food and Drug Administration. 
Today, most gum is made from synthetic materials, with added pine resins and softeners to keep the flavor and improve the texture. But this wasn't always true. The ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, found in Greece and Turkey. Greek women liked mastic gum to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. 
In America, colonists learned from the Amero-Indians in New England to chew resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, people in the eastern United States could buy spruce lumps for chewing, making it the first commercial chewing gum in the country.
Modern chewing gum began in the late 1860s with chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. This gum was smoother and more elastic, leading to a new industry. However, growing sapodilla trees commercially has not worked. As the gum market grew, synthetic alternatives were needed. 
Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, called chicleros, have a hard and dangerous job. They walk long distances in very humid conditions to collect sapodilla. They face dangers like poisonous snakes and insects. The chicle fly is especially troublesome because it lays eggs in the tappers' ears and nose. Despite these risks, chicleros climb trees with just a rope and an axe to collect the sap. They carry the liquid to a camp where it is boiled and made into bricks. Life at the camp is tough, with a simple diet and local alcohol made from sugar cane.
Even though their work is hard, chicleros worry about losing their jobs. The United States used to import 7,000 tonnes of chicle a year from Central America, but last year only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula. As gum sales have increased, manufacturers use synthetics to cut costs and meet demand.
Gum producers are also finding new ways to market their products. They claim gum helps you relax, gives you energy, and reduces tension. Soldiers in both world wars were given gum. The biggest claim is that gum reduces tooth decay. When we eat, plaque acid forms and causes decay. Saliva neutralizes the acid and provides minerals like calcium, phosphate, and fluoride. Gum makers say chewing for 20 minutes can increase saliva flow.
Research continues on new textures and flavors. Glycerine and other vegetable oils are used to mix the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still need natural help. Also, 137 square kilometers of America is used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**Remote Hotels**
**A. India - Ghanerao Hotel, Rajasthan**  
Ghanerao Hotel is in a small village near the Aravalli Hills. The village is known for its craftsmen. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years. Now, Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests to their home. The hotel is simple, with hot water brought in buckets, but this adds to its charm.
**B. New Zealand - Hermitage Hotel, Mount Cook**  
The Hermitage Hotel is on New Zealand's South Island. I found it by accident while climbing. After a long climb down a glacier, I was surprised to see this hotel. It is in a beautiful, wild area. After a tiring day, it was amazing to find such luxury, with someone playing piano music.
**C. Mauritius - Beachcomber Paradis Hotel**  
The Paradis Hotel is on a quiet peninsula in south-west Mauritius. The road to the hotel passes empty beaches. The hotel is not small, and many people enjoy the free watersports. However, you can find peace on the nine kilometers of private beach. In the evening, when everyone leaves, you feel far from everything.
**D. St Lucia - Ladera Hotel, St Lucia**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia is in a dramatic location. It is quiet and away from busy areas, 1,000 feet high. The open rooms have views of the Pitons and the Caribbean Sea. The style is colonial, with wooden furniture and four-poster beds with netting.
**E. Turkey - The Splendid Hotel, Istanbul**  
This hotel is on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, a peaceful escape from Istanbul. The islands are an hour by boat and have no cars, only horse-drawn carriages. The Splendid Hotel is a wooden building, painted white with red domes. It is a bit old now but still charming.
**F. France - Chateau d'Etoges, Epernay**  
In the village of Etoges, in Champagne, is a beautiful 17th-century chateau. It has a moat with swans and 20 unique rooms. Some rooms have four-poster beds, and one has a billiard table. There are special weekend rates with breakfast, dinner, and complimentary champagne.
**G. Kenya - The Fairview Hotel, Nairobi**  
The Fairview Hotel is a comfortable place in Africa without too much luxury. It is a popular stop for travelers between safaris. Some guests decide to stay longer after seeing the gardens and rooms. The hotel is on Nairobi Hill, away from the busy city. It is a great place to watch the sunset with a drink and enjoy a hearty dinner.
**H. Italy - Hotel Splendido, Portofino**  
The Duke of Windsor was the first guest at Hotel Splendido. Many famous people have stayed here, like Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart. Today, you might meet a billionaire or heiress. The hotel, once a monastery, is still splendid. It offers simple, delicious food and beautiful Persian rugs.

'Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. She checks hotels to see if they are good. Christopher Middleton watched her work. At the Globe Hotel, things are not going well. The receptionist is talking on the phone and does not notice Sue. Sue whispers, 'Very poor.' This is a common mistake she has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. The Globe Hotel has three red stars, which means it is one of the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 in the guide. But Sue is not impressed. The entrance from the car park is through a door with a buzzer and a long, empty corridor. 'Not what I expected,' says Sue. Things get worse when the receptionist says they have no record of Sue's booking. Most rooms are empty, but the one they offer is not good. It is stuffy, and there is a hole in the wall behind the wardrobe. Sue was known as 'The Woman in Black' for being tough, but she says she is not too tough. The next morning, after paying, she tells the manager, Robin Greaves, who she is. He looks worried. He apologizes for a bad smell in the lounge. Sue suggests fixing the plumbing and not taking guests to that room. Greaves agrees and takes notes. He has been at the hotel for five months and hopes Sue's feedback will help. Sue praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the waitress, for their good work. Dinner was good enough to keep the hotel's two-rosette food rating. Greaves asks how to get three rosettes. Sue says, 'Don't serve a pudding that collapses.' Sue's job is to say what other guests might not. She remembers a time when a woman complained that Sue got her son fired because he served apple pie with his fingers. Sue writes a report for the hotel after her visit. Hotels pay to be in the guide, so they want to improve. The good news for Greaves is that Sue will not recommend taking away the red stars. But another inspector will come in two months to check again. 'Good,' says Greaves, trying to smile.'

**Seven Up Mountaineer Doug Scott shares his experience of climbing the highest peak on each continent: the Seven Summits.**
**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**
I was in a snow cave near the top of Mt. Everest with my climbing partner, Dougal Haston. Dougal started talking to someone who wasn't there, which I thought was strange. I realized it was because of the lack of oxygen. I also started talking to my feet because they were getting cold. I remembered other climbers who had lost fingers and toes to frostbite. I wasn't worried about surviving, but about how well we would survive. Over the next two days, I thought about our time on the summit ridge. I felt lucky to be climbing with Dougal, who gave me confidence. I knew I needed a better rhythm to reach the summit, and I did.
**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**
This mountain is considered very dangerous. In April 1976, Dougal and I arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier and spent four days carrying equipment and food to the base. After the first day of climbing, we realized how big our task was. We followed an old route at first, but then took a new path to the summit. We climbed 'alpine style', carrying everything on our backs. It was the first time a new route was climbed this way. We camped under a cliff, and by the third day, my sleeping bag was wet. We spent the night on a windy ridge and felt like we were at a higher altitude than we were. We finally reached the summit and came down the other side, feeling triumphant.
**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**
In September 1976, Paul Braithwaite and I went to Nairobi to climb Mt. Kenya. We got a free ride to Kilimanjaro and decided to climb it instead. We got lost in the jungle on the lower slopes and were worried because there was little water. On the second day, we found arrows on trees and a trail of rubbish that led us to a rock pool. We were happy to find water. We tried to climb a steep ice wall but had to turn back because of falling rocks and ice. We took a different route to reach the summit.
**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**
The usual route up Aconcagua is like a walk. In January 1992, I went there with my wife, Sharu. We met a guide, Phil Erscheler, who suggested we join his group on a different route. After waiting for the weather to improve, we left base camp. The Polish Glacier was icy, and we decided to take the standard route instead. We reached the summit just before dark. Back at base camp, we met climbers from the Jakarta Mountaineering Club. They were planning to climb the Seven Summits and encouraged me to do the same.
**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**
I realized I could climb Vinson Massif by guiding enough people to cover the costs. Our team left Britain in November 1992 and traveled to the South Pole. The sun was always up, and the air was clean. On December 7, we left camp for the summit. Despite strong winds and cold temperatures, we reached the top in 8 hours. The storm made it hard to see, but we were happy to succeed.
**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**
Our team met in St Petersburg in early summer 1994. At Terskol, near Elbrus, we had to pay a fee for bringing foreigners, but it was later waived. After acclimatizing, we took a cableway to 3,900m and walked to a refuge at 4,200m. Two days later, we crossed icy slopes and thought we reached the summit, but there was another ridge to climb. We returned to the refuge at night and descended the next day.
**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**
On our trip to Carstensz, we wanted to find a new route and spend time with the Dani people. The mountain has a large gold mine, which is sacred to the local tribes. We were warned about bandits but continued our journey. On May 12, we started climbing. The weather improved, and two team members went ahead. We reached the summit by 11 am. I received applause for completing my seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

**Style Merchants**
Style is important in our lives today, from clothes to home decoration and accessories. Jo Foley talks about this year's fashion trends.
**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**
Ned Ingham designs beautiful, romantic wedding dresses. He suggests choosing simpler styles instead of traditional, stiff dresses. Ingham started drawing and designing wedding dresses when he was in school. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. Besides wedding dresses, he also designs long evening dresses with modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, he offers a navy-blue summer suit, a staple in English fashion, but with a fresh look.
**Sally Quail: Jeweller**
Sally Quail used to work for an art dealer and has no formal training in jewelry. She started designing jewelry when she couldn't find an engagement ring she liked. This led her to become a designer in 1990. Her jewelry is popular with many famous people. She is known for using large semi-precious stones set in gold, inspired by 18th-century styles. Recently, she started using diamonds. At 36, she says, "I reached that moment in every woman's life when she wants a diamond."
**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**
Lily Grimson entered the competitive fashion world four years ago with only a basic art and design course. Two of her handbags were chosen for a major design exhibition. Her bags, made in the UK, are always noticed. They are glamorous, made from fine calfskin or heavy silk. A Grimson bag is special because of its style and quality.
**Peter Little: Hairdresser**
For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of many famous people. He says most women want hair that looks natural and is easy to manage at home. His goal is to make sure clients don't look like they just left a salon. However, his services are expensive, costing £250 for the first visit, and there is a three-month waiting list. He also sells his own hairdryers and styling tools, so people can style their hair at home.
**Penny Pratt: Florist**
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and is a flower consultant for a supermarket chain. She also gives floral ideas to top restaurants. She has no formal training in floristry and left her teaching job 10 years ago to try something new. Her simple yet modern flower arrangements have won many design awards. She has started her own London Flower School and has given successful lectures in Japan and the USA. She advises keeping flower arrangements simple and strong, with few leaves. For wedding bouquets, she says the flowers should be of the same type.

**Title: The Merrion Hotel: Luxury and Modern Technology**
The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It was created by turning four large old houses into a modern hotel. This allowed the hotel to include the latest technology for both staff and guests.
The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, like guest preferences, he uses a computer system. This system, which cost £250,000, helps treat returning guests in a special way. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them next time. The system remembers guest preferences.
Room temperature is important for comfort. Guests can change the temperature in their room a little, but the front desk can adjust it more if needed. Business guests will like the technology in the rooms. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing tool. The hotel has prepared for future technology changes by adding extra cables and renting TVs, so they can be updated easily.
The hotel has 145 large, comfortable rooms. There is also a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. The food is excellent, thanks to Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose restaurant has two Michelin stars. Moving his restaurant to the hotel has been good for both him and the hotel.
With modern technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is set to be successful.

'An eye for detail Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her large garden around her house gives her many subjects to paint. The garden is full of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread everywhere. There is a nice mix of colors, shapes, and structures in the two long flower borders along the path in the garden. This is partly because of the previous owners who loved gardening and left plants that Susan liked. She also got the gardener, Danny, from them. 'Actually, it was really his garden,' she says. 'We got along well. At first, he would say, "Oh, it's not worth it" about some things I wanted to plant, but when I said I wanted to paint them, he understood what I meant.' Susan likes to focus on detailed studies of single plants rather than the whole garden, though sometimes she paints a group of plants where they are. Usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. 'I don't set everything up at once,' she says. 'I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days, and then I bring in another one and build up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish.' Her busiest time is spring and early summer, when the tulips and poppies bloom. 'They all bloom together, and you're so busy,' she says. But she also finds the way flowers decay interesting. With tulips, for example, 'you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day and they each form different shapes. They open out and are fantastic. When you first put them in a vase, you think they are boring, but they change all the time with twists and turns.' Susan has always been interested in plants: 'I studied botany at school and used to collect wild flowers from the countryside,' she says. 'I wasn't very interested in gardening then; in fact, I didn't like garden flowers, I thought they looked like fake ones made of silk or plastic sold in some shops - to me, the only real ones were wild. I was fascinated by how they managed to grow in difficult places, like cracks in rocks or on cliff tops.' Today, the garden has many plants from faraway places, but they seem at home in her garden. She has a relaxed attitude to the garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious damage. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for, and many subjects to paint right outside her door, finding time to work in the garden has been hard recently. She now has an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected with her work, 'you have to get your hands dirty'.'

Many trees in the Brackham area fell during the big storms in March. The town lost two large lime trees from the old market square. This changed how the town center looked, which upset some of the older residents. Normally, Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police, would have been upset too. But during the storm, when the wind knocked down the walnut tree in his garden, Pelham was too sick to notice. He was a strong and healthy man, but he got very sick with bronchitis for the first time. When he first felt a headache and chest pain, his wife, Molly, told him to see a doctor. Pelham thought the police needed him, so he ignored her and kept working. This made him forgetful and short-tempered. Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. He was too weak to argue. Soon, he was getting his medicine and going home to his wife, who sent him to bed. On Thursday morning, Molly told him the walnut tree had fallen, but he couldn't understand it. On Thursday evening, he asked if the house was damaged, was relieved to hear it wasn't, and went back to sleep. By Saturday, the medicine worked, his fever went down, and he got up. He was shocked to see the walnut tree was gone, which changed how the living room looked. The Pelhams' big house had a large garden. It was expensive, but Pelham was happy they bought it. The garden made it feel private. But now, the storm changed things. Before, the walnut tree was part of the view from the living room. It didn't make the room dark because there was another window, but it made nice light patterns that hid the old furniture they brought from their last house. Without the tree, the room was very bright, showing the old furniture clearly. The view from the window was now of the tall house next door, which was ugly with purple bricks and pipes. It had many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams. 'Doesn't it look terrible?' Pelham said to his wife. But Molly, standing in the doorway, sounded happy. 'I've been telling you since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost.'

'Living in the valley We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first realized the dangers in the hills around us. It was the year when the storms came early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe in our valley below the hills. Soon snow began to fall. In one day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. But on the nearby hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed longer. Up there, the wind was very strong. In our valley, we only felt sudden strong winds; trees moved but the branches stayed strong. Still, we knew we had a reason to worry. The snow and wind were inconvenient but not a big problem. It was the river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently, that worried us most. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by dams built many years ago. Soon the snow started to melt. Every day, we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. Grey clouds spread over the valleys, warning us of what was coming. We had seen enough of the sky; now we watched the river, which was getting fuller and wilder every day. The snow was washed away as more rain fell, but high in the hills, the reservoir was filling and getting close to danger level. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. Up in the hills, it was like Niagara Falls, as water surged over the dam and into the stream below. The river seemed wild as the waters rushed down to its lower parts. Just a couple of meters from our cottage, the stream was wild under the bridge. It was deeper than we had ever seen it near our home, hitting its banks hard. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its wall. Luckily, our hopes were answered as the dam held and the waters began to go down. Many times before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages in such a rage. Now, the dam controls the river, and usually, all is well; the large amount of water from the hills, from snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam with just a little overflow sometimes. We can enjoy, not fear, the big clouds over the valley, and be amazed by the river's power. Thanks to this protection, we feel our home in the valley is still safe and secure.'

'Film Critic Mark Adams looks back over the last ten years of his work as a film critic for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing articles about films for The Front Page was my first real job. Before that, I had done some reviewing - novels for other newspapers, films for a magazine, and anything I was asked to do for the radio. That was how I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who had also written for radio and television. He hired me, but Tom was not mainly a journalist, or he would have been more careful in choosing his staff. At first, his idea was that a team of critics should take care of the art forms that didn't need special knowledge: books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. There would be a weekly lunch where we would choose from the artistic material that Tom had decided we should cover, and there would also be guests to make it sociable. It all felt like a dream at that time: a new newspaper, and I was part of the team. It seemed unlikely that a paper could be introduced into a crowded market. It seemed just as likely that a millionaire wanted to help me personally and was pretending to employ me. Such was my lack of self-confidence. In fact, the first time I saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground, then turning to a page with one of my reviews, I didn't know where to look. Tom's original plan for a team of critics for the arts never happened. It was a good idea, but we didn't meet as planned, so everything was done by phone. It turned out that the public preferred to associate a reviewer with a single subject area, so I chose film. Without Tom's initial push, we wouldn't have come up with the present arrangement, where I write an extended weekly piece, usually on one film. This way of working suits me well. I wouldn't have been interested in the more standard film critic's role, which involves reviewing every film that comes out. That's a routine that would make me tired quickly. I would soon be sitting in my seat on a Monday morning with the sigh, 'What bad film must I watch now?' - a style of sigh that can often be heard in screening rooms around the world. The space I am given allows me to broaden my argument - or forces me, in a boring week, to make something out of nothing. But what is my role in the public arena? I assume that people choose what films to see based on the stars, the publicity, or the director. There is also such a thing as loyalty to 'type' or its opposite. It can only rarely happen that someone who hates westerns buys a ticket for one after reading a review, or a love story fan avoids a romantic film because of what the papers say. So if a film review isn't really a consumer guide, what is it? I certainly don't feel I have a responsibility to be 'right' about a movie. Nor do I think there should be a certain number of 'great' and 'bad' films each year. All I have to do is put forward an argument. I'm not a judge, and nor would I want to be.'

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because "it's fun." Teenager with a love for endurance sports WANTED: Sports-loving training partner for a triathlete, preferably female. Chance to train with a potential Olympic champion. Must enjoy distance running (regular 15km sessions), distance swimming (training in cold rivers is a plus), and distance cycling (enjoying 100km rides is an advantage). Ability to do all three without resting is essential. The triathlon is becoming one of the most popular Olympic sports. Recently, it has attracted large crowds who are fascinated (and shocked) by athletes swimming 1500m, cycling 40km, then running 10km without stopping. It's exciting for those watching, but why do triathletes want to push their bodies so hard? And why would a 17-year-old girl with excellent grades give up everything for this challenging sport? Melanie Sears hasn't yet learned the usual phrases about personal satisfaction, mental challenge, and higher goals that most athletes use. "You swim for 1500m, then run out of the water and jump on your bike, still wet. Of course, then you freeze. When the 40km cycle ride is over, you have to run 10km, which is a long way when you're feeling exhausted. But it's great fun, and all worth it in the end," she says. Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. "I won the junior section - but then I was the only junior taking part. It seemed so easy that I was waving at my team-mates as I went around." Full of confidence, she entered the National Championships, and although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she didn't win. "I was following this man and suddenly we came to the sea. We realized then that we had gone wrong. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried all the way through the running." But she did not give up and is determined that she never will. "Sometimes I wish I could stop, because then the pain would be over, but I am afraid that if I let myself stop just once, I would be tempted to do it again." Such determination draws admiration from Steve Trew, the sport's director of coaching. "I've just been testing her fitness," he says, "and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off and into a wall. She had given it everything, but whereas most people step off when they realize they can't go any further, she just kept on." Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower at cycling. That's why I'm working very hard at it." She is trying to convince her parents, who will pay the £1,300 cost of her trip to New Zealand for this year's World Championships, to buy a £2,000 bike ("It's a special deal, with £1,000 off) so she can try national 25 km and 100 km races later this year. But there is another price to pay. Her tough training sessions have made her a bit of a loner. "I don't have a social life," she says. "I'm not a party person anyway. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to go to sleep. But I phone and write to the other girls in the team." What does she talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, what sort of times they are achieving." Where will all this focus end? Melanie has tried other events. She has tried the triathlon "sprint," for example, where you only have to swim 750m, cycle 20km, and run 5km. She wants to enter even tougher events than the triathlon. "The big trouble is, I have no one of my age to train with," she says. Funny, that.

'The Collectors Amanda Roy talks about the things she collects and why many people enjoy this hobby. I have always loved collecting, and one in three adults enjoys this hobby too. It is a world of passion and excitement. But remember, if you do not love an object, do not collect it. Since ancient times, people have wanted to collect things. Early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. They liked their shapes and colors. Over the years, not much has changed. Children still collect stones and seashells for their beauty. I have been collecting all my life, from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. When I was six, I went to a school in a remote part of England. My parents took me to a local museum full of objects collected by people in the past. I was fascinated by these objects. Many adults share this passion for collecting. People collect for different reasons. Some feel it is the only part of their lives they can control. For me, it's just something I enjoy. A famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a 'room of wonders' with coconut shell cups, carved ivory beads, and Oriental china. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. You do not have to be rich to start a collection. I have collected tulip bulbs and china cups with great determination. I remember convincing another tulip collector to give me one I wanted. I planted it, but one year it was stolen by another collector. I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching all over the USA for them. This collection was destroyed in a house fire. The next morning, I saw the remains of my furniture and collection. I am not sure which made me sadder! I am interested in how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king or poet gives value to items traded in markets. As small objects become popular, their prices rise. Toys from the 1950s are now an investment, but only if you kept the original boxes. (I threw them away, along with the toys.)'

'My line of work Four people talk about their jobs. Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum I organize temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and promote it. I read about the subject first and talk to experts to decide the main themes and goals. I plan what objects and pictures to show. I make sure visitors understand the exhibition by planning interactive displays, workshops, and theatre. I also work with engineers and electricians to ensure safety. Before the exhibition opens, I help design and write brochures and leaflets to inform people. Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers I start work at 7.30 a.m. by checking the accounts. Then I see what new maps and documents are needed for learning the routes for the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in school, figuring out the best routes. They learn the correct one-way streets and turns. I help when there is a disagreement, like if a right turn is possible at a junction. When they are close to the test, I give them a simple route and then tell them they must find another way because the road is closed. The next student must find a third route, and I give a reason why they can't use it. This makes them think. Sarah - Marine Conservationist I live by the coast and work from home. I answer phone calls, create educational materials, and set up training courses. Sometimes, I go to the main office, but mostly I am by the coast. I work with schools and study centers and run courses for coastal managers. I take them out to sea in a boat to help them understand marine life better. This often changes their views because it is different from making decisions on a computer. I love my job because conservation is my hobby. The downside is I work for a charity, so we always need more money. I am always looking for more resources and can't do everything I want. Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher My work is varied. I make sure our publishing matches market needs and keep stocks of about 300 books. We have high standards for information. We get many letters from readers about things like international boundaries, which need careful replies. I discuss future projects and sales with co-publishers. I work with an enthusiastic team, which makes the job enjoyable. The downside is there is too much administration, leaving less time for interesting tasks like product development and design.'

'Our Holiday in Ireland We always went to Ireland in June. Since we started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who bought the house, the Malseeds, have added to the building, but they did it very carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. 'How about this?' he said one evening and read the details. We had gone away together the summer before, to a hotel recommended by friends, but it wasn't good because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time, Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school, Dekko Deacon sounds nice, I guess. He and Strafe went to school together, so we call Strafe by his last name like the teachers did. We're all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds were before they moved from England to Ireland. We think it's quite a coincidence. 'How very nice,' Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are about to arrive because she's usually waiting in the large hall that always smells of flowers. 'Arthur, take the luggage up,' she told the old porter. 'Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium.' She was talking about the names of the rooms reserved for us. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of putting numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little details like that; her husband does the redecoration and repairs. 'Well, well, well,' Mr. Malseed said, coming into the hall from the kitchen. 'A hundred thousand welcomes,' he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling with his dark brown eyes twinkling, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and I felt the others thinking that our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn, all was well. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. 'You look younger every year, all four of you,' she said, making everyone in the hall laugh again. Arthur led the way to the rooms, carrying as much of our luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but not for long because we were still tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man on his own and a French couple. There were other people at dinner, of course, because in June Glencorn Lodge is always full: from where we sat in the window, we could see some of them walking on the lawns, others taking the cliff path down to the seashore. In the morning, we'd do the same: we'd walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee in the hotel there, back in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we'd drive somewhere. I knew all that because over the years this kind of routine had developed. Since we first came here, we'd all fallen in love with every part of its beautiful landscape.'

'Keeping the holiday-makers happy A chalet girl's work is never done, Sarah Sutherland-Pilch tells Veronica Lee - in between making beds and delicious dinners. This is the second year as a chalet girl for Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex. Known by her nickname, Pilch, Sarah works for a company in Val d'Isere, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, called chalets, that are typical of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. She says being a chalet girl isn't a career, but a fun way to spend a year or two before settling down. 'It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week.' Sarah does not live in the chalet. She gets up at 7 a.m. to walk about a mile to the chalet, which can have up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests. 'They get porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.' When the guests finish breakfast, by about 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea, which is left for the guests, or cleans the rooms - 'the worst part of the job,' she says. By about 11 a.m. she is ready to go skiing. She skis as much as possible. 'On a good day we can be up there until 4:30 p.m.' Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower before doing so, but does not sleep. 'It's bad if you do,' she says. Dinner, a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. 'There's nothing worse than coming in to a messy kitchen the next morning.' Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they are happy to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week great - breakfast this morning was fun - but some weeks, for whatever reason, don't go quite so well.' Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives - and they go out at about 11 p.m. 'We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening,' she says. But Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night as Sunday is her busiest time of the week. 'A terrible day,' she says, 'when you don't want to be cooking breakfast with a bad headache.' Work begins earlier than usual on Sunday, since breakfast for guests who are leaving has to be on the table by 7 a.m. As soon as the guests leave, Sarah starts cleaning quickly. 'We just clean everything - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't already done the week's shopping on Saturday, Sarah does it now. At around 3 p.m., the cleaning work done, Sarah then prepares tea for the new guests. 'They get here at around 4:30 p.m.' Sometimes they are confused and full of questions. I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them.' Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes any guests needing boots or skis to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet from one of the ski shop staff. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a drink later, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says. '

Miss Rita Cohen, a very small girl with pale skin, visited Seymour's factory one day. She looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but said she was six years older. Rita wore overalls and big shoes, and her pretty face was surrounded by curly hair. Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania, researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. 
A few times a year, someone would call or write to Seymour to ask if they could see his factory. Sometimes, he would help a student by answering questions on the phone or giving a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-year class, who had visited the factory years ago. Seymour had shown them how he made gloves, especially Marie's favorite part, the laying-off table. Here, the men shaped and pressed each glove by pulling it over steam-heated brass hands. These hands were very hot, shiny, and stood straight up from the table, looking flat. As a child, Marie called them the 'pancake hands'.
Rita asked, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' Seymour replied, 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand.' She took notes and asked, 'Do they come directly to your shipping department?' Seymour liked that she was interested in every detail. He explained, 'They come to the tannery. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they make it ready for us to work with. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. So did I, for six months, when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?' Rita said, 'Not yet.' Seymour offered, 'I'll set that up for you if you'd like. They're old-fashioned places. The technology has improved, but it's not much different from hundreds of years ago. It's hard work. Tanning is said to be the oldest industry, with remains found in Turkey, I believe, from six thousand years ago. The first clothing was just skins tanned by smoking them. My father is the leather expert; you should talk to him. He can talk about gloves for two days. Glovemen love the trade. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?' Rita replied, 'I can't say I have. I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child.' Seymour laughed. Rita made him laugh. She was eager to learn, like his daughter Marie, who was taller and fairer than Rita but had the same good-natured intelligence. 
Seymour decided, 'I'll show you the whole process. Come on. We'll make you a pair of gloves, and you'll watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?'

'Is it a tough job? Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as wonderful as they seem. A. Raquel Graham Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She can't meet us tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles instead. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she has to travel around the world quickly. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. There's just one small problem - she doesn't like flying. 'On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help calm me down,' she says. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. 'It felt so closed in with those tiny windows.' When she's not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She has to do some boring paperwork - organizing the diary, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning schedules, and making more travel plans. She didn't apply for the job. She met the manager of a pop group by chance, which led to a job offer. She took a secretarial course at night school at the same time. Five years later, she was in the right place at the right time when her boss needed a PA. B. David Brown David Brown has been both an accountant and a golf caddy, a person who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he liked being a caddy more. Well, you would too if golf was your passion. There were some downsides though. A small flat fee is given, plus a percentage of the winnings. The average earnings are between £25,000 and £35,000, and much of that is spent on travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first caddied for the golfer, Greg Norman. 'You're not just carrying bags. You're giving advice, using your knowledge against the weather, and trying to understand the course.' His accountancy skills were recently recognized by European Tour Productions when they made him a statistical data administrator. From cards brought in by the caddies, he collects and analyzes the statistics of each day's play. The results are wanted by TV commentators, golfing magazines, and the golfers themselves. C. Martin Fern Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper, and one of his easier tasks is to try food in the best restaurants. What does he think about restaurants that charge very high prices? 'For those who can afford it, it's their choice,' he says. 'I'd rather spend £120 on a meal I'll remember for the rest of my life than buy a microwave.' His talent as a cook led to the offer of a food column from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. For Martin, who was then a creative director of an advertising agency, it was a useful extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper called to offer a full-time job. 'It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income,' he says. 'But it was a chance to turn my passion into a profession.' He still does all the cooking at home and tries to keep his weight under control by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station. D. Dick Prince 'I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's writers. 'Before that, I always loved words and enjoyed using them, but my writing was mainly poetry. Then I had this idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew the problem of chickens being killed by a fox. So I wrote a kind of role reversal story called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's story.' Where do his ideas come from? 'Well, it's not easy, I have to work at them,' he says. 'That is what I usually do in the mornings. I'm not up with the dawn, I'm afraid. After lunch, I spend another couple of hours typing out the morning's notes - all of which I do with one finger on an old portable typewriter rather than on one of those awful laptops. I get between 50 and a hundred letters a week, and that is the part about being a writer that I enjoy the most. I do try to answer them all, but nowadays I have some secretarial help.'

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were made into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it were big piles of soft sawdust. These golden piles covered the yard down to the blue lake. That afternoon, with nothing else to do, all the boys followed Michael up a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof onto the sawdust. He lay there laughing and said, "I dare you all! You're all cowards." He watched them from the roof, looking scared, but one by one, they jumped and got up smiling. In the hot sun, they lay on the sawdust, telling jokes. Then one boy said, "Let's go up and jump again." They weren't very excited, but they all went up and jumped off again, except for Michael. The others were below, calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?" Michael wanted to join them, but he stayed on the roof, nervous and smiling awkwardly. It seemed like a longer drop this time. At first, they thought he was joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists. He tried to count to ten and jump, but it didn't work. The boys started laughing at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward. Do you think we'll wait all night?" they shouted. When he didn't move, they walked away, still shouting. "Who started this? What's wrong with you?" he called. But he stayed on the roof, looking sadly at the ground. He was alone for nearly an hour while the sun set over the lake. His clothes were wet from sweating. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, and fell onto the sawdust. He lay there for a long time. The workmen had gone home, and the yard was quiet. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn't jump before. Then he got up slowly and walked home, feeling ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You're old enough to come home on time. If you can't, you should stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke with controlled anger, but Michael, feeling gloomy, hardly heard her. He was still thinking about the boys laughing at him.

**Careers Advice**
Are you unhappy with your job but unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people who want to change jobs are turning to careers advisers. You will need to write a short history of yourself and take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you get a summary with career suggestions and possible retraining options.
I decided to try Career Analysts, a big company that gives career advice. Taking the careers test felt like being back in my science exams. I was with about ten people, answering questions quickly. I had to remember it wasn't about passing or failing. The tests included finding mistakes in lists and matching shapes. After the tests, I talked with an adviser who gave me a report with his thoughts and suggestions. I agreed with most of his conclusions, though I was surprised to learn I did poorly in scientific and technical tests. I was glad to hear I made the right choice with journalism.
Changing your career doesn't always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager after five years. Her friends suggested Career Analysts. 'Losing my job was a chance to look at my career and skills,' says Donna. Some results surprised her. 'I didn't know I had a talent for design. But I had to think about the cost of retraining,' she says. Other ideas included working in the Far East for a year. 'I used my skills to find a job better suited to me. Now, I work as a Public Relations officer. Career Analysts helped me see what I wanted to do. I've recommended them to friends who are happy with the service.'
Some people feel they couldn't have made changes without help. A visit to Career Counselling Services helped 26-year-old Juliet Greene make big decisions. 'After six years at a bank, I found my job boring and needed a new challenge. I didn't know what to do, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. The tests showed I was interested in sciences,' she says. 'I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which was helpful. After the fourth meeting, I decided to study geology and plan to start a degree this year. The advice was worth the fee. I'm much happier and more positive now.'
However, careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says: 'I didn't know where to go in my career. I hoped a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I got many ideas, I rejected them because they required a big salary drop or a lot of retraining. I didn't learn anything new about myself,' she says. 'You have to give the adviser a lot of personal information, and I felt a friend could have given me similar advice.'

'Fun at the Dentist's? If you walk into W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in the center of Glasgow, you'll see bright modern paintings on the wall and a stylish blue couch where patients sit while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, 'Fifty percent of people only go to the dentist when they're in pain instead of going for regular check-ups. That's because they're scared.' To change this, he has tried to make a place where people are not afraid. That's why I decided not to wear a white coat. I think that's something people connect with pain. My idea is that dental treatment should happen in a relaxed, interesting, and fun atmosphere.' This is surprising for many of us who think dental visits mean pain or at least formal, clinical visits. Jerome says, 'If people are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget past bad experiences.' Virtual-reality headsets are one of his new ways to help people relax. 'We were the first in Britain to use them and they're very popular. The headsets are used for the first check-up, where the patient sits comfortably on the blue couch and watches a film about underwater wildlife while I look at their teeth. Then the headset shows a special camera view, giving the patient a tour around their mouth.' Surprisingly, most patients enjoy this part of their visit. Another important thing is that the office smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's. Today it smells like orange. Jerome explains, 'When people walk in, I want them to know with all their senses that it's not like going to the dentist's. Smell is very important. That dental smell can make your heart race if you're scared of dentists.' I found the nice smell in the office very pleasant. Although he is known as Glasgow's most fashionable dentist, Jerome wants to say that he takes his work very seriously. The relaxation techniques are important, but the quality of the treatment is the most important thing. For example, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them, instead of scraping them. It feels a bit strange at first, but as long as people are relaxed, it's not painful at all. Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about dental techniques. 'One thing I learned there was that when you make it easier for the patient, you make it easier for yourself,' he explains. He sees his patient-focused attitude as the start of a slow change towards less formality in the traditional British dentistry profession. At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes over, offers him a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks him what video he'd like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this five-star treatment, and it's no surprise. The office feels more like an elegant beauty salon than a regular dental practice.'

**THE SHELL ARTIST**
Peter Cooke is 83 years old and has become very skilled in his art. He still wants to try new things like paper-making and feather-work, but for now, he focuses on making beautiful and unique objects from shells. As he shows me his work in his apartment, he says, "Tell me if I am boring you." However, he is not boring at all; he is very enthusiastic and charming, and his creations are beautiful.
He shows me some shell-covered ornaments above his fireplace and says he doesn't mind if people don't buy them because he loves them. He never planned to sell his work, but friends encouraged him to have an exhibition. Five years ago, he had an exhibition in London, and 70% of his pieces were sold. His second exhibition just opened, and the pieces are quite expensive, with some costing around £2,000.
There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Cooke says he doesn't set the prices and is open about them. He believes no one else in the world makes work like his, and the gallery owner told him that one day everyone will want his pieces because he will stop making them.
Cooke wishes he had started this art earlier in life because he feels he could have created even more wonderful things. Although he still has many ideas, he finds himself more physically limited now. Despite this, his work is far from the typical shell crafts found in seaside shops. He creates boxes covered in tiny shells, pictures made from shells, and baskets of realistic flowers.
Cooke has developed his own method and uses materials he finds. He uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He says his work seems to create itself, but the detail and symmetry show it is not accidental.
His search for beautiful, tiny shells has taken him to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He only collects dead shells and defends himself against people who accuse him of harming beaches. He says that people walking on the beach destroy shells faster than he can collect them, and the sea breaks them up too. He would never collect shells with living creatures inside or dive for them. He believes that collecting empty shells is not harmful, and his work turns them into something even more beautiful.

'The Schoolgirl Model When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not traveling to amazing places and appearing on magazine covers, you will probably find her studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw finds out more. 'I'm afraid Kira will be a little late,' the receptionist at the agency told me. 'Oh, fine,' I said, 'no problem.' I had been trying to convince myself that all the bad things I had read about models were not true, but words like difficult, vain, and unintelligent kept coming into my head. And now she was going to be late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she had decided a visit to the hairdresser's would be more fun than talking to me? If she was late, she would be rushing. She could be in a bad mood and refuse to answer my questions. But when the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition walked in, she was smiling, relaxed, and apologetic, and she was with her mother. Kira was not dressed in expensive designer clothes but in a simple black dress and trainers. There was no sign of a selfish attitude; she was just a very friendly, very tall, very pretty girl. All models under the age of 16 must take an adult with them whenever they work, she explained, and apart from looking very young, her mother was a normal mum - visibly proud of her successful daughter. Kira seems a bit surprised by her new fame, which is understandable since it was not planned. It was her older sister who decided that she should enter the model competition. 'She saw the competition and said I should go in for it,' Kira remembers. 'I said no, but she sent some photos in anyway.' When the call came to tell her that she was a finalist, she was at school. Being selected for the final gave Kira the confidence to go through with it, and she performed perfectly. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London immediately offered her work. Kira now finds that one of the hardest things she has to do is to manage her two separate lives. But her friends and teachers have become used to having a star among them. 'They're really proud of me,' she says. However, a few unkind people at her school are rude about her success. 'They say I have too high an opinion of myself.' This kind of remark must be hard for Kira to deal with, since there can't be many people as successful as her who are less self-important. But she says, 'They assume that because I've suddenly become a model, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I've become more confident - not in a bad way, but I'm able to stand up for myself more.' As a busy model, though, her social life is obviously affected. The Select agency can call at any time and tell her that she is wanted for a job the next day. 'If my friends are going out together, I can't say I'll come, because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get broken, but my friends are good about it. They don't say, "Oh, you're always going off modeling now, you never have time for us".' Kira has the looks, ability, and support to have a great career ahead of her. And not many people can say that before they even sit their school-leaving exams. I am about to finish the interview with the girl who has it all, and I ask what she would like to do as a career if she didn't have the outstanding beauty that seems certain to take her to the top of the profession. She pauses and replies: 'I'd like to do what you're doing.' '

**Father and Son Search for Gold**
Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from cold Canada to hot Africa to find gold. Terence is an explorer, and Chris is a mineral expert. They think their mine on a Welsh mountain might have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in Wales, they believe they are close to finding a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, who is 68 and from Liverpool, said, "We are finding a lot of gold as we dig; we just need to go a few more meters to where it is concentrated."
The Maddens have spent their lives looking for gold. Their search started when Terence read about gold in the "Dolgellau gold belt," an area near the Welsh town of Dolgellau. They studied old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth to find the best place to dig. After clearing the land and finding small pieces of gold, they spent ten years getting permission to dig, taking earth samples, and removing old cars and rubbish. They dug out 150 tonnes of rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now, they are running out of money. They need to find someone to invest £50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, it seems difficult, but we have some people we can ask."
As news of their dig spread, people in the area became interested in gold. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and locals are hopeful. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "If they find gold, more people might visit, but I hope not too many come and dig up the hillside."
The Welsh gold industry has declined since the late 1880s when many people worked in mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed recently. However, some people are still looking for gold. George Hall, another gold seeker, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the hill from the Maddens. Hall, who is 70, said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It's adventurous and exciting, like finding hidden treasure. Maybe I'll be lucky this time."

'IN HOT WATER Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she isn't teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle, like a tiny car, and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. Inside, space is so small that she can touch the two pilots. They are used to these conditions, where they can't stand or move, and must stay inside until someone opens the door from outside. A dive can last 16 hours - three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is a problem, they can press a panic button. The outside part drops away, leaving a small escape vessel that quickly goes to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it wouldn't be a pleasant trip. The first time Rachel got into the vehicle, she was on a ship's deck with an instructor. He explained the emergency procedures, like what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in such a small space. Now Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. They went to a place five days' sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. On the ocean floor, there is a large area of underwater volcanoes, with chimneys blowing out black smoke. The Russian team was placing scientific equipment there to study the effect of a program that would make a hole 150 meters through a volcano. When not at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton. Two-thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she loves, but she does it to continue her research on the "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes - water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It pours out at one meter per second and at 350 degrees. The only time Rachel was scared was when she first went down with the Americans. They were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when there was an explosion. There was a loud bang as shock waves hit their vehicle, and Rachel thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive. Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time Rachel looks out of the porthole and sees those chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, and no one else has ever seen them before. She studied the black smokers for three years for her PhD. Seeing them for real was an amazing feeling.'

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired, and my mind couldn't handle more foreign timetables, money, or languages. "Never again," I said when I got home. But I said the same thing the next year. And the year after that. I just needed to buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. Sleeping in a train corridor is different from sleeping in a bed. The train's movement helps you sleep deeply. Carrying everything in a backpack makes you travel simply. You might even burn socks that smell bad or throw away books when you're done with them. This way of thinking is part of the Inter-Rail spirit. You can forget about common sense and just enjoy the freedom. All you need is one of those tickets. This train ticket lets young people travel through many countries quickly. On my first trip, my friends and I didn't know how special this ticket was. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our camp-site in southern France. But we couldn't resist traveling more because there was always another country nearby. And it didn't cost us extra. We were not completely uninterested in culture. But this was our first holiday without parents, like most other Inter-Railers. We made our own plans and only saw the easiest sights. It was a chance to escape guided tours and do something different. I was proud that sometimes all I saw was the view from the station. We were there to enjoy ourselves. We were like other Inter-Railers, sharing train floors, food, water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from seeing a place that was just a name before. It's like the city didn't exist until you arrived and saw it with your own eyes. Only by seeing Europe, watching the landscapes change, and noticing different attitudes and lifestyles, can you really understand the continent. Everyone knows what's there, but it means nothing until you see it yourself. That's why other people's holiday photos are boring. The train trip won't show you anything new in the world, but it's a valuable personal experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail gives people the best chance to see this, though we didn't realize it right away.

'It is very disappointing to arrive at an airport in another country and find out that your baggage is not there. At best, you will have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline finds your luggage. At worst, you might be in a different climate and have to wear clothes that are not suitable. Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it is common for regular travelers to lose their luggage at some point. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and no airline can promise that your checked luggage will be on the same flight, especially if you have to change planes. 
Airlines ask passengers to check in early to give enough time for baggage to be loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest times needed to transfer between flights, and these are also set to allow for baggage transfers. Usually, the system works well. But extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights and cause the baggage system to fail. Human error or accidents, like a torn destination label, can also cause problems. These issues can be worse at large transfer airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport handled over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, mostly moving between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4. Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. The risk of losing baggage is higher at some airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when passengers connect to flights to Latin America.
To avoid losing your luggage, choose direct flights when possible and check in early. If you must change planes or if it makes your flight cheaper, try to fly with the same airline. Allow more time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses. Include the flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline official in the baggage hall and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

'The Kingfisher Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and eats fish. Old trees hang over the stream, shading the shallow water. The main colors are soft greens, mud browns, and different yellows of sunlight.
