The bird moves quickly through the scene, like a flash of light. It disappears in a second, but the image stays in your mind. Charlie James loved kingfishers from a young age. He cannot explain exactly why he loves this little bird so much. In Greek myth, the kingfisher was a moon goddess who became a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top became blue like the sky, and its bottom was burned by the sun. There is some truth in this. Kingfishers have no blue pigment in their feathers. The structure of their feathers reflects light and looks blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or green, depending on the light. Many wildlife photographers love them. Kingfishers are shy but can be watched from a hideout. Charlie James's first hideout was an old blanket over his head while he waited near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird came back in minutes and sat very close. But it took him four years to get his first good picture. During this time, the European kingfisher became very important in his life. He spent as much time as he could by a stream with many kingfishers. School was a problem because it took time away from the birds. He missed lessons and did not do well in school. But people noticed his interest in the kingfisher, the only one of its family to breed in Europe. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. He then worked as an assistant to the editor and later became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he wants to make the best kingfisher film. 'No speech, just beautiful images,' he says. 'I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings...' He stops, thinking of the bird's colors. His photos show his feelings, but he knows there is more to his relationship with the kingfisher than his work can show.'

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from Five New Conductors**
**A. ANNE MANSON**
Anne Manson, 30, had an unexpected start in conducting. She asked to watch Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna and ended up replacing an absent assistant. This led to more opportunities, and she wasn't nervous about leading her first rehearsal. Manson, originally from America, works with a London opera company that focuses on modern music. She is also gaining recognition in Europe, helped by the British Arts Council. She has worked with Abbado on several projects since then.
**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**
Andrew Constantine, 31, says the hardest part of conducting is convincing people to give you chances. He won a big competition in 1991 after failing in two others. He believes the timing was perfect, as earlier success might have been overwhelming. The competition gave him many chances to perform and work with a famous conductor. However, he worries about being known only for the competition. He hopes orchestras, like the English Chamber Orchestra, will continue to invite him back, as this is crucial for his career.
**C. WASFI KANI**
Wasfi Kani, who started Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long practice periods in opera. She began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's business district until Pimlico Opera became fully professional. Learning from Sian Edwards was a turning point for her. Seeing someone her size conduct was inspiring. She appreciates the complexity of opera, including dealing with singers' personalities.
**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**
Roger Vignoles, 48, found conducting unexpectedly fascinating. He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, which was easier than he expected. He knew the music well and aimed to achieve the performance he wanted. His musical experience has been valuable, and he is open to trying new things to discover what he enjoys.
**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**
In 1986, Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, then a young assistant conductor, and recommended him. Marshall, now 32, soon conducted a musical in London on short notice, facing challenges like musicians reading newspapers during the show. He was firm with them, always giving a clear beat. He believes many musicians don't need much guidance but isn't afraid to express his wishes. Although he hasn't formally studied conducting, he is determined and knows what he likes.

**Theme Park Reviews**
If you want to take children to a theme park in Britain, there are many options. We asked five families to try some of the best parks.
**Fun Island - The Burns Family**
Last year, we visited a big theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. But we were surprised! The park is great for young children, so our three-year-old had fun too. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older kids, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were tired, but the kids wanted to stay longer. Our only complaint is that the park could have a better atmosphere and scenery. However, the staff are very helpful, and the park is clean, well-organized, and safe.
**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a road. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to rest. The landscaping is beautiful, and the staff are friendly. There is something for everyone, including adults.
**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**
After seven hours, we still had more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus with its exciting trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared, they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you'll get wet, but you don't. Toy Land is fun for younger kids. The children wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but they were too small. The park is well-designed, so even waiting in line isn't too boring. It's very clean, and the staff are great. On one ride, a staff member offered to sit with one of my daughters when I couldn't.
**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**
We arrived at 1 p.m. and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This park is great for younger children because the rides aren't too scary. I'm usually scared, but I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then gets exciting. We waited 30 minutes for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didn't try the Big Leap, but it looked fun for those who are brave. If the children were older, they might find it a bit tame, but they loved it.
**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**
The park says there is 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we agree. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is very scary, but Ben loved it. Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, and the older kids went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. The staff were mixed; some were great with young kids, but not all were friendly. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We couldn't tell the kids we were leaving early!

'Running a business in the countryside Five women share their experiences of starting a business in the countryside. A. 'My customers are friends,' says CHRISTINE HOGAN, who runs a computer-aided design business. She earns over £200,000 a year and has four full-time employees. 'My husband and I moved from London to the countryside when our children were small. I wanted a job I could do from home. I had worked with computers before, so my husband suggested starting a computer-aided design business. It needed a lot of money, and it was hard at first. But I was careful with money and always informed the bank if I might spend too much. Working from home saves money, and I can work in the evening if I want. It is still a small business. We rarely deliver work; local people usually pick it up.' B. 'I enjoy being independent,' says MAGGY SASANOW, who designs greeting cards from home. 'I studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum. But when I got married, we moved to the countryside, where there were no such jobs. So, I started my own business and created 50 greeting cards that I sell to museums. I work in a large room upstairs. The downside of working from home is that there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. My business grows by word of mouth—I don't advertise. People send work from London because I am cheaper than other artists. Working alone means I don't share ideas with others, but there are more benefits than drawbacks.' C. 'It has been hard at times,' says DELIA TURNER, who makes curtains. 'I started my business eight years ago. At first, the business grew, and my earnings went from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. I used to have six full-time workers. But I had to let them go because the economy got worse, which was hard because jobs are scarce here. Now, I am almost back to the start, making curtains at home with my husband's help and using women who work from their homes. I have to be ready to lower my prices when needed and look for new opportunities.' D. TESSA STRICKLAND runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. 'I moved to the countryside three years ago for two reasons. First, because London was too expensive, and second, because I love the countryside. I like working when I want. Eighty percent of my income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so I have to take calls at odd hours. The downside is that it takes discipline to stop working. I publish children's books from different cultures, working with authors and artists. All my work experience was in London, so I felt very alone at first.' E. MEG RIVERS runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop, earning £250,000 a year and employing six people, some part-time. 'I started ten years ago at home. I am very interested in health, so I began making fruit cakes with good quality flour and eggs. Then friends and family started asking for them, and soon I was sending cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, I rented a small building, and everything is made there now—we have a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. I don't bake anymore; I manage the business side. My biggest challenge has been the financial side because we didn't have a lot of money to start with.'

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**
The Watkins family is special because they are all involved in music. The sons, Paul and Huw, are talented musicians and composers, and their father, John, makes musical instruments. 
When Paul was ten years old, he needed a cello. John and Hetty, his parents, found that buying one was too expensive. So, John decided to learn how to make one himself. He attended evening classes at the Welsh School of Instrument Making for about three years. After practicing with violins and violas, John made his first cello for Paul. It was so good that Paul used it for many years.
John eventually left his teaching job to become a full-time instrument maker. He now makes about twelve violins a year. One of his violins was even bought by the famous American musician Jaime Laredo.
Both Paul and Huw started playing music when they were young. Paul first played the piano and then chose the cello because he admired a cellist in his father's music group. Huw, on the other hand, decided to play the piano and compose music. He was inspired by Paul's success but was never pushed by his parents.
Paul achieved great success with the cello his father made. He won the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at the age of 20. Recently, he started playing a very old and valuable cello, a Francesco Rugeri, which is on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. Paul will soon perform on television with this cello, but he won't be able to watch it because he has a concert the same night. Huw also has a performance that evening, as his String Quartet will be played in London for the first time.
John and Hetty will have to be very organized to keep up with their sons' busy musical schedules.

'Looking after the countryside THE NATIONAL TRUST The National Trust is an organization that works to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden for the Trust. Gareth says a warden needs common sense and must be good with people because they work with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and builders. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people wanted the warden job, but Gareth got it because he knew the area well and had farming experience, even though he didn't have formal training. He still helps on his parents' farm, which helps him understand farmers' problems. His farming background also helps him with the physical work like building fences, planting trees, and making walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers collecting flowers and bird nests as a child and realizes now that farming has changed the countryside. He believes it's not the farmers' fault because they followed government advice. When Gareth started, farmers and conservationists disagreed, but now they talk and understand each other better. Conservation is a big part of Gareth's job, along with allowing public access to Trust land, planting trees, and meeting with tenant farmers. He likes seeing projects finished, although he spends a lot of time on paperwork. Gareth loves his job, even though he is always working. He enjoys talking to the public, but some people annoy him when they act like they own the place. If you have common sense and like outdoor work, you might want to be a warden like Gareth, but don't expect a job on the Lleyn Peninsula soon!'

**The Netball Captain**
In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is preparing for next month's World Championships. Her days are busy with teaching at a local school and training in a supermarket car park. I asked her if people look at her strangely. She said, "I'm too focused on my movements to notice. I might see cars slow down, but that's all."
Kendra's life is all about being her best for the Championships. She follows a strict plan to be very fit. This is her fourth World Championships, and 27 nations will join. "We'll have home support, which is special," she says. "It's important to improve netball's reputation in our country. A home crowd will expect us to start well."
Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "We have always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have lots of ability." England is ranked fourth in the world. The World Championships are tough. "You play every day with no rest. You only have one chance to win."
In her 15 years at the top level, netball has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive. "You train to win," says Kendra. "But after the game, we're all friendlier."
Netball now uses a scientific approach to fitness. "We must think and train like world-class players," says Kendra. "As captain, I need a strong mental attitude and must lead by example. I support and encourage my team."
Kendra's netball career has been carefully planned. She decided this competition will be her last as a player. She might coach young players in the future, but now she focuses on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.

**Specialist Music Schools**
How can parents help a child with great musical talent? It is not always easy to know the best way to support their gift. Some parents might not notice their child's needs until the child becomes frustrated and difficult. Most schools can help children who are good at academic subjects, but musically talented children need special support that regular schools might not offer, especially if music is not a main focus.
Children with musical talent, encouraged by parents or teachers, might benefit from attending a specialist music school. There are five such schools in Britain. These schools provide a supportive environment for children aged seven to eighteen to develop their musical skills with professional musicians. At these schools, children spend one-third to half of their day on music activities like lessons, orchestras, and music theory. They also practice for several hours a day in special rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program focusing on essential subjects like English, math, science, and languages. Students can study more subjects if they want.
All five British specialist music schools are independent, with small classes and many teachers. Most students live at the school, which means they spend a lot of time with others who have similar interests. 
What are the disadvantages? One problem is the cost; fees are high (£12,000-£17,000 a year for boarders). However, schools try to help parents with scholarships and financial aid. Also, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. School directors often question if it is good to admit children as young as seven into such a strict environment. They aim to help children become well-rounded individuals.
There is a risk that separating musically talented children early can cause stress. Musical talent might fade during teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to a feeling of failure. But specialist schools monitor students closely and offer help if needed. Many former students feel they gained a lot from the music teaching, but some worry about the limited academic program. Many musically talented children are also smart and can handle academic challenges, so they might feel frustrated if their academic needs are not met.
For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is older and can decide for themselves about specialist education. Children who are also good academically might do well in a regular school with a strong music program or by combining regular school with music training at a music college. These colleges offer Saturday lessons and music experiences, but this option is not possible for families far from major cities.

'An eye for detail Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her large garden around her house gives her many ideas for her art. The garden is full of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread everywhere. The garden has a nice mix of colors and shapes, thanks to the previous owners who loved gardening. They left plants that Susan likes. She also got the gardener, Danny, from them. 'It was really his garden,' she says. 'We got along well. At first, he didn't agree with some of my ideas, but when I said I wanted to paint them, he understood.' Susan likes to paint detailed pictures of single plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints a group of plants where they are, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. 'I don't set everything up at once,' she says. 'I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then I add another one.' Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. 'They all bloom together, and you're so busy,' she says. She also likes watching them change as they age. For example, tulips change shape and open up after being in water for a day. Susan has always loved plants. 'I studied botany at school and collected wildflowers,' she says. 'I didn't like garden flowers then; I thought they looked fake. I liked wildflowers because they grew in difficult places.' Now, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they fit well in her garden. She lets the garden grow freely, like an aunt who lets children play as long as they don't cause harm. With two exhibitions coming up, she finds it hard to work in the garden. She has hired another gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her work, 'you have to get your hands dirty.'

**Keeping the Holiday-Makers Happy**
Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a 24-year-old from West Sussex. She works as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. This is her second year doing this job. People call her "Pilch." She works for a company that takes care of visitors who come to ski. These visitors stay in wooden houses called chalets.
Sarah studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University. She graduated last summer. She says being a chalet girl is not a career, but it's a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more serious job. "It's a good way to meet successful people," she says.
Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet. The chalet can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast first, then prepares breakfast for the guests. They get porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms. She says cleaning is the worst part of the job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. She skis as much as she can. "On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m."
Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower before cooking but does not sleep. "It's bad if you do," she says. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. Sarah cleans up after dinner and loads the dishwasher. "I don't like coming to a messy kitchen in the morning." Sometimes she talks with the guests, other times they prefer to be alone. "Good guests can make a week great, but some weeks are not as good."
Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives, and they go out around 11 p.m. "We usually start at Bananas, then maybe go to G Jay's, and end at Dick's T-Bar," she says. But she never stays out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. "It's a tough day," she says. "You don't want to cook breakfast when you're tired."
On Sunday, work starts earlier. Breakfast for guests must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. "We clean everything, clear breakfast, strip the beds, and get everything ready." If she hasn't shopped on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for new guests. "They arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. I think it's the mountain air."
Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need boots or skis. She takes them to the ski shop and gets a ride back to the chalet. Soon, it's time for dinner again and maybe a chat with friends, but not always. "Sometimes I'm so tired I just go to bed early," she says.

'Changing lives with a Stranger
Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent the day at the magazine Marie Claire. 'Choosing what to wear was hard because I usually wear a uniform at work. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, and here I was rushing around. Some of the fashion team seemed stressed - my job isn't like that. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed thinking I'd usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I'm interested in how magazines work, but I love my job at the zoo, so I'll stay there.'
Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent the day at London Zoo. 'I arrived at the zoo in leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. As I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad but had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I might work with elephants, maybe in Africa.'
Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, went with the TV gardening programme Ground Force. 'I was excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was nice. I liked being in the fresh air. Sometimes, I don't see daylight because of my shifts. It was hard work but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. My idea of gardening didn't include hard work or planning. I'm more enthusiastic than effective, so I won't leave my job.'
Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener with Ground Force, worked at Hammersmith Hospital. 'I made beds and gave out tablets. I thought I would faint, but I was okay. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is a waste of time compared to nursing. My day at the hospital wasn't pleasant, but it gave me a great sense of satisfaction.'
Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent the day with Ryanair as cabin crew. 'I changed into the uniform, and I felt different - people looked up to you. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt self-conscious. On the return journey, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one adult to look after.'
Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent the day as a personal trainer in a gym. 'I was worried about this swap because I don't exercise. I was amazed at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, you meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was surprised at lunch to see some trainers didn't eat very healthily, but they all drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this. However, it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier.''

'On the rails Five celebrities share their favorite railway journey memories with Andrew Morgan. A Andrea Thompson - Newsreader I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit often. There's a local train from Cannes along the coast that crosses into Italy. It takes you past amazing sea views. It doesn't matter what the weather is like or the time of year, it is always beautiful. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. You feel like you are looking into the lives of the rich and famous. The travelers are always lively because there is a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking journey. Raj Patel - Explorer I have enjoyed many rail journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which runs across the desert in northern Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park. I was considered too young and was sent to an aunt. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn't traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its great glass dome amazed me. Betty Cooper - Novelist I am grateful to one train: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said pink is good for the brain, and I've worn it ever since. What I remember about the journey is how nice it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor. It was the perfect way to relax after the wedding. Martin Brown - Journalist We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in an African country. There wasn't a road, so we took the Desert Express. The timetable was unreliable - we were just given a day. We heard the driver would wait for days if he knew people were coming. When it appeared, hundreds of people climbed into and onto the carriages - people even traveled on the roof for free. During the night, the train crossed beautiful landscapes. It was like a dream, like traveling across the moon. Arisu Mezuki - Actress Most people have favorite train memories from childhood, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw few trains. It wasn't until I was a teenager that trains became important to me. I made a film with a railway in Yorkshire. Most filming was on an old line maintained by volunteers. That's where my love for steam trains began. When we weren't filming, we rode the train, and when I went back last year, it was like time had stood still. Everything was still there, even the gas lights on the station platform!'

'Want to get published? If you are thinking about where to send your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has the advice you need. Readers of this magazine often ask, 'I have written this story/book. Who should I send it to?' The first thing they need to know is that they should research their markets and learn about publishers while improving their writing skills. Selling your writing takes a lot of knowledge about the 'writing world'. Whatever kind of writing you do, you need to know about the markets you are aiming for. The best way to do this is by reading everything you can find. Use your local library and visit local bookshops and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what kinds of writing publishers are accepting at any time. This knowledge must be updated as new publications appear, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. New titles come and go all the time. Publishers always want new writers; as writers, we must give them what they want. At first, you may not be sure what you want to write. Let's say you want to write short love stories. The first thing you must do is find out which magazines publish love stories, and get as many recent copies as you can. Then learn about the kind of stories they are buying and who the readers are. These readers expect different things from their magazine, and the editor wants to meet their needs. Writers often send me their stories saying, 'This has been rejected three times - am I wasting my time? Do I have a chance?' As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone. But it is unlikely that the work is ready to be published; so I try to give an honest opinion, but always positively. The problem is that most new writers are too eager to send their work out, usually before they are ready. If you have only written one story or article, it is not likely to be published. That almost never happens. When you read about 'success', you usually find that the person has been in publishing or journalism for years before their success. When you send off your work for the first time, start working on more stories while you wait for a reply; write ten more stories, even twenty. Each one will be better than the last, and you will start to think of yourself as a writer, and your fluency and confidence will grow. Don't throw any of them away - improve them instead. Also, I advise not showing your work to anyone else, especially in the early stages. Remember that every successful writer has had many rejections before succeeding. Do everything you can to advance your career as a writer. See if there's a creative writing course near you. If not, try joining a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing - every day if possible.'

On the last day of a bad year, I was at the Baltimore railway station. I was waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I expected. The station didn't feel as clean and airy as usual. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and college students sat on the floor with their bags. 
A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to strangers. He looked well-off: tanned skin, nice sweater, and a soft, beige coat. He asked a woman sitting alone a question, then went to a girl near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I might like to talk to her. The man asked, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" 
She said, "I'm going north, but to New York." He thanked her and moved on. Now, I was interested. I heard him ask an old lady, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said, "Wilmington," and he moved on to another couple. 
I was going to Philadelphia, but he didn't ask me. Maybe I looked unreliable. He glanced at me and went to another bench. He looked stressed. "Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Are you going to Philadelphia?" 
She said, "Yes, I am." 
"Could I ask you a favor?" he asked. I pretended to check my watch, even though I didn't have one. The woman seemed cautious. The man said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" 
They announced my train. People started moving to Gate E. I heard the man say, "My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. She forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia and didn't know what to do." 
The woman listened. I would have waited to see what he wanted. "I told her to stay there, and I would find someone to bring her passport." 
Why didn't he go himself? The woman asked, "Why don't you go yourself?" 
"I can't leave my wife alone. She's in a wheelchair," he said. This seemed like a weak excuse. I looked at them. The man held a padded envelope, not a plain one. It looked stapled shut. I thought, "Be careful, lady."

**Gary and Me**
John Moore, a restaurant owner, writes about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes everyone gets a chance in life. Gary's chance was cooking, and John's chance was running a restaurant. When John found the restaurant, it was in bad condition, but he thought it was perfect for his plans. This reminded him of his childhood when his mother worked in a factory, and he was left alone. He wanted to have time for family life, so his wife took care of the children and did the accounts while he ran the business. They lived above the restaurant and always had meals together, which helped their children, Gary and Joe, become confident. From a young age, Gary and Joe talked to the regular customers, which gave them a good start in life.
Gary was a lively child. Once, when he was seven, he jumped into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he worked for pocket money, starting with odd jobs and then working in the kitchen every weekend by the age of ten. He was disciplined and often woke up before his father. Gary wasn't very academic, but he was excellent in the kitchen. By 15, he was as good as the men working there and sometimes was in charge, making over a hundred meals. John knew Gary would go into catering because he had a talent for it. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend's restaurant.
Gary recently started playing the drums and has his own band. John worries about what will happen to Gary's cooking if the music becomes successful. He advises Gary to focus on one thing, saying, "If you chase two hares, you catch neither." John told Gary that he needed to succeed by the age of 30. Gary went to catering college at 17, and on his first day, he finished a morning's work in an hour and helped others. John is very proud of Gary's successful TV cookery series. He always told Gary that if you want something, you have to work hard for it. Gary has taken his opportunity and succeeded. John is happy that Gary listened to some of his advice.

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you could afford was very difficult. The best way was through personal contacts: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a place, that often worked. But if, like Jo, you had just arrived in Dublin, you had no personal contacts, no one to tell you about a vacant place. So, you had to stay in a hostel and search. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown. She felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she took the train to work there. She didn't question why she was going. Everyone at her school assumed she would leave. Who would stay in a small, boring town? That's all she heard for years. Everyone wanted to leave, see life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family would help them settle. But none from Jo's year were going to Dublin. She was going alone. Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed in the hostel permanently. It was run by nuns, so she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm because hostels were known to be cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay a whole week in a hostel. But Jo didn't know they were still thinking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. It said, 'Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was near the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. She hoped it would be nice, that they would like her, and that it wouldn't be too expensive. There wasn't a queue because it was more 'Third Girl Wanted' than 'Flat to Let'. The 'own television' part made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary. It was a red-brick terraced house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, who was obviously not chosen, was coming down the stairs. 'Desperate place,' she said to Jo. 'They're both awful. Common as dirt.' 'Oh,' said Jo and continued climbing. 'Hello,' said a girl with 'Nessa' on her T-shirt. 'Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type.' 'What did she do?' asked Jo. 'Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, "Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear," in a posh accent. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?' Pauline wore a very colorful shirt, almost as bright as her hair. Pauline was a punk, which amazed Jo. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but hadn't talked to one. 'I'm Jo, I work in the post office and I called.' Nessa said they were about to have tea. She brought out three mugs; one said 'Nessa', one said 'Pauline', and the other said 'Other'. 'We'll put your name on it if you stay,' she said kindly.

'Behind the dolphin's smile People love dolphins. We like to see them in seaside marinas, films, and TV shows. But the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about how dolphins are disappearing. Dolphins are special to us. They are very smart, understand human feelings, and make us dream of freedom in the sea. TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest make us love them more. But these shows do not show the real problems dolphins face in polluted and overfished seas. The number of North Sea harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think dolphins are protected by law and live in safe marine areas. But this is not true, and not helping them could be a big wildlife problem. There are forty kinds of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and harbour porpoises. The first two live far out at sea and are seen only in small groups. We know little about them. The large grey bottlenoses and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenoses are very social and were found on the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only in the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few left have skin injuries, showing they are stressed. Dolphins have complex habits, making it hard to know why their numbers are falling. Overfishing, which reduces fish stocks and threatens fishing industries, also threatens dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly. If fish are taken by fishing, they may not find food in time. They can also get caught in fishing nets, which they cannot see. Modern fishing uses big nets that float or move fast through the sea. Many dead dolphins have been found on French and Cornwall beaches. Marks and cuts show they died from being caught in nets. Waste and chemicals in the sea can build up in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can absorb them. These poisons can pass to their young through milk. There is a case of a young dolphin dying from its mother's milk. Another big threat to dolphins is human disturbance. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise from ships and oil wells travels four times better than in the air. This noise may disturb dolphins in ways we do not yet know.'

'GETTING FIT Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced when life feels busy and stressful. You might think this is just another article about fitness, but there are many good reasons to exercise. Exercise is good for you. It makes your muscles stronger and changes your body shape quickly. It helps you stand or sit correctly, which is called good posture. Good posture prevents muscle problems that can cause injuries. Exercise also helps your heart, lungs, and blood circulation. You might have heard these reasons before and feel bored, but here are some more reasons to exercise. Exercise can help with depression, tiredness, and sleep problems. It also helps control stress and can help with some medical conditions. If these reasons don't convince you, common sense should tell you that exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, jogging, or lifting weights. But be careful not to train too hard or lift too much weight, as this can cause injuries. Start slowly and carefully. If you're unsure, ask your doctor what is best for you. Good posture is important for your body shape. A stiff or slouching body can look unattractive and feel tired. If you slouch, imagine a balloon pulling your head up to the sky. This will help you stand straighter and breathe better. Stretching your muscles makes you more flexible and helps prevent injuries. Stretching should be part of your exercise routine and should be done slowly and carefully. The best exercise routine includes a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.'

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**
What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their home comforts for months? They are looking for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, two of the hardest people to find are producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. They are currently in the Ngorongoro Crater, where it has rained almost non-stop for six months, causing many problems. Newman said they had to buy an expensive tool so that when their vehicle gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him out. Their teamwork has created some of TV's best wildlife films, like their popular film on leopards. Even while this film was being shown, they were back in the wild, this time following the shy jackal. This is common for TV partnerships. Travelling film-makers have been going around the world to film exotic wildlife since TV began.
I talked to Newman about their partnership while he was briefly meeting other people at a safari lodge. 'We sometimes argue but we get over it quickly,' he says about his colleague. Neither of them sees themselves as the leader, and they get along well because they both see animals in the same way. 'When we travel, we set up our tents each night. But now we have a fixed camp, and since we start at 5 a.m. each morning, we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask.' Their daily meals are pre-packed and heated by whoever is available. 'We can be out for up to eight weeks, so food can be a problem,' says Newman. It can be tough, but being alone in remote areas lets them get close to the animals. Newman remembers filming a lion family where one lioness would greet their car as part of her routine.
Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called 'The Great Rift', and two years later, they filmed Arctic foxes together. Since then, they spend four months on location to get enough material for each half-hour film. Before starting, they must submit a script for approval. 'Amanda and I had a good working relationship from the start,' says Newman, 'because we shared the same ideas and vision. We want to make films that are rich in atmosphere, show the true spirit of the place and animals, and touch people's hearts. I believe it's better to make people feel something than just think about it.'

**The Netball Captain**
In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she had a typical day: teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I was surprised about her training place. 'Don't people look at you strangely?' I asked. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice,' she said. 'I might see cars slow down, but that's all.'
'My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships,' says Kendra. She follows a strict plan to be very fit. These are her fourth World Championships, with 27 countries taking part. 'We'll have home support, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to improve netball's reputation in our country. Playing here means more pressure. People expect us to start well.' Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'We have always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have lots of skill.'
The England team is ranked fourth in the world. But the World Championships will be tough. 'You have to play every day, with no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win. But in the Championships, there's only one chance,' Kendra explains. In her 15 years of playing at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive. 'You train to win,' says Kendra. 'But after the game, we're all friendlier.'
Netball now uses a more scientific approach to fitness. 'We must think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. As captain, she believes it's important to have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. 'I support and encourage the team,' she says.
'From the start, my netball career was carefully planned,' she says. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She might coach young players in the future, but now she focuses on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

'In hot water Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she isn't teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle, about the size of a small car, and dives three kilometres down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 'Inside,' she says, 'space is so limited that I can touch the two pilots. We can't stand up or move, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours - three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours gathering rock and water samples, and then three hours to return to the surface.' 'If there is a problem and we need to get to the top quickly, we can press a panic button. The outside drops away, leaving a small escape vessel that goes quickly to the surface. No-one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a pleasant journey.' 'I didn't know how I would react the first time I got into the vehicle. It was on a ship's deck, and I got in with an instructor. He explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack! They were testing me to see how I would react in such a small space.' Now Rachel has made six dives. Last year she dived with a Russian crew. 'We went to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. Here, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes, with chimneys blowing out black smoke. It is where the Atlantic Ocean comes alive. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study the effect of a multi-national programme that would make a hole 150 metres through a volcano.' When she isn't at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton. 'Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research into the "black smokers". This is another name for underwater volcanoes - water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It pours out at a rate of one metre per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees.' 'The only time I was frightened was when I first went down with the Americans. We were towing equipment on a 50-metre rope when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a loud bang as the shock waves hit our vehicle, and I thought, "I'm going to die." We stared at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we couldn't believe it. The relief was incredible - we were still alive!' 'It's such an adventure diving to the deepest part of the ocean. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, there is a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no-one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my Ph.D. When I got down there and saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling.'

**Interview Tips**
First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, body movement, how fast or slow we talk, our volume and tone of voice, and our words.
Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, "I worked hard to earn my degree. When I graduated, I was very confident." She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she recalls. "I would have changed, but I knew it would make me late, and I always think it's important to be on time." Mary didn't get the job. Her friend, who also teaches at the school, told her the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?"
Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "Interviewees who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should try to look your best." Many people ignore the importance of having a professional image. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but didn't get an interview. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what happened," she says. "He told me I didn't fit the image of an office manager. He suggested I improve my wardrobe before I applied again for promotion. I was shocked. I do a very good job, and the way I dress shouldn't make any difference."
Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of any message about our feelings and attitudes comes from words, 38% from voice, and 55% from facial expressions. If our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will believe the non-verbal message more. So make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages will confuse the interviewer.
It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went so well she was offered the job immediately. "I was delighted," she recalls. "But I reacted with too much enthusiasm. Once the boss saw how excited I was, he knew I wouldn't turn him down. So, he offered me a lower salary than I wanted. I'm sure I could have got more if I had controlled my excitement."
Finally, what we say and how we say it is important for a successful interview. David Artesio, the manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about areas of company involvement. Mention an area that interests you during the interview. This will give a positive note and show your interest in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confused sentences. As she says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and even in highlighted points."

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years, working in the City became boring. I didn't plan to leave for another five or ten years, but then I lost my job unexpectedly. I didn't get much money, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with a top restaurant. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm happy not to be in an office anymore, but I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and sell a product."
**The Painter**
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now works as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. So, I decided to leave my job and become an artist. The career counselor I spoke to was surprised because most people my age need to work for money. But my wife and I married young, and our children didn't need our support. We moved to the north of England, where we didn't know anyone. We left our friends, but they still visit us."
**The Hat Maker**
Katherine Goodison was a company lawyer for five years before starting her own business making hats in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and paid well, but the hours were long. I didn't want to work more hours as a senior partner, so I left. Some people thought I would get bored, but I haven't. The secret is having deadlines. In fashion, there are always new collections and seasons, so I have to keep a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I miss socializing with colleagues, but I love being responsible for my product. If I do a bad job, it's my fault."
**The Masseur**
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, making deals. I liked the excitement but didn't find the work rewarding. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I quit and traveled for a year. During that time, I thought about what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gyms and talked to the owners. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I feel in control of my life now."

'Dedicated to their sports Four young sports stars talk about their lives. A Darius (runner) I've always loved sports. I tried many different ones, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I had a chance to join a professional football club, but I chose athletics instead. My biggest moment was when I competed for my country in the youth team and won a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped to get some sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun there because of the great athletics facilities and nightlife. But I have to be disciplined. If friends ask me to go out the night before training, I have to say no. I wish I didn't, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to get to the next Olympics - that would be amazing. B Gabriel (surfer) The surfing community is small, so you meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn, so you can't go to late-night parties. I don't mind that much, but I love sleeping in, and I usually have to give that up too. But it's worth it because, without dedication, I might not have won the National Championships last year. After a win, I make sure to have a big night out, and if there's prize money, I'll go somewhere nice. The sacrifices are worth it because winning the championship got me a job presenting a surfing series on TV. I guess I'm a bit of a celebrity now. C Dieter (yacht racer) With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We're traditional and always celebrate a win in style. Some say we act childishly when we're out, but we don't look for media attention. Sometimes reporters care more about where we celebrate than how we did in the race. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's great to come back and hang out with friends from different backgrounds. You can't focus on the sport all the time - it's not healthy. I'm known in sailing, but I've only been recognized in the street a few times. I'd hate to be a celebrity. I get nice letters from people asking for signed pictures, and I reply to every one. It takes time, but it's important to me. D Tomas (tennis player) It's great to walk on court and feel the crowd's support. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with people crowding around. Still, I enjoy being noticed by fans when I'm out shopping. But it has downsides. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up, I think. It was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in any sport; you have to be serious and professional. It doesn't bother me too much. I'm happy to focus on my game now and enjoy other things in life after I retire, which happens early in this sport.'

**Young Shoppers**
Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it's not the latest sugary breakfast cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually all three. I can't afford all this, and I feel guilty about buying unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get upset even before we leave home. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make their own choices. I can't win."
Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This number is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents say no to buying things, and they find it hard to believe that sugar is bad for their teeth when they see fun and exciting ads.
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with ads and having to say no to their children all the time."
The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb points out, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can't say, 'Tell your mum to buy this,' that's still what they want."
Some parents find it stressful to decide which things to buy for their children and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and ads. Her son is critical of ads, and they look at labels together. She says, "I've talked so much that I've made him think all ads are rubbish. We don't have many arguments in the supermarket now because the children don't ask for things I won't buy."
Parents also admit they are not always consistent. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We say no to sweets because they're bad for him, but we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It's fun to buy nice things, and it's normal for children to want that too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on how I feel. If I'm in a good mood, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing play areas for children. Even if parents spend less because their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without a child's demands might attract more customers.

**Title: The Merrion Hotel: Luxury and Modern Technology**
The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It was created by turning four large old houses into a modern hotel. This allowed the hotel to include the latest technology for both staff and guests.
The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, like guest preferences, he uses a computer system. This system, which cost £250,000, helps treat returning guests in a special way. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them next time. The system remembers guest preferences.
Room temperature is important for comfort. Guests can change the temperature in their room a little, but the front desk can adjust it more if needed. Business guests will like the technology in the rooms. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that is also a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing tool. The hotel has extra cables for future technology updates. TVs and DVD recorders can be easily upgraded.
Despite all this technology, the rooms are comfortable and welcoming. The hotel has 145 large, well-furnished bedrooms, a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.
The food at the hotel is excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who had two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This is good for both him and the hotel. He has a modern kitchen and better parking. The hotel benefits from having a popular restaurant without financial risk.
With great technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is set to succeed.

'Where I get my energy Emma Marsden asked six women who live life fully to tell us how they do it. A. Jeanette Kupfermann Journalist and author: 'I think it's excitement. I need to do something challenging. If I'm learning something new, I get a lot of energy. Anything with rhythm gives me energy, too - right now I'm learning flamenco dancing. Dance is wonderful, very expressive, and gives energy. I think you can feel tired if you're bored or feel life has no purpose. Being effective in the world - even in a small way - gives you energy.' B. Linda Kelsey Magazine editor: 'I have a lot of work but I enjoy it - I love being at work, it isn't a chore. If you enjoy something, it doesn't make you feel low even if you're tired. I need a lot of sleep, so when I get it, I feel good. When I only get six hours of sleep, I feel a bit down. I know exercise gives me energy, but it's hard to find the energy to do it! I do a yoga class once a week before work and try to do a workout at home. But if I've done exercise, my mood improves a lot. I feel low in the office between 3 and 5 in the afternoon and think it's good to eat something then.' C. Annie Nightingale Disc jockey: 'I don't eat healthily to get my energy - I think it's natural enthusiasm and being positive. I really can't stand people with negative attitudes. I'm quite naive - I think we should all enjoy our lives, live in the moment. Enjoyment comes first. You have to achieve things and set goals. I enjoy what I do and the last two years have been very exciting. In my job, there are lots of lively young people and you can't help being affected by that. I love rushing around for work, having a busy life. I'm very sociable. I enjoy taking photos but I'm not sure if I'm good at it. I rush to get them developed and can't wait to see them. I've also started writing words for imaginary songs - it's just for fun and it's a good way to relax my mind when I'm traveling.' D. Floella Benjamin Author and children's TV presenter: 'My energy comes from things I do and enjoy. I believe in what I'm doing, both at work and at home with my family, and I think being positive about life helps. That's why I love working with kids, they give so much and have a natural resilience. Energy is like a natural chemical, triggered by communicating with others - just try smiling at people and feel the thrill when they smile back. It's much better than feeling sorry for yourself. Although I try to eat healthily and don't smoke or drink, I don't have an exercise plan. The most energetic I get is running around with the kids and playing with them.' E. Deborah Moggach Author and playwright: 'What I love doing more than anything is making a garden out of wasteland. I did that once. The garden was solid concrete - I broke all the concrete and added a lot of soil. It was better than any workout or tennis. The other thing that gives me energy is knowing that someone wants to read what I'm writing - I find it hard to write without an audience. And I like sneaking into a farmer's land or a wood. If I'm found, I say "Oh, what a wonderful wood, I didn't know it was private," and so on. I like it because it's childlike.' F. Katherine Monblot Therapist: 'I believe you must have an interest in and respect for what you do in life. I like to take risks and I get bored quickly, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you don't want to do makes you tired. I used to be a member of various committees and didn't like the demands they made on my time. You only have a certain amount of energy, so use it for the things that are most important to you.' '

**ICE SKATING**
Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists found skates made from animal bones. People used these bone skates until about 200 AD when iron skates came to Scandinavia. In Scandinavia, the upper classes thought skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was stylish and calm. But at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie showed a more athletic style, making skating more popular. Today, skating combines art and athletics, making it graceful and physically challenging.
For beginners, balance and control are very important. You can go faster as you get better. Your body position helps with balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees bent to keep your weight centered. Your body should lean a little forward. Relaxation is very important in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It seems easy, right? As you practice, you can make your movements longer.
Learning how to fall is one of the first skills for skaters. Even the best skaters fall. To fall without getting hurt, try to stay relaxed. This way, the impact is softer. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand. Once you can move confidently on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. The best way to start is to learn figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer lessons to help you learn the basic moves, and soon you can try turns, jumps, and spins.
If you watch good or professional skaters, you will see how relaxed they are and how smoothly they move. To be like them, you should do regular exercises. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises are important. Focus on your legs, back, shoulders, ankles, and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness.
Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also improves heart and lung health and makes the body stronger. When combined with swimming or jogging, it is a great way to stay healthy and fit.

**Young Stars and Their Lives**
**A. Annika Reeder, 15**  
Annika won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The work is very hard now. I don't have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gym and school. I try to take training one day at a time. When I'm very tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can't take too many days off, or you get stiff."
**B. Annika's Mother**  
"Annika showed great potential from a young age. Some parents push their children, but it doesn't work. To perform at Annika's level, you have to want it yourself. People say we've given up a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it's done for Annika. Before gym, she was shy and hid behind me, but now she's met people worldwide and gained confidence."
**C. Sarah Stokes**  
Sarah started show-jumping at ten and won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere. Shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of it; I love show-jumping events. Even without my parents, I would do it because I'm determined. I'm glad they are happy when I win, but I do it for myself. My goal this year is to join the British young riders team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."
**D. Sarah's Mother**  
"Sarah loved horses from age 1. At 5, she got up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, you have to jump all over England. We save money by sleeping in our horse box. Sarah is well-organized and happy on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is wonderful."
**E. Jane McShane, 10**  
Jane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When playing, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around. I'm not afraid of getting a big head. I don't talk about my success at school because I don't like embarrassment."
**F. Jane's Mother**  
"Jane played her first game at 5. My father said, 'Let's see if she likes it.' He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. I'm happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to put her down because she's exceptional. If she has this gift, let her reach her potential."

'It's true - we're all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. 'What do you want to be?' asked the teacher. 'The flagpole on a ship?' The teacher had a point because Chris, at fourteen, was already almost two metres tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe grows by another centimetre. Every year, more tall people are born. Interestingly, this does not mean we are creating a new super race. In fact, we are returning to what we were like as cavemen. We are losing the effects of generations of poor diet, with big changes. 'We are only now beginning to reach our true potential,' says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer. 'We are becoming like Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived on this planet 40,000 years ago.' For most of human history, our ancestors got their food from many sources: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found that they based their diet on 85 different wild plants. Then about 9,000 years ago, farming was invented, with big consequences. Most of the planet's green places have been taken over by farmers, so just three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories we eat today. This poor diet has had a bad effect on human health and body size. Over the centuries, we have lived on soups, porridges, and breads that have left us underfed and underdeveloped. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when they began to grow corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly, underweight farmers. Tooth decay increased, as did diseases. Corn was a public health problem, according to some anthropologists. However, farming spread because a piece of farmed land could support ten times the number of people who had lived off it as hunter-gatherers. The fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished and stunted has only recently been addressed, even by the world's wealthier nations. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets again reflecting the richness of our ancestors' diets. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. It is a welcome trend, though not without its own problems. Heights may have risen, but the world has not changed much. A standard bed-length has remained at 190 cm since 1860. Even worse, leg-room in planes and trains seems to have shrunk, while clothes manufacturers are constantly having to change their products. The question is: where will it all end? We cannot grow forever. We must have some upper limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, of University, it could be as much as 193 cm - and we are likely to reach it this century. However, scientists add one note of caution. Individuals may be growing taller because of better nutrition, but as a species, we are actually shrinking. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller - an evolutionary response to the cold. (Large, round bodies are best at keeping in heat.) Since the climate warmed, we appear to have become slightly thinner and smaller, even when properly fed. And as the planet continues to heat up, we may shrink even further. In other words, the growth of human beings could be offset by global warming.'

'Studio Audiences What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of TV, but many people don't understand them. When we see them excited on game shows, we wonder - who are these people? Some think studio audiences are not very important. Even people who work in TV sometimes don't respect them. I thought studio audiences were just people wanting to be on TV for a moment. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from all backgrounds and jobs. TV tries to get different people for different shows. People who like watching TV at home don't understand why others go to a studio. Why get tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in an uncomfortable studio to watch something you can see at home? One idea is that people want to be on TV for a second. I didn't believe this until I talked to Angela. She said she came for a chance to be on TV. Another idea is that people are curious to see behind the scenes. But most people said they came because a friend gave them a ticket. Few of us have been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it's like. You sit with strangers, and someone shows cards that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you clap or laugh. This might be true for some shows, but not all. A studio manager said, 'We hope a show is good enough not to need these signs.' Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, sitting in a studio is 'more exciting', and Charlotte liked being part of live TV. 'Last year I saw my favorite comedian. At home, you miss a lot.' I missed seeing live actors because I could only see the back of someone's head. The first scenes were so far away that I watched on a studio screen. Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most people, it was just fun and a free night out.'

**Favourite Places**
**Bruce**  
I don't like wild landscapes. I like places with people. When I travel, I like villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I cycled to the village of Lastingham. Cycling was a break from school. I loved exploring the hilltops, valleys, and old villages. I am from Scotland, so the landscape felt familiar but different. I still visit there today. I wrote about my adventures in a diary. That was my first try at travel writing, which later became my career.
**Sophia**  
There is a small train from Hythe to Dungeness, run by hobbyists. I always travel first class because it is not much more expensive. The scenery is not amazing. The train goes across Romney Marsh with sheep and next to a canal. But I love when the train goes through back gardens. We can see people doing everyday things like making tea or washing dishes. I see myself as a woman in a small train, looking into people's homes. I like the ordinary landscape. Just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look closely to find something special.
**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful and remote coast. The beaches are hard to reach and have many rocks, so there are not many people. Some brave surfers come, but most people enjoy the sea's beauty. The coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are walks along the coast and trips inland through valleys with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple accommodation with a family in the village of Southole.
**Annette**  
My favourite place in England is the Trough of Bowland. It is a wide-open moorland, perfect for hiking. There are not many people living or visiting there. It is an unknown, empty, and remote area. I like the feeling of space. I found it by chance when I was a student. Since then, I visit every year, alone, with my boyfriend, and now with my son. It has not changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits special. It makes me sad that he is growing up in a city.
**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favourite house in Britain. I wanted peace and to connect with my English roots. I grew up in Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, England. I used to cycle around the moors and village streets. We had a story about a place we never cycled past: if you went down the driveway, you'd never return. That place was Glenthorne. It's the place of my dreams. It's a magical, quiet, romantic house. You can't hear anything except the sea, wind, and birds.

Title: ANIMAL ADVENTURE
We are a family that loves animals and enjoys having them around. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work. She was excited because she found a pine snake. "Can we keep it?" she asked. I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank for animals we found, so we could look at them and read about them in our natural history book.
I got home late and started cooking when I heard my sons shouting, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I ran to their room. The problem was with Domino, our cat, and Bianca, a white mouse I got for Mother's Day. Domino had the mouse in his mouth and was running around the room. The room was full of furniture and children, and Domino was trying to find a way to enjoy his catch. I tried to help but tripped and fell.
While on the floor, I saw the snake escaping from its tank. It was moving across the floor. The room was chaotic with the cat, mouse, kids, and now the snake. The dog was barking too. I quickly turned off the boiling pot in the kitchen and came back to the room. I managed to catch Domino by the tail and saved the mouse, which was unharmed.
