Interestingly, the same mouse was caught by the cat three more times but lived a long life.
Feeling confident, I turned my attention to the snake. It was not easy to catch. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, trying to calm it down. Slowly, the snake relaxed, and I carefully picked it up. I took it to the garden and pointed it towards a tree, hoping it would leave. But when I let go of its head, the snake wrapped around my shoulders like a scarf. It seemed to like me because I was warm.
My eldest child, DJ, said, "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't." We all helped to gently move the snake towards the tree. It finally climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last part of its tail vanished, my three-year-old, Clay, said, "Boy, that was one big snake!"

'Write Me a Letter! In our fast world of phones, fax machines, and computers, the old art of letter writing might disappear. But for me, getting a letter is special. There is the excitement when it arrives, the pleasure of seeing who it is from, and the joy of reading it. I have been writing letters for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. She always made me write my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday presents. It didn't matter how short or messy they were, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote once a week, and so did my mother. Sometimes my father wrote, and his long, funny letters were always a joy to receive. Most letters from home were about everyday events with my parents and their friends. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters most. There were also letters from my boyfriends. I often had boyfriends who were away for work or study, and we stayed in touch by writing. Instead of hurting the relationships, letter writing seemed to make them better. I found I could express myself more easily in writing than by talking. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but it's even better to have a year's worth of news! It's even better when it's an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps. My overseas letters come from Mangala in Sri Lanka, someone I trained with over 20 years ago. I also have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. Then there's the lady who writes to me from France. If we hadn't talked in a restaurant on the way home from holiday, if my husband hadn't taken her photo, and if I hadn't asked for her address, I would never have been able to write to her. More importantly, if she hadn't replied, we would have missed out. Now, we write to each other regularly. I can improve my French (she speaks no English); we have stayed at her home twice, and she has stayed with us. My biggest letter-writing success was this summer when my family and I stayed with my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that a correspondence could last so long. The local newspaper even wrote about it on the front page. I am happy that my children are continuing the tradition. Like my mother, I make them write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly encourage readers not to let letter writing become a 'lost art'.'

Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**
Many old pictures carved into rocks in France are being destroyed. Scientists are worried that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego, in the French Alps, are being damaged quickly. These drawings are 4,000 years old and show cows with horns, fields, and gods. The mountain was once a place for prayer. As more people visit, the pictures are being ruined by graffiti. Jean Clottes, from the International Committee on Rock Art, says, 'People think the pictures will always be there, but if the damage continues, they will be gone in 50 years.' He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings and even taking pieces home. Some visitors rub the drawings to take better photos, which damages them. Others scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks.
Experts disagree on how to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, from the Museum of Natural History in Paris, thinks the best way is to stop people from visiting, except on guided tours. He says this will save the site and help research. Clottes disagrees, saying this will upset local people. He believes they should do everything possible to save the site. David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says the area is too big to stop all damage, and they don't have enough money for guards. They might need to charge visitors a fee.
In Nice, Annie Echassoux is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reach, more damage will happen. She thinks they should rope off the area and use guides. She says money must be found to protect the site because it is a historic place. If they don't act, the drawings will be lost for future generations.

'Shopping with Children Shopping with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, 'They want everything they see. If it's not the latest sugary cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually all three. I can't buy all this stuff, and I feel guilty if I do. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make choices. I can't win.' Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This number is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why parents say no to buying things. Arguments about sugar being bad for teeth are not as convincing as the fun and emotional TV ads. Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, 'Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with ads and having to say no to their children.' The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb says, 'The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can't say, "Ask your mum to buy this," that's still what they want.' Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and ads, so they don't ask for things she won't buy. Parents also admit they are not always consistent. Mike, a father of two, says, 'We say no to sweets because they're bad, but we buy chocolate for ourselves. It's nice to buy treats, and it's normal for children to want them too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on my mood. If I'm happy, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be consistent.' Supermarkets could help by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering play areas for children. Parents might spend less without their children, but shopping without their demands could attract more customers.'

**Going up the wall**
In the past, climbers went to the mountains. Now, you can climb anywhere, indoors or outdoors. At the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham's National Indoor Arena, the crowd watches French climber Francois Lombard. He is hanging upside down by two fingers on the climbing wall. The National Indoor Arena is also known for the TV show Gladiators, and both events have something in common - The Wall. This is possible because of new technology.
Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were good climbing spots. In winter, they either climbed in cold weather, walked, or climbed on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, climbers needed to stay fit. When cliffs were not usable, they used brick or stone buildings to practice. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom.
Soon, sports centers started building walls for climbing, using bricks with special edges. Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, built a climbing wall at Leeds University in the mid-1960s. He used natural rock set in concrete for the wall. Many walls like this were built in sports halls in the 1970s, but they had problems. These walls were only vertical, unlike real cliffs with overhangs and angles. Also, once built, they couldn't be changed, and climbers got bored.
In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a material shaped like real cliff features. These could be attached to any wall and changed when climbers wanted something new. French companies also started using panels on steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for overhanging walls, but steel frames could be set up anywhere. This system gave climbers many new holds to try.

'So you want to be an actor? If you tell someone that you want to be an actor, they will probably say it is 'risky'. And yes, acting is a risky career. There are more actors than there are jobs for them. When you decide to become an actor, some friends might say you are crazy, but others might think differently. Everyone will give you different advice. But it is your choice, and only you can make it happen. There are no easy ways to become an actor. There are no exams to pass, and no guarantee that you will succeed after your training. It depends on luck and talent. But there is always a need for new faces and talent, and acting can be exciting and glamorous, with the chance of big rewards. People often ask what talent is. I think it is natural skill plus imagination. It also involves courage and belief in what you are doing. Why do people want to act? It is hard to explain. In the theatre, the important thing is the moment of connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is what drives actors to act. If you ask actors how they succeed, they might not know. They know about their skills and techniques, but they do not take success for granted. They know they are only as good as their current job, and fame might not last. Disappointment is the biggest enemy for actors. Last month, you might have been out of work, selling clothes or waitressing. Then you get an audition, but you might not get the job. So, actors do not talk about their chances. They find ways to handle the stress of competing for a part and the possibility of rejection. Nobody likes being rejected. And remember, rejection is possible from the first moment you start auditioning. You are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. And, in many ways, it is up to you. If you do not care enough, no one else will care for you.'

**Food for Everyone**
We are excited to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available now.
**A. Delia Smith**
When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, Delia Smith often comes to mind. Her recipes come from all over the world and are known for being exciting and easy to follow. Her book, "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course," is a must-have for modern cooks. It offers simple guidance on cooking, along with hundreds of great recipes. The book has been updated recently and is perfect for anyone who wants just one cookbook.
**B. Raymond Blanc**
Raymond Blanc became a top chef in just 15 years. His book, "Blanc Mange," goes with his first TV series. Raymond wants to help us become better cooks by showing how ingredients work together. He believes cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. The book has over 80 recipes and explains why some dishes might not work. It also includes some basic food chemistry. Raymond loves to cook for others, and this book shows how good he is at it.
**C. Le Cordon Bleu**
Le Cordon Bleu is famous for classical French cooking. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, the school released "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook," featuring 100 respected recipes. The book starts with basic kitchen skills and includes sections on Appetisers, Main dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe has step-by-step illustrations and photos of the finished dish. Expert chefs from around the world share their famous recipes and secrets.
**D. Nigel Slater**
Nigel Slater, food editor of The Observer, believes good food doesn't have to take long to make. His book, "The 30-Minute Cook," shows that you can make tasty meals quickly. Nigel thinks you can create something delicious in the time it takes to deliver a pizza. The book has over 200 recipes from around the world, all ready in 30 minutes. Nigel's style is fun and enjoyable, and his recipes prove that fast food can be great food.

'We are all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, 'Do you want to be the flagpole on a ship?' because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every ten years, people in Europe grow about one centimeter taller. More tall people are being born each year. This doesn't mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are returning to our size from 40,000 years ago. Back then, people ate a variety of foods. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. They ate about 85 different wild plants. But 9,000 years ago, farming started, which changed everything. Farmers took over green areas, and now three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - give us more than half of our calories. This poor diet made people less healthy and shorter. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Farming spread because it could support more people, even if they were not well-nourished. Only recently have diets improved in Europe, the US, and Japan. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is good, but it brings problems. Beds are still 190 cm long, and leg-room in planes and trains is small. Clothes manufacturers have to change their products. We can't grow forever. There must be a limit. Robert Fogel from the University says it could be 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. But scientists say that while individuals are getting taller, as a species, we are shrinking. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate warmed, we became thinner and smaller. If the planet continues to heat up, we might shrink more. So, global warming could stop us from growing taller.'

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years, working in the City became boring. I didn't plan to leave for another five or ten years, but then I lost my job unexpectedly. I didn't get much money, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with a top restaurant. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm happy not to be in an office anymore, but I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and sell a product."
**The Painter**
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now works as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy and becoming an artist was a logical choice. A career counsellor helped me. I was the first person to tell him, 'I don't want to go back to my old job.' Most people in their mid-forties need to work for money, but our children didn't need our support. We moved to the north of England, leaving our friends, but they still visit us."
**The Hat Maker**
Katherine Goodison was a company lawyer for five years before starting her own business making hats in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and paid well, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to work more hours as a senior partner, so I left. Some people thought I'd get bored, but I haven't. The secret is having deadlines. In fashion, there's always something to do, so I keep a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I miss socializing with colleagues, but I love being responsible for my product. If I do a bad job, it's my fault. You care more when your name is on the product."
**The Masseur**
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, making deals. I liked the excitement but didn't find it rewarding. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year to find out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gyms and talked to the owners. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I feel in control and have peace of mind now."

**Two Brothers and Their Childhood Game**
Dave and Norm Lagasse are two brothers in their forties with bushy beards. They live in a simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA. They are playing a game from their childhood called pichenotte. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, who was a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and taught it to his family. The family loved playing it on weekends and holidays. When they moved to New Mexico, they continued to play with the board their grandfather made from old wooden crates. Visitors were often curious about the game because it was not known in southern USA.
Three years ago, Dave noticed the old board was damaged and decided to make a new one. It was so nice that a relative and then a friend wanted one too. To see if others were interested, the brothers took a board to a sports bar in Santa Fe. At first, people were not interested, but once they tried it, they loved it. Dave researched the game's history and found it might have started in India with a game called 'carroms'. It then became 'squails' in Britain and was brought to Canada by British immigrants. In Quebec, it became known as pichenotte.
Pichenotte is a game of skill for two to four players. Each player has 12 pieces or 'pucks' to flick across a board using one finger. Flicking a puck into a small hole earns 20 points. There are three rings around the hole worth 15, 10, and 5 points. Eight small posts make the game more challenging. A game usually lasts two minutes.
Seeing how popular the game was, the brothers made more boards and sold them at markets and craft fairs. The game became so popular that championships started, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. The boards sold quickly, so the brothers decided to make pichenotte their full-time business. They set up a workshop in their garage and have made over 450 boards. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12kg, and is 1cm thick. They sell for $595 on the brothers' website.
There are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows yet, but the brothers hope their business will grow. They dream of one day having a luxury car in their garage instead of wood and tools. Until then, they enjoy playing the game they love.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**
When you first enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago this was just a piece of empty land, covered with wild plants. For a long time, people thought it was useless land. But one man, with the help of his wife, turned it into the beautiful place you see today. Many tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into the landscape you see now. Machines helped, but a lot of hard work was also needed. After shaping the land, about 1,000 tonnes of topsoil were added to create the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens.
Hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted in the Model Village. These plants had to be chosen carefully because they needed to survive the salty air from the sea and strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some came from as far as Canada and New Zealand.
The whole village was designed by Colin Sims. He made over 100 models by himself over nine years, starting when the village opened in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, wood, and plastic to last in all weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to understand how materials would last over time, but he soon became an expert himself.
You will see that the models are all made to the same scale, with great attention to detail. This was done with patience and special building techniques. The Model Village is a popular attraction known for its high-quality work. The techniques used here are now used in other model villages in England and are even taught in some schools.
All the model buildings show traditional British architecture but are not exact copies of real places. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower. It is based on manor houses from the West Country. As you walk around, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini-golf course, which is the newest addition.
Please stay on the paths and do not touch the models; a small mistake can cause hours of repair work. You can take photos from the paths. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead. To enjoy the Model Village more, you will find buttons in front of some models. Press them to make the models move.
At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your thoughts. New models are always being planned, and your ideas can help us make the village more interesting. We also want to know if any models need improvement. We hope you enjoy your visit and come back again. Don't forget to tell your friends about it.

'Every week, British tabloid newspapers show pictures that invade people's privacy and break the newspaper editors' rules. Sometimes pop stars pose for photographers, but this is not common. Usually, these pictures hurt famous people when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, few people ask for help from the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), an organization made to handle these issues. These pictures rarely serve the public interest. Do private photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens photos before, and since she was in a hotel, where she should expect privacy, she had a good reason to complain, but she didn't. It is surprising that the PCC did not start an investigation. They should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. The pop star, like the actress, did not make a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on these and other unfair stories? At first, this seems like a good idea. It would lead to many decisions against newspapers. These would be reported by other newspapers and on TV and radio. The public would not support the newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such material. Even photographers would be affected, as they could not afford to spend time hiding to take pictures of celebrities. If the PCC decided to act like a 'police officer', there would be problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it ask the victim to complain? And if the person still refused, should it continue anyway? Also, celebrities and royalty might expect every story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't. The role is too big. How could the PCC watch all British newspapers: national, regional, and magazines? There is also the embarrassment factor. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the embarrassment of an investigation? Most people probably want to forget it and move on. Some may have other reasons for staying quiet. A worse story might exist that they have kept from the press, and they know it might come out if they complain. In other words, even the PCC might become the enemy. A British comedian also suffered when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He didn't complain then, nor recently, when he and his family were photographed during a holiday. He feared that the newspaper, News of the World, would show the pictures again with a new story about his 'anger', saying it was just a joke, and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People think they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.'

Many people give advice to college graduates looking for their first job. This article is about moving to a second job. We are not talking about those looking for a second temporary job while searching for a permanent one. We are also not talking about those leaving a bad job in the first few weeks. Instead, we focus on those taking a real step in their career, choosing a job that matches their goals now that they have some experience and skills. What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to ask yourself if you want to specialize in a certain area, move up to higher responsibility, or change to a different field. Whatever you decide, choose your second job carefully. You should plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next job. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow and give you more responsibility. If you want to travel, now is a good time to do it. You can do temporary work when you return and then find your second job. Future employers will be glad to see that you have traveled and are not likely to leave again soon. Juliette Davidson spent her first year after leaving St. Aldate's College working for three lawyers. It was a great first job because they were very supportive. She learned about office work and improved her computer skills. However, there was no chance to move up. One day she quit, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year. Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. 'In two and a half years, I have become more skilled and my job has grown,' she says. 'From the start, my boss wanted to help me develop. My job title is the same, but my duties have changed. I went from mostly typing and phone work to handling most of the correspondence and budgets. I also deal with different questions, from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own business. Brenda includes me in all her work and gives me specific projects and events to organize.'

Title: How to Become Confident
Confident people might seem like they were always confident, but many learned it over time. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.
A. Jenny
When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At 25, I helped at my daughter's school. I was nervous but did well. Someone suggested I take a university course. I was scared on my first day, but my confidence grew. Working at the school changed my life.
B. Michaela
Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and acted too aggressive at first. I learned that to be confident, you must believe in yourself. If work is too much, I don't feel bad about leaving some tasks for the next day. When faced with something hard, I remind myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you less confident, so I talk to myself to overcome it.
C. Lisa
People think I'm confident, but when I look calm, I'm actually scared. In TV, looking confident is important. Interviewing people taught me that everyone gets nervous, and we feel better when talking to friendly people. My mom once told me, "Who's looking at you? Everyone's worried about themselves." I remember this advice. You gain confidence by facing fears. I was nervous for my driving test but passed. After that, I felt less scared.
D. Barbara
I enjoy my work, which gives me confidence. Over time, I've built it up. By learning from mistakes, you become more confident. I work hard and am liked at the restaurant, but not everyone likes me. I don't let that bother me. You should like yourself for who you are. My company offers training courses that boost my confidence. Setting small goals helps you see progress, rather than aiming too high and achieving nothing.
E. Kim
After college, I worked as a secretary and was too scared to speak in meetings. Eventually, I started speaking up. In politics, I was nervous about public speaking. I told myself, "People do this every day, so you can too." Writing notes helped me feel better. Everyone gets nervous speaking in public. The secret to confidence is telling yourself, "Nothing is impossible."

'Visit to Malaysia Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled when I gave him his broken kite. 'You should keep it,' he said, 'it's a tradition - if the line breaks, the finder keeps it ... and I have many more.' He showed me a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were 120cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and bamboo. We sat next to them under the trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and watched Malaysia's biggest kite festival. In the middle of the beach were 10 platforms, where helpers held the kites, and a line of competitors waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered and the kites flew up like rockets. More than 500 men and boys joined the competition, which lasts five days every year. Each person entered four different designs, judged on decoration, stability, and flying skill. 'Flying kites isn't hard,' said Adnan, 'but making them takes skill. Visit me at home and I'll show you how.' I accepted his invitation. At his house, I drank cold tea and ate fish crackers. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to fix his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, into mountains with thick rainforest. I took a wrong turn and the road ended at a river. A boat was there to take people across. Nearby, a sign pointed up a path into the forest: 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km.' I didn't know that most of this path was steep and slippery. When I reached the track, I found a man with a flask of tea. This was Baba, who took care of a kitchen and some bamboo huts. I decided to stay, trying not to think about insects under my mattress. The night was very dark and full of sounds. A waterfall was loud nearby and many creatures moved and made noises. In the morning, there was a great view of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind, then lightning hit the treetops. I got soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the big butterflies avoided the rain. I also worried about my car being washed away and the chance of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, the car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track. In Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, people asked me questions: 'Where are you from?' 'How old are you?' But they were very friendly. Kelantan is famous for its kites, but I remember it more for its kind people.'

'What kind of shopper are you? Whether you love it or hate it, we all go shopping. But there are different types of shoppers. Do you know which one you are? Abby Edwards asked some people ... A. Melanie, 22, dancer I'm an addict - I can't spend enough money! When I have cash, I'm out shopping, and then I feel happy. I find it hard to walk past sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often go shopping together. We're an addicted couple! B. Brenda, 40, office manager I'm a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I don't spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we all have different tastes. I don't spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and rarely tell my husband how much I've spent - I always say it's less! The real price always sounds too high. C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager I only shop for essentials. I hate shopping and only go when I really have to. When I do, I know what I want and I won't choose anything else. I find shopping tiring and there's always something I'd rather do. D. Anita, 35, TV producer I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time and I get in and out quickly. I do have some mistakes at the back of my wardrobe, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes gets it wrong! E. Lizzie, 41, secretary I don't enjoy shopping at all. I really dislike shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want or anyone to help me. The shops are too noisy, everything is messy, and I find it a nightmare. Luckily, I rarely have to shop for clothes because most of my clothes are given to me. For food shopping, I go to the local supermarket once a week and finish it quickly! F. Lisa, 22, actress I'm probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out to look around the shops with my friends, and we often end up buying things. I don't usually have a specific item in mind, but if something catches my eye, I'll buy it. G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant I'm a careful shopper - I like going, but I don't buy much. I usually know what I want and I rarely go crazy. I sometimes shop to cheer myself up, but I usually feel worse because I've spent too much! H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on a Saturday because it's too busy. I'd say I'm a careful shopper. I always have an idea of what I want, and I never buy things immediately. I look in other shops to find a better deal - I take a long time! I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager I'm an unwilling shopper - maybe because I work in the city centre, the shops have lost their attraction for me. When I have to, I'll go shopping, but I don't try things on because it's too much trouble. Clothes I buy don't always fit, but I don't mind too much. I'd rather make a few mistakes than spend a lot of effort shopping!'
